  "translated_title": "[Cover Story] The People of Daechi-dong",
  "translated_text": "Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul], are you curious about how your neighbors live? Or do you want to know what their interests are? Here are the answers. JoongAng Ilbo dissects Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] inside and out every week.

The first target is Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry].

Meet the real inner lives through 'The People of Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry],' a three-week consecutive series.

To survive in a credential-based society, you must go to 'Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry]'
Why did we board a train with no brakes?

Order of 'The People of Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry]' articles:
1. Why did we board a train with no brakes?
2. Their world that outsiders can't understand
3. Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] kids' yesterday, today, and tomorrow

Metro G Team = Ahn Hye-ri, Lee Won-jin, Kim So-yeop, Park Hyung-su, Jeon Min-hee, Kang Na-hyeon reporters, Photo = Kim Kyung-rok reporter

Their children's grade levels, husbands' occupations, personal educational backgrounds, and ages were all different, but they agreed on exactly one point. They had "boarded a train with no brakes (college entrance exams)." While outsiders see this as precarious, no one in Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] wants to get off this train.

Instead, they say "we're fortunate to be able to board this train even now." The reason is that there's no place like Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] for surviving Korea's persistent and tiresome credential-based society. They firmly believed that "sending children to good universities is the only way to climb the ladder of social mobility, or at least maintain the same social status as our generation."

Professor Lee (40, female), who finished 10 years of living in America and moved to Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] last year for her two children's education, said, "I wish someone could prove that this path I'm walking isn't the right answer," adding "but until I know this isn't the answer, I absolutely cannot stop."

Especially the Daejeon-jok [families who relocate to Daechi-dong specifically for their children's education] who have staked everything on their children's education desperately cling to hagwon education. Because they pour everything into education costs, they can't even dream of preparing for retirement. Their future is mortgaged to their children's hagwon education. To people outside Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry], this is truly a 'strange land.' But from the perspective inside Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry], it's the most rational choice.

Lee (42, female), who moved into Eunma Apartments in Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] on jeonse [a Korean housing rental system where tenants pay a large lump sum deposit instead of monthly rent] last year, is a somewhat unusual case. Usually mothers push to come here, but in the Lee family, it was her husband Jeong (47) who strongly wanted it. The trigger was when their son, who had been doing well in middle school, saw his grades drop. Jeong said, "My boss at work, who sent all his kids to university from Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry], told me 'there's no place like Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] for educating kids,'" so he immediately had them pack their belongings. At first, Jeong also hesitated. But his boss's words "think of it as an investment in your child" were decisive.

Jeong became unemployed when his company went bankrupt during the 1997 financial crisis. He now works as a deputy manager at a large corporation, but that experience still remains a wound. During his unemployment, Jeong blamed his mediocre educational background a lot. He confided, "I felt painfully that you need at least good credentials to somehow survive."

Jeong's monthly salary is approximately 5 million won [approximately $3,750 USD]. Half of that goes to hagwon fees for his son (17) and daughter (14). Although his mother-in-law is unwell and requires monthly hospital expenses, he says hagwon education costs absolutely cannot be reduced. Lee said, "2.5 million won [approximately $1,875 USD] per month for two kids is probably not a very large amount in this neighborhood," adding "we sent the kids to hagwons when we lived in Hwagok-dong too, but not to this extent." She said, "Hwagok-dong is also a place with high interest in education, but coming here, it's a completely different world," sighing "I'm so exhausted I want to go back, but my husband won't even listen, saying 'the kids need to study well so we can be comfortable later.'"

Not just the Lee family, but most Daejeon-jok [families who relocate to Daechi-dong specifically for their children's education] go 'all-in' on their children's education, or rather hagwon education. When we looked at the proportion of education costs relative to income, Daechi 1-2 dong reached 45.8%. This means they spend half their earnings on education costs. They use the other half for living expenses. Naturally, there's insufficient money left to invest for retirement.

The Korea Development Institute's report on domestic household education expenditure (2012) shows how serious the situation is. As of 2011, the education poor, so-called edu-poor, reached 824,000 households nationwide. A significant portion of Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] Daejeon-jok [families who relocate to Daechi-dong specifically for their children's education] belong to this category.

Why do they insist on being Daejeon-jok [families who relocate to Daechi-dong specifically for their children's education] even to the point of becoming penniless? The peculiarities of Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] schools contribute to the locals' extreme hagwon education. Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] schools only have high-achieving top students and bottom-tier students who form the base. There's no middle. This is a strange phenomenon compared to schools in other areas where middle-tier students make up the majority.

Lee Ji-hyeon (42, Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry]), who has a second-year middle school son, said, "When they take exams, it's either 90s or 40-50s," adding "there are absolutely no mediocre scores in between." Lee cited the hagwon education effect as the reason. "Children who receive proper hagwon education help from their mothers maintain top ranks, but without hagwon education, they can only hover in the bottom ranks."

Park Eun-ju (41, Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry]), who has siblings in second year of middle school and first year of high school, said, "Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] mothers don't just send their children to any hagwon, but accurately know their children's weak areas and send them to places that can supplement those areas," adding "I feel frustrated when I see mothers who just go to hagwons saying 'please take good care of my child.'" She added, "Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] is a place where you can't compete unless mothers properly understand their children academically," explaining "this is why it's difficult to succeed when you come at a mediocre time."

This means that native Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] children start hagwon education from kindergarten and systematically establish long and short-term plans, so it's not easy for children who transfer in middle or high school to quickly catch up to the study volume that native children have accumulated. That's why Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] mothers unanimously say, "If you're considering becoming Daejeon-jok [families who relocate to Daechi-dong specifically for their children's education], you must make the decision by fourth grade at the latest."

Choi Eun-young (42, Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry]) said, "Entry into Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] becomes harder to catch up the later you are," adding "because this is a place where advanced learning proceeds with such intense rigor, when you transfer in the middle, both mothers and children struggle between keeping up with grade-level classes and advanced learning." As a result, they push themselves harder, and in this process, parent-child relationships often become strained.

According to a Gangnam District Office survey, Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] mothers had worse relationships with both their husbands and children compared to mothers in other Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] areas. When asked if they were satisfied with their relationships with their children, Apgujeong-dong mothers averaged 4.34 points (out of 5). However, Dogok 2-dong and Daechi 1-2 dong, which includes Tower Palace and is part of greater Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry], scored only 3.5 and 4.1 points respectively.

Satisfaction with spousal relationships showed similar patterns. Because parent-child relationships aren't good, children don't open up to their parents even when they have concerns. When asked who they would consult about their worries, only 13.9% of Daechi 1-2 dong students answered parents. Dogok 2-dong was slightly higher at 38.4%, but significantly lower compared to Apgujeong-dong (62.8%).

Mothers who drive their children into hagwon education to the point where families become distant. Perhaps it's because many mothers suffer from educational background complexes? However, reality is the opposite. Good educational backgrounds are basic, and there are many mothers with professional jobs like teachers or doctors that others envy. Regardless of educational background or occupation, mothers line up to become Daejeon-jok [families who relocate to Daechi-dong specifically for their children's education].

Kim (48, female, Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry]), a native Daechi resident, said, "I don't understand why everyone flocks to Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry]," adding "newcomers aren't welcome." Yet she also complained, "Honestly, it's true that it's convenient for hagwon education compared to other areas and the academic atmosphere is far superior," but "the image of Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] has become too negative because of the overheated competition among Daejeon-jok [families who relocate to Daechi-dong specifically for their children's education] mothers."

Lee (41, female, Mapo District), a high school teacher, also sent her daughter (16), who became a high school student this year, to a Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] school. Lee said, "Once you send them to Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] hagwons, as a working mother, you need to worry relatively less," explaining "because the hagwons check every move of the children and inform mothers of each day's situation." She also said it was an advantage that "children can feel viscerally that there's nothing to do but study wherever they go."

While it seems like you need to abandon 'yourself' and cling entirely to your children to properly care for them in Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry], there are quite a few opinions that it's actually a customized neighborhood for working mothers. The logic is that because you can't check on children daily like full-time housewives do, Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry], which is a perfect 'vacuum state' except for studying, is optimal.

Dr. Baek (50, Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry]) said, "It's not easy for working mothers to get information from other mothers," adding "female doctors in the Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] area have created a female doctor community to share information." She claimed, "There are hagwons that meticulously analyze children's study tendencies, which actually resolves anxiety." She said, "Hagwons send real-time texts about children's movement routes, so I can feel at ease," adding "Even though I'm a busy mother, I'm confident that I know thoroughly about my child's grades and life."

However, some say that mothers who catch both rabbits of their own careers and Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] education are not mainstream in Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry]. Most Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] mothers said, "Success as Daejeon-jok [families who relocate to Daechi-dong specifically for their children's education] is guaranteed by mothers' sacrifice."

Of course, it's not sacrifice without compensation. Children repay their mothers' sacrifice with results: prestigious universities and professional jobs after graduation.

Byeon Hee-geum (48, female, Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry]) said, "Because my husband went abroad as an expatriate, our whole family lived in Ecuador and Venezuela, and when we first returned to Korea, we lived in Bundang," adding "all the kids speak English at native level, but we couldn't find hagwons that matched their level in Bundang, so we came to Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] four years ago." Her son, who was a high school freshman at the time, adapted well going between Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] schools and hagwons, and smoothly entered Sungkyunkwan University's Global Studies program. Byeon said, "Having lived here, Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] is the best neighborhood for teaching kids to study," adding "no matter what level a child is at, you can find a hagwon here that offers classes at exactly the right level." She also added, "If you use it well, it's not something to view only negatively."

Dr. Kim (44, Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry]) and his wife have a similar stance. The couple receives consulting from education experts together while educating their two middle school sons. What's unique is that they only provide hagwon education for two subjects and have the brothers study self-directedly. Both maintain top grades at Daecheong Middle School.

The surrounding reactions are interesting. Wife Jeon's (42) explanation: "I don't go to mothers' gatherings much. Since our kids don't receive much hagwon education but study well, surrounding mothers are very interested. They constantly call and point out that 'you're educating your children wrong.' They advise that kids should try bad things in advance, telling me to 'let them go to PC rooms too.' They also offer to include them in projects with their own kids. Whenever I feel anxious wondering if I'm doing wrong, my husband helps me stay centered, saying 'don't be swayed.' It's that the Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] mothers who go on hagwon pilgrimages attack us to justify their own behavior."

Jeon said, "It's really difficult to educate children when spouses think differently," adding "fortunately, we are of one mind, so we were able to maintain our philosophy.""
}

{
  "translated_title": "[Cover Story] The Truth About Performance Assessment",
  "translated_text": "One mother with a middle school child says: Her child's performance assessments are nothing but torture for the mother, everything is wrong from beginning to end. The school teacher says: The problem is mothers who interfere with every aspect of their child's academic process and don't trust the school.

So we listened to both mothers and schools. We met mothers whose children attend 14 schools including Gyeongwon Middle School, Daemyeong Middle School, Daewang Middle School, Daecheong Middle School, Sehwa Girls' Middle School, Sungmun Middle School, Sindong Middle School, Sinsa Middle School, Apgujeong Middle School, Yeoksam Middle School, Changdeok Girls' Middle School, Changmun Girls' Middle School, Cheongdam Middle School, and Hwimon Middle School. The more complaints mothers had about schools, the more their memories differed from teachers' to the point where it was questionable whether they were talking about the same performance assessments.

Would you like to judge what the truth really is?

Last April, apples suddenly sold out at fruit stores around Guhyundai Apartments in Apgujeong-dong. The reason for the apple shortage was none other than a home economics performance assessment at nearby Apgujeong Middle School. How are performance assessments conducted that such things happen? We listened to parents from 14 middle schools in Seoul. When compiled, roughly five types of complaints emerged.

First, they don't understand what educational purpose the performance assessment tasks serve. Second, they don't understand what criteria are used for evaluation. Third, they don't understand why things not taught in school are being evaluated. Fourth, they don't understand why tasks are sent home instead of being done during school hours. Finally, they claim it's reverse discrimination against male students.

The mother of Mr. Choi, who has a son in first grade at Apgujeong Middle School, said, "When I heard they were doing apple peeling in a spiral as a performance assessment, the family sat around to demonstrate apple peeling, and the child peeled over 10 apples for the first time in his life even though no one was going to eat them." She said, "Spiral apple peeling isn't an easy task for a child who has never held a fruit knife," adding with a grimace, "We ended up using half a box of apples for practice but still only got a B."

Another parent, Mr. Kim, made this claim: "They timed the test and my child got nervous and first quartered the apple. Then the teacher immediately gave him a D. Couldn't they give him another chance to peel an apple? What help is apple peeling ability going to be in life..."

Mr. Choi's mother told a similar story. "My child practiced frying eggs the night before the technology and home economics performance assessment, making a mess of the kitchen, but still got a C," she said. "The reason for getting a C was that another friend accidentally knocked over the frying pan while passing by." She said, "Later I pleaded for another chance since it wasn't our child's fault, and the teacher raised the score of the child who knocked over the pan from A to B, and our child's score from C to B," complaining, "Won't this just make relationships between children worse?"

There are also complaints about English performance assessments. The complaint is about the 'mileage book' system where students receive one stamp each time they interview with a native speaker teacher. This is because not all students get equal opportunities - interviews with native speakers are limited to 5 students per day on a first-come, first-served basis. A parent of second-grader Kim said, "Even though regular arrival time is 8:30 AM, even going to school at 7:30 AM often fails to secure an interview appointment," claiming, "Notebooks with many stamps often get stolen." He said, "I don't understand why they conduct evaluations that make kids steal and mothers suspicious of each other."

Second: Ambiguous evaluation methods
There are many complaints about scoring based on handwriting style and volume rather than content. A parent at Sindong Middle School said, "Recently there was a Korean performance assessment with the task 'Let me introduce myself,' so I asked senior mothers and they said you just need to write a lot with pretty handwriting," adding, "Our child got an A but I felt bitter." She added, "Hearing another child's mother blame herself saying 'I didn't have information so only our child suffered,' I thought this isn't studying but evaluation to match teacher preferences."

This means mothers' information networks affect not only hagwon education but also performance assessments significantly.

There are also high complaints about group evaluation methods.
A parent with a first-grader at Sehwa Girls' Middle School said, "The current group evaluation system is where good students earn scores for poor students too," adding, "It feels bad as only hardworking kids get taken advantage of." Third-grader Kim at Daewang Middle School had a similar experience in last year's physical education performance assessment. Kim's mother said, "The task was for groups to create choreography and perform group dance, but nobody was motivated," adding, "Our child alone stomped her feet creating the choreography, but when they couldn't perform the group dance in front of the teacher, they all got 0 points together." She said, "After group evaluations end, there are often hurt feelings between children and parents," adding, "If teachers can't manage by clearly dividing group member roles, I wish they wouldn't do group evaluations."

Third: Testing without teaching
Many parents are bewildered when schools test things they haven't taught. They say isn't this the school saying it will only give high scores to students who improved their skills through hagwon education.

A parent with a second-grade male student at Sinsa Middle School talked about music performance assessment. He said, "They could teach instruments anyone can play like recorders and evaluate everyone equally with that, but I don't understand why they do group evaluation with ensemble that they don't even teach in school." The point is that children who received instrumental lessons from a young age inevitably get good scores. He concluded: "Performance assessment scores correlate highly not with children's ability but with their family's economic power." "For science performance assessments, you have to pay money and entrust it completely to professional companies to get good scores, and for music you have to attach vocal lessons to get scores. The saying that you can't quit hagwon education because of performance assessments is really true."

A parent with a third-grade daughter at Apgujeong Middle School also said "It's all about money," stating, "Not only performance assessments but most school awards are often done by hagwon instructors while children just receive the awards."

Fourth: Performance assessments are mothers' scores
Parents' biggest complaint is that performance assessments aren't finished at school but brought home. The moment that happens, it becomes mothers' homework.

Sinsa Middle School goes through upheaval every summer vacation because of science performance assessments. Students set research topics, then submit research results to be reflected as second semester science performance assessment scores.

Ms. Lee, mother of third-grader Jang at this school, said, "It costs at least 1 million won [approximately $750 USD] to do one science performance assessment." Lee said, "In first grade, not knowing better, I really let the child set his own research topic and only helped a little, but the score was low." When she visited the science teacher to ask about grading criteria, the teacher showed her a portfolio that received an A grade and a school award. It was a 20-page portfolio meticulously containing the process of setting hypotheses and verifying them through 4-5 experiments. It was obviously professional level. So in second grade, she entrusted everything to a science hagwon director in Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry]. Jang easily got an A. Lee said, "I know it's not right, but since everyone does it that way, we can't help it," adding, "Since the child dreams of going to a science high school or gifted school, there's no choice."

Teacher Jung (science) at a middle school in Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] said, "When we see performance assessment results that exceed student levels, teachers agonize over whether to exclude them entirely or judge that educational achievement was made in the process of receiving help and give scores," explaining, "Most teachers choose the latter."

Fifth: Reverse discrimination against male students?
The mother of a third-grade male student at Gyeongwon Middle School said, "For performance assessments, female students try to get scores but male students just aim to participate." A third-grade parent at Yeoksam Middle School also says, "If you send a boy to a coeducational school, you give up on performance assessments to some extent even before enrollment."

This is because performance assessment items often include 'bringing required materials' and 'attitude evaluation.' Male students are generally less meticulous and often fail to understand the performance assessment tasks pouring in from each subject. Also, note-taking included in performance assessments for each subject makes it easier for female students who write prettily and organize well to get scores.

The gender gap widens further in practical performance assessments. For example, technology and home economics subjects mainly test cooking, knitting, and cross-stitch making, giving female students an advantage.

Physical education is exceptionally advantageous for male students. But since different standards are applied for males and females, it's useless. That's why there are claims of "reverse discrimination - applying the same standards in subjects favorable to female students while applying different standards in physical education favorable to male students."

Teacher Shim (38, Korean) at a middle school in Mapo District said it's "a valid point," adding, "Including materials and attitude in performance assessments is teachers' dereliction of duty." Since performance assessment is a learning process, activity tasks that match the learning objectives of the relevant unit should be given. He claimed this phenomenon is "one of the adverse effects created as the proportion of female teachers increased."

Yeoksam Middle School has high parent satisfaction
Not a few parents support performance assessments. Schools receiving parent support had different performance assessment operation methods. They prepared mechanisms to prevent the five complaints above from interfering. For example, Daecheong Middle School, Daemyeong Middle School, and Yeoksam Middle School finish performance assessments at school. This eliminates opportunities for parent involvement. Feedback is also thorough. When Daecheong Middle School conducts music singing performance assessments, teachers mark on the score where students made mistakes. Instead of just announcing scores, they teach the parts where mistakes were made.

Schools' claims
Teachers: "Most complaints arise from parent misunderstandings"

"If it were Korean, English, or math, that would be different, but making a fuss over technology and home economics performance assessments - aren't mothers overreacting?"

Many parents react this way when hearing that mothers are troubled by their children's performance assessments. The criticism is that they're reacting too sensitively when middle school first-graders (current second-graders) changed from relative to absolute evaluation for school records [GPA], and only autonomous private high schools like Hana High School and Minjok Leadership Academy reflect all subject grades rather than just major subjects in high school admissions.

Teachers find it even more incomprehensible. Kim Sung-hee, Hana High School's planning and public relations director, emphasized, "Reflecting all subjects' school records [GPA] in admissions means to faithfully complete middle school life," adding, "Hana High School admits students at the 4-5% level of middle school school records [GPA], so there's no need to overdo it for 1-2 performance assessment points."

However, mothers obsessing over performance assessments think differently. Ms. An (42, Banpo-dong, Seoul) claimed, "Grades are displayed as absolute evaluation grades, but schools still rank students from first to last," adding, "Absolute evaluation is just 'covering your eyes and crying.'" Another parent whose daughter is preparing for Hana High School admission said, "You can quickly calculate subject rankings by looking at grade averages and standard deviations by school in addition to school record [GPA] grades," adding, "There probably isn't a Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] mother who believes the story that admissions only look at school record [GPA] grades." The logic is that since rankings are still important, not even one point can be neglected in any subject.

Whether it's mothers' groundless worries or schools' problems is unclear, but there was strong mutual distrust between parents and schools.

A parent at Daewang Middle School claimed, "We had group dance as a physical education performance assessment, but other kids in the group were insincere, so our child worked hard but got 0 points." However, Joo Mi-kyung, the physical education department head at this school, countered, "Since the basic score is 12 out of 20 points, the claim of getting 0 points is false to begin with," adding, "We guided practice during class time for 3 weeks and watched the process, so the parent's claim is groundless."

However, Daewang Middle School removed group dance from performance assessment items entirely this year due to many such parent complaints.

Sinsa Middle School, which had students submit 'science free inquiry reports' during summer vacation and reflected this as second semester science performance assessment scores, also stated, "Starting this year, we decided to accept free inquiry reports only from those who wish and exclude them from performance assessment items, and we plan to announce this soon." Jung Sung-geun, vice principal of this school, also claimed that complaints about instrumental ensemble evaluation, which has high parent criticism, are "misunderstandings." Mothers believed you need to use high-end instruments like cellos and violins to get good scores. But he explained, "You can get full marks even playing only with recorders."

Sindong Middle School, where complaints were raised that Korean performance assessments give scores based on handwriting style rather than content and send tasks home, also clarified that this is "different from facts." Ma Hee-chang, vice principal of this school, said, "We evaluate objectively based on the responsible teacher's expertise, and the principle is that all performance tasks are completed at school."

Apgujeong Middle School also reacted with "frustration." They claim that students and parents completely misunderstood the purpose of the problematic 'mileage book.' An English teacher at this school said, "Mileage book stamps can be obtained through many other methods besides first-come-first-served native speaker interviews," adding, "Students who don't prepare properly engage in stamp battles one or two days before inspection." Regarding apple peeling and egg frying performance assessments, a home economics teacher at this school said, "We evaluated tool usage ability according to the Ministry of Education's 2008 experiential evaluation policy." Also, "We never gave bad scores for quartering apples or accidentally knocking over frying pans," claiming, "If students wanted, we gave sufficient time and opportunities."

Overseas cases
USA also had fairness disputes initially, but gained parent trust through thorough feedback

"We should consider that only the name 'performance assessment' was borrowed (from foreign countries)."

This is education experts' common opinion about performance assessments implemented in domestic elementary, middle, and high schools. Performance assessment was introduced in 1999 with the intent to check students' learning activities and establish individualized teaching plans. However, performance (遂行・the act of actually carrying out work or tasks) has disappeared and only assessment remains.

Professor Song In-seop (Education) at Sookmyung Women's University pointed out, "Performance assessment has deteriorated into just another tool for ranking," adding, "We only borrowed the framework of performance assessment while actually following the limitations of written exams."

One country that started performance assessment before Korea is the United States. Private schools introduced it early, and public schools also began full-scale introduction in the late 1980s as part of educational reform. The trigger was the 1983 report 'A Nation at Risk' related to educational competitiveness. This report worried about declining academic achievement, stating, "American students' academic achievement levels are very low internationally, and about 30% of all 17-year-old students cannot read."

America's educational reform to raise academic achievement can be summarized in three main points. First, strengthening school and teacher accountability. Second, introducing state-level academic achievement tests and improving grades through them. Finally, expanding performance assessment.

Each public school conducted performance assessments by assigning project-type tasks such as research and investigation reports or experiments and practices, creating essay and written exams, and introducing various team activities into classes. Performance assessment subsequently gained attention as a new educational model that breaks away from memorization-centered education and nurtures creative talent capable of applying and integrating knowledge.

Lee Ki-dong, elementary principal at NLCS Jeju International School who worked in education in the United States for 25 years from 1985, said, "In the mid-1980s, American public schools focused only on ranking students by test scores," adding, "Performance assessment supplemented this."

Han So-young (Sogang University International Korean Studies 2), who graduated from Dwight-Englewood School, a private school in New Jersey, said, "They tell me in detail about performance assessment results - what I lack and what points I need to supplement," adding, "Perhaps because of this, I generally trust teachers' evaluations."

Principal Lee Ki-dong said, "America also had much confusion in the early days of performance assessment introduction due to issues of fairness and objectivity in the evaluation process," but explained, "Now it's much more stable." He said, "When performance assessment grading criteria were accurately announced in advance and teachers provided detailed guidance to parents about evaluation results after assessment, parents came to trust the evaluation results."

Kim Myung-hwa, research fellow at the Korea Institute for Curriculum and Evaluation, also evaluated that "the feedback process was important" in America's performance assessment establishment process. She gave an example of an elementary school in LA. Director Kim said "The effect was also significant where many top-tier middle school students gathered at specialized high school hagwons flowed directly into Daechi-dong's [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] university admission hagwons," explaining "Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] parents, who had strong educational enthusiasm and economic power, were willing to pay the high lecture fees of expensive top instructors, and top-class instructors also had no choice but to gather in Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry]." Daechi-dong's [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] hagwon district, covering international middle school-specialized high school-university admissions, wrote its myth while bustling day and night.

Hagwons Close Due to Hagwon Education Suppression, But Parent Burden Remains the Same
Experts: "Weak Public Education Cannot Bring Down Daechi-dong's [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] Stronghold"
Must First Raise School Education Level to Dismantle Hagwon Education Hub No. 1

Hagwon Education Suppression Policy... 2008 Specialized High School Selection by School Records [GPA]

However, Daechi-dong's [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] hagwon district's steep growth curve became sharply gentler between 2008-2011. The turning point was when specialized high school selection methods changed from school-specific written exams to middle school English school records [GPA] in 2008. Entering the 2010s, the 'easy CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam]' tone was maintained and the government's admission diversification policy increased university early admission programs. As CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam]'s influence became less than before, Daechi-dong's [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] heat subsided. International middle school admissions, which had driven even kindergarteners and elementary students into the hagwon education market, also changed to a lottery system in 2014.

Lee Jong-seo, director of Etoos Chungsol Evaluation Research Institute, explained "As CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] became easier, there was no need to specifically seek out Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] top instructors, and as EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] connection rates rose to 70%, 'solo test-takers' who studied independently while listening to internet lectures increased." Education critic Lee Beom said "As specialized high schools' school-specific written exams disappeared, foreign language high school admission hagwons took a direct hit," adding "Large franchise hagwons closed one after another."

The measure prohibiting hagwon classes after 10 PM, implemented from 2010, also dealt a blow to Daechi-dong's [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] hagwon district. Kim Young-gyu, director of Youngjae Hagwon, expressed that "the 'hagwon teaching time restriction measure' tightened the last breath of Daechi-dong's [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] hagwon district." Unlike before when one instructor could lecture four times a day at 4 PM, 7 PM, 10 PM, and 12 AM, being able to lecture only 1-2 times a day worsened hagwon profitability. Director Kim said "With school after-school programs making students' dismissal times later and hagwon teaching restricted to 10 PM, it became impossible to create hagwon schedules," adding "The time students stayed at hagwons itself became shorter, so we had to reduce the number of classes and instructors, and ultimately the hagwon scale had no choice but to shrink."

Large Hagwon Instructors Who Lost Jobs Move to Small Hagwons

As large hagwons' profitability worsened, hagwons put up for sale have recently increased significantly. Mr. Shin, a Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] real estate agent, said "On the surface it seems like they continue classes normally, but there are countless hagwons secretly put up at low prices, yet there aren't really people who want to buy them." Kim Gab-soo, chairman of the Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] Private Academy Federation, said "Much more hagwons than shown in statistics are disappearing," adding "It's true that Daechi-dong's [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] hagwon district is in a recession." Chairman Kim said "As large hagwons over 100 pyeong [approximately 3,300 square feet] fall into management difficulties and downsize, instructors who lost jobs in this process are opening small hagwons nearby," explaining "Large hagwons are splitting and splitting again, so just looking at numbers it seems like the number of hagwons is maintained, but individual hagwons' management conditions are becoming increasingly poor."

Director Lee, who runs a supplementary hagwon, said "Real estate agents constantly call asking me to take over hagwons," adding "I receive calls like 'It's 50 million won [approximately $38,000 USD] deposit and 3.5 million won [approximately $2,650 USD] monthly rent, with 50 students and 2 instructors. We'll hand everything over, so just take the 50 million won [approximately $38,000 USD] deposit,' which would have been unimaginable 5 years ago (when Daechi-dong's [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] situation was good)."

Education critic Lee Beom analyzed, "Changes in admission policies continuing since 2008 succeeded in segmenting the traditional hagwon education market of 'international middle school-specialized high school-university admission CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam],'" adding "Although there's talk that the early admission market grew as much as the CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] market shrank, it's not enough to offset the CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] market's reduction, so the part of curbing hagwon education through education policy can be seen as somewhat successful."

Still Inadequate Public Education: "Hagwon Education Won't Disappear"

Since this hagwon district has stagnated, is the stronghold of hagwon education hub No. 1 also crumbling? Education experts unanimously said "Daechi-dong's [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] hagwon district will find an optimized system again" and "The total scale of hagwon education costs consumed here won't decrease."

The reason they're optimistic about Daechi-dong's [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] hagwon district is simple. Korea's public education is too weak to bring down Daechi-dong's [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] stronghold. Lee Jong-seo, director of Etoos Chungsol Evaluation Research Institute, said "The first condition for hagwon education growth is precisely public education's inadequacy," adding "Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry], hagwon education hub No. 1's vitality is inversely proportional to public education's soundness."

Education critic Lee Beom also pointed out, "Korea's public education inefficiency and irresponsibility are the foundation that erected Daechi-dong's [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] hagwon district." He criticized public education's problems with specific examples. "Looking at Korea's high school curriculum, it's structured on the premise that classes occur until the day right before graduation," pointing out "In reality, since students must take CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] in November of senior year, they must finish all coursework by senior year first semester at the latest and enter college entrance exam preparation." He also said "The most ideal curriculum would be finishing all coursework by sophomore year and entering the admission system for early admission and regular admission in senior year." Since the curriculum is unrealistic, the only way for students to survive is advanced learning through hagwon education.

Counter-arguments to criticisms that Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] hagwon education increasingly targets younger students and uses fear marketing were also found in public education. Instructor Choi at P Hagwon, a reading discussion hagwon for kindergarten and elementary students, said "Parents who come here don't trust school education at all," adding "Since elementary school first grade doesn't properly teach even reading and writing Korean, parents naturally have no choice but to seek help from hagwon education." In fact, Korea's elementary school first grade has only 4 weeks allocated for the 'reading' process.

Dissatisfaction with English education is also great. Parent Cho Eun-jung (Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul], Seoul, 40) with elementary school children said "School English is just 2 hours a week from elementary 3rd grade and 3 hours from 5th grade," adding "I don't think you can master a foreign language with this level of classes." Ms. Cho said "They say they'll make CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] English an absolute evaluation qualification test to curb English hagwon education, but English isn't aimed at CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] but a basic ability children living in future society should have," raising her voice, "It's a natural result to send children to good hagwons because what schools teach is insufficient." Another parent, Kim So-yeon (Seocho-gu, Seoul, 38), pointed out, "When consulting with school teachers about children's academics, I often hear advice to 'send them to hagwons,'" adding "The problem is that even public education teachers don't think they can improve children's academic abilities through school education."

Kim Jung-baek, sociology professor at Kyung Hee University, said "Daechi-dong's [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] hagwon district received attention because it quenched the thirst that public education couldn't fill," adding "If admission policy focus is placed on 'improving public education level' rather than 'hagwon education suppression,' Daechi-dong's [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] hagwon district will naturally walk the path of dismantlement."

  "translated_text": "College Entrance Briefing Fever

Worried about falling behind on information, mothers start as early as elementary school

College entrance exams are often compared to marathons. This means establishing long-term plans and making sustained efforts. The same applies not just to students but to parents as well. In an era where students must study for CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] and school records while parents must study college admission systems. College entrance briefings help make the complex and difficult admission system and over 2,000 different admission tracks easier to understand. Even knowing these briefings are hagwon [private academy] marketing, parents flock to briefing venues. They want to establish even slightly advantageous strategies for their children. According to parents who frequently attend briefings, there are four stages to becoming an expert: confusion-addiction-stagnation-maturity. Below are photos and graphics depicting the four stages of parents' initiation into college entrance briefings, parodying 'Maslow's hierarchy of needs.' Do you frequently attend briefings? If so, which stage do you fall into? Who are these college entrance briefings, which have reached fever pitch beyond mere enthusiasm, really for?

First Confusion, Then Addiction... "I go three times a day"

At 11 AM on the 6th at the Textile Center in Samseong-dong, Seoul, about 500 parents flocked to a 'Final Strategy Briefing for 2016 Early Decision vs Regular Decision' prepared by a hagwon education company. Forty percent of attendees were men. One mother who came with her husband said, "Husband and wife must join forces for our child's college admission," adding "We came an hour early worried there might be no seats." Another parent said, "I've attended education briefings at least once a week since my current high school senior was in third grade," adding "Combined, it would exceed 300 times." The term 'college entrance briefing fever' is not an exaggeration. Beyond raising children healthily, it has become reality that parents must become education experts.

'Essential, Not Optional' Briefings

Ms. Kim (50, Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry], Seoul), who has children in 12th grade, 7th grade, and 6th grade, is frantically chasing education briefings these days. Since the educational information needed varies by grade level, there are many briefings she must attend. Sometimes she participates three or more times per day. A few days ago, she attended an 'Admission Counseling Specialist Training Course' run by a hagwon education company from 10 AM to 1 PM, then listened to a 'Strategy Briefing for 2016 Essay Writing Exam Preparation' at a small hagwon in Daechi-dong from 2 PM to 4 PM. After that, she exchanged educational information with close mothers at a cafe for about an hour, then participated in 'Preparing for Special Purpose/Autonomous Private High Schools from 7th Grade' organized by a math hagwon from 7:30 PM. Ms. Kim said, "Starting in September when entrance exams approach, there are many briefings I must attend," adding "I have less free time than when I worked."

A considerable number of parents with high educational fervor are enthusiastic about attending briefings. Just those related to college entrance exams include college application strategies, university-specific admission briefings, high school entrance briefings, international middle school admissions, hagwon briefings, and countless others. Adding briefings related to general child education such as adolescent child management, career planning lectures, and reading guidance methods increases the number much further.

College entrance briefings now seem to have become essential rather than optional. This is due to the complex college admission system and frequently changing education policies. In the 1980s during the academic achievement test era, studying well was enough to get into a good university, but now it's different. One must understand over 2,000 college admission tracks and establish strategies. Instead of busy test-takers, strategizing has become parents' responsibility. One parent met at a briefing venue said, "These days, mothers must be managers scheduling children's hagwon schedules, drivers shuttling between hagwons and schools, and even education experts," adding "Every time I come to briefings, I desperately want to emigrate."

Parents find this reality frustrating but think they have no choice but to follow along. They fear falling behind if they don't participate in briefings. Ms. Jung (53, Mokdong, Seoul), who sent both children to university, said, "I didn't feel the need to attend briefings for my first child but regretted it when writing early decision applications," adding "Later when preparing my second child's college admission, I attended every briefing I could as time permitted." Ms. Shin Jeong-yeon (49, Daechi-dong, Seoul), who has children in first year of university and 12th grade, feels the same. Ms. Shin said, "Among people around me who got into universities better than their ability level, there's no one who didn't diligently attend briefings," adding "Even if you get separate consulting for details, drawing the big picture for college admission has become the mother's role."

Flood of Briefings Since 2009 Introduction of Admissions Officer System

Briefings became as numerous as now starting from when the admissions officer system expanded in 2009. As entrance exam tracks diversified, information parents needed to know increased, and various organizations including the Korean Council for University Education (KCUE), large hagwon education companies, small tutoring hagwons, high schools, local governments, and financial sectors began holding college entrance briefings. In 2011 alone, college entrance briefings hosted by KCUE exceeded 31 times. While the frequency varies yearly, total attendance increased about four-fold from 47,193 people in 2012 to 197,476 people in 2014. College entrance briefings held by Jongro Academy Sky Education, a hagwon education company, show the same trend. In 2010, 10,748 people participated in 5 sessions, but this year 32,797 people already attended just the 4 briefings held in the first half.

The age range of parents visiting college entrance briefing venues is also lowering. Among 6,188 applicants for the 'Sky Education Special Purpose/Autonomous Private High School Selection and University Admission Intensive Analysis' briefing held by Jongro Academy Sky Education last May, 2,078 people (33.6%) were parents of pre-school and elementary children. This means mothers are starting to prepare for entrance exams from earlier.

College entrance briefings began taking their current form starting from when CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] was implemented in 1994. Lee Young-deok, director of Daesung Academic Development Research Institute, said, "When CSAT was implemented, many people were curious about the changed entrance exam system," adding "Even then, over 5,000 people flocked there." The special purpose high school fever that blew from the mid-1990s expanded college entrance briefings from college to high school admissions. Lim Seong-ho, president of Jongro Academy Sky Education, said, "Over 1,000 parents from across the nation flocked to the special purpose high school briefing in 1999," adding "Some people even flew in from Jeju Island." From around 2000, large hagwon education companies like Cheongsol Academy, Daesung Academy, and Megastudy began holding briefings for 10,000 people per session.

The format of briefings is also diversifying to meet consumer demands. KCUE has been holding University Admission Information Fairs since 2011, allowing parents to directly meet and consult with university admission officials. Kim Young-sim, director of KCUE's College Admission Counseling Center, explained, "Recently, there's more interest in customized briefings rather than one-way briefings." Choi Eun-ji, team leader at Etoos Cheongsol Education Evaluation Research Institute, said, "This year's 'Mock Test Briefings' and 'Early Decision Application Strategy Briefings' were held by academic track targeting the highest achievers," adding "Briefings are also changing while accommodating parents' demands."

Finding Suitable Lectures Is Not Easy

There are stages to becoming absorbed in briefings. Parents divide this process into four stages: confusion period, addiction period, stagnation period, and maturity period. The first stage is the confusion period. Ms. Lee Eun-jeong (51, Mokdong, Yangcheon-gu), who finished her child's entrance exams last year, said, "Starting as early as when children are in elementary school, most experience 'mental breakdown' when they begin attending college entrance briefings." This is because they can't understand even half of what the lecturer says. Parents who realize their shortcomings judge that not attending briefings frequently enough was the problem and enter the second stage addiction period.

During the addiction period, they must participate in all briefings held everywhere - large hagwon education companies, small hagwons, district offices, schools - to feel satisfied. If they miss even one, they show symptoms of anxiety and restlessness. Ms. Kim Su-hyeon (47, Garak-dong, Seoul), who has a son in 8th grade, said, "When I missed important briefings due to housework or personal matters, anxiety would unknowingly overwhelm me," adding "Even when parents who attended briefings told me 'it was nothing special,' I couldn't feel relieved." When Ms. Kim confided this state to a senior parent, she was told "You seem addicted to briefings like shopping addiction."

The third stage, stagnation period, is when they distance themselves from briefings, thinking 'Do I really need to go this far for my child's education?' This comes earlier the less outstanding the child's grades are. This is because they realize that no matter how frantically mothers attend briefings, it's of little use if the child's ability doesn't keep up. There's also the aspect of worrying about relationships with children deteriorating. Ms. Shin said, "On days I returned from college entrance briefings, I couldn't stand seeing my child watching TV," adding "I ended up nagging more about 'study,' so I deliberately didn't attend briefings for a while."

The maturity period is the stage where through various trials and errors, they learn to use briefings appropriately and seek out only what's essential for them. It becomes possible to receive less stress and obtain educational information helpful to oneself.

Mother's Information Power Doesn't Correlate with Child's Ability

The biggest reason mothers visit briefing venues is to obtain entrance exam information, but it's not simply because of educational information alone. Many say there's a kind of healing effect where just going to briefings makes them feel better. Ms. Lee said, "The anxious and restless feelings about my child's entrance exams subside when I'm listening to briefings," adding "Thinking that I'm doing my best effort provides self-comfort."

It also serves as a stimulant. When they clash with their children while preparing for entrance exams and get stressed and exhausted, going to briefing venues and seeing other mothers helps them pull themselves together. Ms. Song (40, Bundang, Gyeonggi), who has children in 6th grade and 1st grade, said, "There are quite a few mothers who say 'I need to go to a briefing to get some stimulation,'" adding "It seems many participate to use it as an opportunity for self-reflection rather than understanding information."

It's also an expression of support for their children. It's an unspoken message saying 'I'm making this much effort for you.' Ms. Kim said, "Children are consciously and unconsciously influenced by their parents' actions," adding "Even if diligently attending college entrance briefings doesn't raise children's grades, I think it will have a positive influence."

Briefings have now established themselves as a community culture among parents. Listening to briefings together and gathering at nearby cafes to exchange information about college admission tracks or child education is a familiar scene. Ms. Lee said, "Mainly mothers with similar grades attend briefings together and share educational information," adding "It becomes an opportunity to gauge children's levels and view entrance exams from a broader perspective."

But mothers need to know something. A mother's information power doesn't develop her child's ability. There's no use if only the mother 'studies hard.' Teacher Ahn Gwang-bok from Jungdong High School said, "During counseling, I often see cases where the mother knows SKY [Seoul National University, Korea University, Yonsei University] entrance exam tracks by heart, but the child can't even get into Seoul metropolitan area universities," adding "There's a need to match the child's eye level." Teacher Ahn added, "While participating in college entrance briefings has become unavoidable reality for parents who want to send their children to good universities, what's more important is paying attention to their children."

▶ How to Use College Entrance Briefings According to Senior Parents

① Abandon Impatience and Greed
The biggest misconception mothers who attend briefings have is the absurd belief that 'attending briefings will solve everything.' Ideals and reality are different. If you try to learn everything from A to Z at once, you'll easily get exhausted. You need to think that learning just one piece of information at a time is beneficial.
You must let go of impatient feelings. This is why participation in college entrance briefings is recommended from 10th grade. If you pour large amounts of information all at once in 12th grade, a year passes while being confused. Also, with increased early decision recruitment, the three-year high school process greatly influences entrance exams. Shin Dong-won, vice principal of Whimoon High School, said, "There's a need to grasp the overall context and trends while drawing the big picture by listening to college entrance briefings in 10th grade." You also need to understand basic information about briefing seasons. Knowing generally what field briefings occur in which months means you won't be anxious if you miss one or two. Usually briefings are held on: winter vacation hagwon special lectures and CSAT regular decision (November-December), science gifted schools (February-May), science high schools (May-July), summer vacation special lectures (June-July), CSAT early decision (July-September), special purpose/autonomous private high schools (June-November).

② Believe Only Half of What Hagwons Say
Parents believe briefings will serve as navigation for selecting hagwons perfectly suited to their children, but most fall into confusion. This is because even for the same subject, each hagwon emphasizes different content. For English, debate hagwons emphasize English debate, Korean-style English hagwons emphasize grammar, and reading discussion hagwons emphasize reading original texts. Ms. Shin Jeong-yeon (49, Daechi-dong, Seoul), who has children in first year of university and 12th grade, said, "Mothers need to maintain their center well," adding "You can believe only half of what hagwons say." If you don't keep your wits about you, you can easily fall for hagwon marketing tactics. Ms. Lee, who has a child in 7th grade, said, "When I first went to a briefing, I was tempted by the hagwon director's words and double-registered for various hagwons, then had trouble canceling," adding "Since then, I read posts about hagwons on education communities or investigate surrounding opinions, then attend at least three hagwon briefings to carefully examine commonalities and differences."

③ Definitely Attend Your Desired High School's Briefing
Parents of middle school children are immediately concerned about high school admissions. Ms. Shin, who has a child in 11th grade, said, "If you're interested in special purpose/autonomous private high schools, you should listen to school-hosted briefings at least once." They reveal high-level information unavailable at hagwon college entrance briefings, such as news that 'students without straight A's from last year's entrance exam results were automatically eliminated.'
However, places with high student and parent preference are difficult to even participate in. Hana High School, Hankuk University of Foreign Studies Affiliated High School, Sangsan High School, and Hanil High School are representative examples. Ms. Kim Su-hyeon (47, Garak-dong, Seoul), who has a son in 8th grade, experienced 'instant elimination' while trying to make reservations for Hankuk University of Foreign Studies Affiliated High School's briefing. She was waiting from 9:50 AM for 10 AM reservations, but registration ended in 20 seconds. Ms. Kim said, "It's harder than idol concert tickets or Chuseok holiday train reservations," adding "Next year I'll have to go to a PC room or mobilize relatives."
There's a reason special purpose/autonomous private high school briefings are popular. Most have school tour programs. Touring the school the child aims for and talking with current students provides good motivation. Consequently, servers often crash due to access overload on briefing reservation days. However, even if you can't make reservations, most schools let you stand and listen at the back of the auditorium.

④ Stay Until the End at University-Specific Briefings
College entrance briefings should be approached in order: high school, large hagwon education companies, then university-hosted briefings. After understanding school levels through your current high school's briefings, you should participate in briefings by Daesung Academy, Jongro Academy Sky Education, etc. to understand the overall flow of university admissions. Then establish specific strategies through briefings held by university admissions offices.
Especially at university-specific briefings, you must stay until the end. Choice information emerges when mothers gather in small groups to have Q&A sessions with admissions officers. Ms. Kim Hyeon-jeong (48, Daechi-dong, Seoul), who has children in first year of university and 12th grade, said, "Some mothers bring their children's school records when going to university admission briefings and receive on-the-spot consulting from admissions officers," adding "Reactions vary tremendously depending on university atmosphere and admission officials' tendencies, but it's worth trying."
Sharing entrance exam information with children is also necessary. This is the case for Ms. Jun (46, Mokdong, Seoul), who has a child in 12th grade. Ms. Jun searches for videos and shows only parts that would help her child. Ms. Jun said, "Through this, students realize what they need more," adding "There's no use if only parents frantically attend briefings."

Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] hagwons organize classes meticulously from levels 1-6 to provide instruction perfectly matched to student levels, but Songpa District hagwons only have about 3-4 class divisions due to fewer students.'

The concentration of private high schools and general high schools with good university admission results like Joongdong, Hyundai, and Whimoon high schools in Gangnam District also fuels the Gangnam District concentration phenomenon. Looking at Seoul National University admission results for Seoul-area general high schools in the 2015 academic year, Gangnam District general high schools sent an average of 11.2 students per school to Seoul National University, while Songpa District general high schools averaged only 4.2 Seoul National University admits per school. <JoongAng Ilbo Gangnam Communication, November 25, 2015, pages 10-11, 'The Secret of General High Schools That Sent Many Students to Seoul National University in 2015'> Mr. Han (46), who is raising two children—a 6th grader and a middle school 2nd grader—in Songpa District, said: 'Many parents move to Gangnam District during middle school with an eye toward university admissions even more than special purpose high schools.' Mr. Han explained: 'Even living in Songpa District, we consider Gangnam schools when thinking about high school advancement. The current atmosphere is to move to Gangnam if you have the ability to survive the school record competition there, and to stay in Songpa District to secure school record grades if your ability is lacking.'

Seocho District has many students who transferred from Dongjak District. Looking at the 2012-2014 migration data for ages 10-14 into Seocho District, internal movement within Seocho District was highest, followed by students who moved from Dongjak District. Among students who moved to Seocho District from other districts, those from Dongjak District comprised 16.8% (445 students) in 2012, 15.8% (462 students) in 2013, and 17.7% (447 students) in 2014. CEO Lim explained: 'There are many transfers of Songpa District middle school students to Gangnam District and Dongjak District middle school students to Seocho District. Many families rent for 3-4 years to live in the Gangnam area for university admissions and return to their original areas after university entrance exams end.'

Common to all three Gangnam districts—Gangnam, Seocho, and Songpa—general high school enrollment decreased while private high school enrollment rates increased. The rate of Gangnam District middle school graduates entering private high schools increased from 11.8% (824 students) in the 2013 academic year to 13.5% (848 students) in the 2015 academic year. Meanwhile, general high school enrollment rates decreased from 81% (5,641 students) to 77.7% (4,884 students) during the same period. Seocho District middle school students' private high school enrollment rate increased from 17.1% (844 students) to 19.2% (878 students), and Songpa District increased from 9.2% (765 students) to 10.1% (767 students). Kim Hye-nam, a teacher at Munil High School in Seoul, analyzed: 'Particularly in the Gangnam area where preference for science and medical fields is pronounced, preference for private high schools with good medical school admission results has increased significantly.'

Large Academic Achievement Gaps Even Within Education Special Zones

In the 2015 National Assessment of Educational Achievement taken by 3rd-year middle school students last year, middle school students in Gangnam District showed an 88.5% rate of proficient or above academic achievement (combined Korean, English, mathematics). The Academic Achievement Assessment is an indicator for gauging schools' average academic levels, dividing achievement into three levels: proficient or above, basic, and below basic according to achievement level. Proficient or above academic achievement means achieving 50% or more of the national curriculum achievement goals. It refers to an academic level that can smoothly follow the curriculum when advancing to the next grade. This means 88.5% of Gangnam District middle school students met this condition. Seocho District showed 87.8%, Songpa District 81.1%, Yangcheon District 79.1%, and Nowon District 78.1%.

Academic Achievement Assessment results by middle school show gaps widening again within each district. In Gangnam District, schools ranked in order: Daecheong Middle (97.9%), Daewang Middle (95.8%), Jinseon Girls' Middle (94.3%), Apgujeong Middle (94.2%), and Daemyeong Middle (94%). Eonbuk Middle showed the lowest level with a proficient or above rate of only 69.5%. Even within Gangnam District, the gap between the highest-achieving school (Daecheong Middle, 97.9%) and lowest-achieving school (Eonbuk Middle, 69.5%) was 28.4 percentage points. Seocho District showed a 23.2% gap, and Songpa District showed 30.3% (excluding Seoul Sports Middle School, which specializes in physical education).

Experts cite three main factors related to Academic Achievement Assessment gaps: influx of excellent students from outside, hagwon education, and academic atmosphere. Indeed, Daemyeong Middle, Daecheong Middle, and Jinseon Girls' Middle, which showed high academic achievement results in Gangnam District, ranked 1st, 2nd, and 4th respectively among Gangnam District middle schools for net student influx (number of transfer-in students minus transfer-out students) from 2012-2014. Daemyeong Middle increased by 99 students over three years, Daecheong Middle by 98 students, and Jinseon Girls' Middle by 86 students.

Looking at Gangnam District overall, net student influx for middle schools increased significantly from 100 to 376 students during the same period. Conversely, Songpa District had more students transferring out than in, recording negative net influx of -52 students in 2012, -85 students in 2013, and -145 students in 2014, with the negative gap continuing to widen. A vice-principal at a Gangnam middle school said: 'The effect of hagwon education cannot be ignored. Top-tier students clustering together creates an academic atmosphere, naturally having a large effect of pulling up mid-tier students.' Lee Seong-kwon, representative of the Korean Education Policy Teachers' Solidarity (teacher at Daejin High School in Seoul), said: 'The concentration phenomenon toward specific regions and specific schools could intensify further. It's urgent to increase support for schools with low Academic Achievement Assessment results and for schools to make efforts to raise the academic levels of students who fall short of basic achievement.'

  "translated_text": "Lee Ye-rim (pseudonym, 16), a student about to enter her senior year at a general high school in Seoul, has found studying much more enjoyable lately with her new goal. Her goal is not college admission, but passing the civil service exam. She plans to take on the Grade 9 civil service recruitment exam to be held early next year. "Even though they say civil service exams are 'harder than getting a camel through the eye of a needle,' if I study diligently, there's no reason I can't do it, right?" Lee's grades place her in the top 10% at her school.

Lee hasn't dreamed of becoming a civil servant for very long. "Until recently, all I wanted was to become someone who could positively influence others," she said. So she studied hard for her school records and consistently ranked at the top. She too thought she would go to university.

Then one day, her mindset changed. Last summer, a career aptitude test conducted at school showed that jobs delivering public services, like civil servant or social worker, suited her well. Since that day, the three characters 'civil servant' haven't left her mind. Also, it overlapped with the world of the correctional officer (prison guard) who appeared as a supporting character in the movie <Harmony> she had seen sometime before, and her desire to become a civil servant began to sprout in her heart. What captivated Lee in this movie was the supporting character Lieutenant Gong Na-young (played by Lee Da-hee). "The way she didn't discriminate against or look down on the prisoners, but rather empathized with their sadness, was impressive. Ah, I thought, what if I helped people in that way too?"

When her thoughts reached this point, doubts about college admission came flooding in. 'Since civil servants can apply regardless of whether they're college or high school graduates, what's the point of spending money to get a college diploma?' This thought solidified further as she watched her older brother, who had delayed college graduation for a year due to unemployment and was living as a semi-unemployed person. Lee said, "Every time my brother says 'I want to get a job quickly so I can quit my part-time work,' it breaks my heart."

**Civil servant ranks #1 as 'popular job' among middle and high school students**

Lee's decision is quite different from the atmosphere among high school students who are all focused on college admission. In fact, the college enrollment rate among Korean high school students in 2014 was 70.9%. This means 7 out of 10 high school students choose to go to college. However, compared to the 84% college enrollment rate in 2008, this is a decrease of about 13 percentage points. This is evidence that more and more high school students are choosing paths other than college admission.

Among them, high school students like Lee who prepare for civil service exams early have increased markedly. On the internet, a new coined word 'gongding,' referring to 'high school students and repeat test-takers [students retaking CSAT after high school graduation] preparing for civil service exams,' has even emerged.
