The proportion of teenagers among all applicants also increased from 1.1% to 1.4%. Behind this increase in 'gongding' lies the phenomenon of civil servant preference. According to the '2015 Social Survey' conducted by Statistics Korea, 1 in 4 middle and high school students preferred civil servant as their desired job. Civil servant ranked first, beating out other occupations.

Along with this, the 'vocational institutionalization' of universities and the increase in unemployed college graduates also fuel the increase in gongding. According to '2015 Youth Statistics,' 48.6% of youth (ages 9-24) in 2014 answered that the main purpose of university-level education is 'to get a good job.' 'Developing one's abilities and talents' was 36%, and 'building character or cultivation' was only 1.8%.

The reality of having to pay enormous time and costs for job preparation even after college admission is also cited as one of the causes of mass production of the gongding tribe. According to survey results from 'University Tomorrow's 20s Research Institute,' college students preparing for employment are preparing an average of 5.2 specs per person and spent an average of 1,304,000 won [approximately $980 USD] on employment-related course fees. Despite this, the number of college students frustrated at the threshold of employment has instead increased. Last year's unemployment rate among college graduates was 3.6%, an increase of 0.4 percentage points (about 90,000 people) compared to 3.2% in 2012.

What served as a catalyst for the increase in the gongding tribe was the 2013 revision of the Grade 9 civil service exam. Administrative law general principles and public administration introduction, which were mandatory subjects, were changed to elective subjects, and high school curriculum subjects like social studies, science, and mathematics were added as elective subjects. As subjects overlapping with school classes increased, more high school students turned their attention to the Grade 9 civil service exam.

An official from A Civil Service Academy in Noryangjin said, "High school students and repeat test-takers who come for consultations with their parents account for 3 out of 10 consultees in January and February," describing the changed landscape. "What has visibly changed is the composition of students. Three years ago, there were almost no students of high school age. But now, 1 or 2 out of 10 students are high schoolers or repeat test-takers."

Cases like Lee's, where students enter general high school then give up university and prepare for civil service, are not common. This is because the opportunity cost of giving up college admission feels too great to jump into preparing for the highly competitive civil service exam. However, the story could be different for gongding who switched direction early.

Most third-year students in the civil service exam preparation class at Daedong Tax High School have aimed to become civil servants since middle school. They knocked on the door of this specialized high school to take the exam through the 'Regional Talent Grade 9 Track' rather than the open competitive exam.

The Regional Talent Grade 9 Track, implemented since 2012, is a system that separately selects Grade 9 civil servants limited to specialized high schools, Meister schools, and junior colleges. Only 5 people recommended by the principal per school can apply. The competition rate is lower than the Grade 9 recruitment exam, they only need to compete among peers, and two subjects are excluded from the exam, making it advantageous in many ways. The Ministry of Personnel Management announced it would select 160 people through the Regional Talent Grade 9 Track this year. This is the highest number ever.

**'Future talents' preparing since middle school**

However, not everyone who wants to can apply for this track. The qualification conditions needed to be selected among the 5 people per school are strict. For 'general subjects' like Korean, English, and mathematics, all subjects must rank within the top 30%, and for 'specialized subjects' like tax law and accounting principles, all subjects must be B or above, with more than half being higher than A.

Kim Tae-hyeon (17), who was in the top 15% of his middle school graduation grades, gave up college admission early due to his father's unemployment. His father, a high school graduate who worked at a cement manufacturing company, lost his job during company restructuring in the mid-2000s.

Struggling with family finances, Kim eventually had to give up his dream of college admission. Instead, he set out to find a stable job possible with a high school diploma. "Civil servant was truly the optimal job for me," Kim emphasized. "When I was in third year of middle school, I had the opportunity to attend a specialized high school information session. After hearing that 'Daedong Tax High School has a high civil service exam pass rate nationwide,' I immediately decided to enroll."

Kang Seong-su (17) was also familiar with the civil servant profession from a young age. Kang said, "Since both my grandfather and father worked in public service, the civil servant profession wasn't unfamiliar to me." He 'declared' to his parents in his second year of middle school that he would prepare to become a civil servant. Kang's older sister is also a specialized high school graduate who currently works at a financial company. "If my sister had gone to a general high school, she probably couldn't have gotten into her desired university. But at her current job, they say she can get university admission qualifications after working for 3 years. When you think about it, it's actually advantageous for college admission too."

Kang's mother said she's the object of envy among her friends. "We practically have no money going out for education expenses. There's no time I'm more proud than when I hear people around me say, 'How nice that your child goes to a good school for free.'" According to the 'hagwon education Expenditure Survey' announced annually by Statistics Korea, the monthly average hagwon education expenditure per high school student in 2014 was 230,000 won [approximately $173 USD].

Like Kim and Kang, students in the civil service exam preparation class all thought about their future from a young age and decided their career path themselves. This point contrasts with the Korea Press Foundation Media Research Center survey where students chose parents most often (56.8%) as 'the person who has the greatest influence on career decisions.'

Perhaps because of this, they have strong will regarding independence and success. Kim, who receives about 100,000 won [approximately $75 USD] in allowance per month, said, "Every time I get allowance from my parents, I feel sorry and burdened." Kang also said, "The reason I want to become a civil servant quickly is so I can stop receiving allowance from my parents and actually give money to them instead."

Yoon Min-ho (17), who said "I want to show my parents a successful side of myself," is the same way. He said, "When I was young, perhaps due to an inferiority complex, I often thought my parents favored my older sister." "From then on, I sought out external activities myself to show my parents something. Later, I would organize my thoughts first, then go to my parents to ask for help."

Not only high school students, but repeat test-takers jumping into civil service exams have also greatly increased. This year's Grade 9 civil service recruitment exam will be held on April 9. From the repeat test-takers' perspective, they have the burden of taking another exam just months after taking CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] last year. Their mindset differs slightly from high school students. Myeong Su-min (18), who has been preparing for the Grade 9 civil service exam since taking CSAT last year, explained, "Because the future is much more uncertain."

**Anxious repeat test-takers also join in**

Originally, Myeong's goal was to enter the English Education department at a top university in Seoul. However, in last year's CSAT, he received an average of Grade 4. For Myeong, who had easily surpassed an average of Grade 2 in mock exams, this was a report card he absolutely could not accept. Both school teachers and hagwon instructors had encouraged him, saying "You'll be fine if you just reduce mistakes."

Even so, he couldn't easily decide to repeat. There was no guarantee the same thing wouldn't happen again as last year. Looking toward only the CSAT, which is taken once a year, and deciding to repeat felt like 'gambling.' While he was unable to decide on a direction and was worrying, his older sister made an unexpected suggestion: "If you're really anxious, how about preparing for the civil service exam first?" Myeong said, "The subjects weren't very different from CSAT, and I was drawn to the fact that you can take the civil service exam three times a year."

For Myeong, the civil service exam is a kind of 'insurance.' Though it's been three months since he started preparing for the civil service exam, he still doesn't think being a civil servant suits his aptitude. He also has plans to prepare for CSAT anytime if he fails the civil service exam. "Even if I become a civil servant, I definitely plan to get a bachelor's degree through night university or cyber university," is his aspiration.

Having this two-way approach at an age still too young to understand the ways of the world is no easy task. Among his friends, he's the only one preparing for civil service. "I have fears like 'what if this path doesn't work out,' 'what if I aim for both CSAT and civil service exam but end up with nothing.' It's lonely too."

However, to Song Han-na (25, female), who is about to graduate from a top university in Seoul, Myeong's anxiety is close to whining. She has been preparing for the civil service exam since July last year. Before that, she hadn't really thought about the future. Her status as a university student was like a kind of 'anesthetic' to her. "I spent four years with the vague thought that 'I'll do something,' and before I knew it, graduation was approaching," she expressed regret.

Although she started preparing for civil service late, Song keenly feels the lack of time. This is because her parents' conditional permission to "try until 2016, and if it doesn't work, get married" binds her. For Song, who finds every minute and second precious, she often can't sleep due to regret, thinking "What if I had started just two years earlier?"

So what do gongding-origin civil servants currently working in the field think? Does the label of 'high school graduate' work against them? Are there no difficulties in starting social life early?

Im Su-yeon (20, female, tax investigator), who started working at Dongdaemun Tax Office last year, explained, "I get that question a lot, but it's not like that at all. Rather, there are many advantages because I'm young." In Im's case, the average age of her tax division colleagues is about 28. The oldest among them was born in 1962. There's a 34-year age gap between her and this person, who is old enough to be her father.

Im is also distinctly young in the office. There's an 11-year gap between Im and her immediate senior. Given this situation, bosses old enough to be her father always take care of her like a daughter. Im smiled and said, "I've often heard from seniors that the youngest really acts like the youngest."

Kim Ji-hye (pseudonym, female, 21), who has been working at a government agency in Sejong City for two years, thinks the difference in mindset can be a strength unique to high school graduate civil servants. She said, "College graduates or Grade 7 civil servants tend to look down on miscellaneous work. But high school graduates came in relatively easily, so they seem to think they need to work harder."

Among college graduates, not few have complaints when they have to do work not directly related to department duties. Once, when doing work to identify department staff birthdays, a college graduate colleague complained, "I don't want to do such trivial work." But Kim silently did whatever work was given without being picky. Praise from superiors continued, saying she "takes initiative even with trivial tasks" or "has a sense of responsibility."

**Current test-takers advantageous to 'settle the match' within next year**

When asked if they regret not having university life and choosing civil service directly, both people agreed "No." "Senior civil servants say things like 'I should make my child a civil servant without sending them to university,' 'If I were reborn and became a civil servant again, I would challenge it right after high school graduation.' Every time I hear such praise, I think 'I'm glad I chose to come in early.'"

The outlook is that Grade 9 civil service exams will continue to gain steady popularity among high school students and repeat test-takers in the future. However, there's no guarantee these good times will last forever. The lowered entry barrier is scheduled to be restored to its original state.

According to the 'Grade 9 Civil Service Recruitment Exam Subject Revision Plan' released by the Ministry of Personnel Management on January 25 this year, from 2018, Grade 9 civil service exam subjects must include at least one 'specialized subject' related to the applied position's practical work. For example, tax positions must choose between tax law or accounting, and statistics positions must choose between statistics and economics. Regarding this, an official from KG Pass One's affiliated research institute, a civil service exam specialized academy in Noryangjin, Seoul, explained, "This would essentially be the same as returning to before 2013, so the path to becoming a Grade 9 civil servant could become more difficult." To achieve the gongding dream, it might be more advantageous to settle the match within two years.

Kim Byeo-ri, intern reporter kimstar1215@hanmail.net / Photo by Kim Hyeon-dong kim.hd@joongang.co.kr"

Mature, charismatic middle-aged actors who dominate Korean cinema like Cha Seung-won (born 1970), Lee Byung-hun (born 1970), Jang Dong-gun (born 1972), Jung Woo-sung (born 1973), and Lee Jung-jae (born 1973) are being recruited en masse as game advertisement models recently. As the main consumer base of mobile games, previously considered the exclusive domain of teens and 20-somethings, shifts to the 30-40 age group, companies are deploying strategies targeting middle-aged people as their main target by recruiting top actors familiar to them. The ticket power of middle-aged people has long been proven in the film industry, and in the publishing market, the main readership has been moving to middle-aged people over 40 since 2014.

According to 2015 Statistics Korea, the generations occupying the largest proportion in our country's population structure are those in their 40s (17.2%) and 50s (16.2%). As the middle-aged emerged as a power consumption group, marketing targeting middle-aged consumption is in full swing in the marketing industry. 'NoMU tribe' means 'No More Uncle,' referring to middle-aged men in their 40s-50s who firmly refuse to be called 'uncle.' Anti-aging Skin Care is Basic... Don't Spare Investment in Appearance

'HAHA tribe' means 'Happy Aging Healthy & Attractive,' referring to middle-aged people who live happily through self-development. They're characterized by consuming for themselves, generously investing time and money in cultural life and health management.

Lee Hyung-gi (52, pseudonym), who runs a business, is a representative flower middle-aged man. He exercises daily under a personal trainer's guidance and receives skin care once a week. For anti-aging, he receives 'Thermage' skin lifting treatment once a year and has undergone laser treatment to remove spots and blemishes and surgery to remove under-eye fat. Every morning before going to work, he carefully applies BB cream before leaving home. To avoid giving a stiff feeling, he wears scarves instead of ties and prefers colored shoes in brown or navy rather than black.

"I think I spend about 1 million won [approximately $750 USD] per month on appearance. Since I run a business, I meet people frequently and have to pay a lot of attention to appearance. Thanks to this, I often hear people say I 'look young' or am 'young-looking.' It seems like they're recognizing my value, so I'm secretly proud. I think 'flower middle-aged' ultimately means people who have the leisure to invest time and money in appearance."

Kim Seong-cheol (47), who works at a foreign company. His hobbies were drinking, and on holidays, becoming a mermaid princess (lying sideways with legs crossed, not moving and only watching TV) - but recently he's struggling to be reborn as a flower middle-aged man. It's because of his eldest son Dong-jun (8), who recently entered elementary school. "I married late, so my children are still young compared to my peers. When I went to my son's kindergarten for a class observation, I heard that his friends teased him saying his dad was old, and I thought this wouldn't do." Kim reduces drinking sessions and exercises at least three times a week. He bought expensive shampoo and toner to prevent hair loss and visits a beauty salon once a month for coloring and scalp massage. He bought men's cosmetics for skin care and even received Botox treatment timed for Dong-jun's elementary school entrance ceremony. "It started to boost my child's spirits, but now I'm satisfied with how I look. Since I thought I was still young, I was lazy about health and appearance, but from now on I want to be faithful not only to appearance but also to life for my inner self."

Middle age is a generation 'caught' between the young and elderly generations, a confusing time when one is neither young nor old. Also called the second adolescence or 'sa-chu-gi' (思秋期), it's a psychologically unstable period with much conflict, along with adolescence.

Jung (Carl Gustav), the founder of analytical psychology and a Swiss psychiatrist, defined middle age as 'life's noon' that divides life's first and second halves, noting the 'midlife crisis' by saying 'people experience important life turning points in middle age, causing serious inner changes.' However, he viewed the midlife crisis as a kind of self-healing process and emphasized that it was a healthy change appearing in mature people.

Middle-aged men who have invested time and money for their families rather than themselves often don't know what they really want to do or how they can be happy. While there's no need to necessarily follow the trend of flower middle-aged men created by consumer society, if they at least start by listening to their inner desires, they can find happiness regardless of age.

- Kim Kyung-cheol, Seoul correspondent for Japan's Kodansha News Magazine Division"

With Seoul National University maintaining silence, expectations are particularly high for you two as presidents of prestigious private universities.

Yeom Jae-ho: How can Seoul National University, which is essentially a national university despite corporatization, speak out loudly? It's natural for them to stay quiet (laughs).

Song: Still, 10 years ago they occasionally made critical remarks about entrance exam reform and such. But now... I recently watched the match between AlphaGo and Lee Sedol [a Korean professional Go player], and it made me reflect on what universities have prepared. I think the presidents of Yonsei University and Korea University, the most important institutions for nurturing 21st-century talent, bear the burden of our times.

Kim Yong-hak: The AlphaGo incident actually made it much easier to explain my educational philosophy that universities must start matching pace for the next 100 years. Today's freshmen will live until age 100, until 2100. What meaning does industrial society's educational approach have for such generations? Education that nurtures narrow specialists will lose half its meaning in the age of artificial intelligence. AlphaGo was an incident that helped my message about preparing for the next 100 years.

Yeom: In Gheorghiu's novel '25 O'Clock,' submarines always carry rabbits aboard. But rabbits react faster than humans to oxygen-deficient situations. Universities and intellectuals must play exactly that role. Universities must completely change. The 'pioneering intellectuals' I emphasize are exactly such talents. I met Jeremy Rifkin in Italy 10 years ago. We agreed that the 'employment society' is over. Yet Korea still considers employment rates in university evaluations. I read an interesting article in a daily newspaper. When asked 'Why do large corporations hire new employees?', an HR manager said, "What kind of employment policy is the youth employment policy? That's welfare policy." Meaning if left alone, no one would hire anyone. As President Kim said, social systems are almost entirely networking structures, yet we still try to solve problems with 20th-century methods. Facing the 21st century's civilizational transformation, universities must be completely overturned.

Song: That's where the problem lies. I sometimes tell my students in class: "Since you belong to the top 0.5%, don't steal other people's jobs. Give them to the 99.5%. Kim: It's 'going from inside the classroom to outside.' Concepts like problem solving or active learning—students define humanity's historical problems encountered in local communities and the global village, and find ways to solve them. Educational reform has begun. I think that's real practical education and a model that enhances public value.

Song: Social science students mainly learn about community, power, and human behavior only through theory. So educational approaches involving direct participation in local communities and organizations are very desirable. We need an exit that tears down university walls. Previously, people went to Seoul National University, Yonsei University, and Korea University to meet good professors, but now we have videos and internet. It's important to draw out students' qualities, but we only try to cram things in, so things must change.

Song: Money is indeed important. U.S. private university tuition is around $50,000 annually.

Don't wait for cruise ships, build rafts for entrepreneurship

The boy played with nature as his companion. When living in Gangneung, Gangwon Province, and even after coming up to Seoul, he would climb Namsan mountain to catch crayfish in streams, and whenever vacation came, his body would itch with desire to go down to Gangneung. After winning first place in a writing contest in middle school, he hoped to become a poet, and in high school, he dreamed of being an artist. This is the story of Choi Jae-cheon (62), director and chair professor of Ewha Womans University's Division of EcoScience and the first director of the National Institute of Ecology. After graduating from Seoul's Kyungbok Middle and High School and Seoul National University, he earned his PhD from Harvard University, then worked at the University of Michigan and Seoul National University before currently serving as a professor at Ewha Womans University. At first glance, it might seem he found his aptitude well and succeeded smoothly, but because he had many things he wanted to do from childhood, he wandered quite a bit. However, thanks to that, he was able to become a consilience scholar crossing humanities, social sciences, natural sciences, and arts, and gained the realization that 'if you know, you love.'

'Men are heaven, women are earth' - that's how I was raised
On the contrary, I decided to become a soft red-bean porridge father
Son raised freely, sharing love through service
At one point, I misunderstood that I had raised him selfishly and wrongly
If you don't know each other well, there's conflict; if you know, you can't help but love
Now I understand my father's patriarchal love too

Mother who would not compromise when it came to children's education

"There's a saying, 'Men are heaven, women are earth.' That's exactly the story of our house during my childhood." Director Choi Jae-cheon's father was a career military officer who graduated from the Korea Military Academy. He was a typical patriarch, and his mother couldn't even breathe properly in front of him. His perfectionist father often worked at home even after returning from work, and the four brothers, including Director Choi who was the eldest son, had no choice but to stay as quiet as possible to avoid disturbing their father's mood. The boisterous scene of brothers hitting and playing with each other was hard to find in his house. "If father bit into a stone while eating rice his mother had prepared, he would spit out the rice he was chewing and slam down his spoon with a 'thud.' Mother would immediately clear the table and wash the rice again to cook new rice. I still remember how the table mother was carrying out trembled 'rattle rattle rattle.' On such days, mother would be scolded by father all night long, hearing things like 'What are you doing at home that you can't even cook rice properly? A person must be perfect. There should be no mistakes.'"

In front of such a father, there was only one thing where mother would not bend her stubbornness: matters concerning the children's education. Director Choi's mother judged that the frequent moves due to the nature of being a military officer would not be good for the children, so she left the children at her brother's house in Seoul. This was even before Director Choi entered elementary school. Even when her husband yelled, "What difference does it make where they study? Even if you study on an overturned apple crate in the Gangwon mountains, those who will succeed will all succeed," she did not back down. "Father had no choice but to think that way. He had farmed in the Gangwon countryside while studying and was accepted to the Korea Military Academy in his second year of high school with a four-year scholarship. He was the only one accepted from all of Gangwon Province and was apparently called a genius. When I was young and went to the countryside, all the adults knew father."

Three of the four brothers grew up to become university professors

Director Choi's mother's educational fervor was never broken under any circumstances. She often said, "No matter what happens, I will definitely support all four brothers." It was also his mother's will that he received expensive private tutoring in sixth grade. At that time, entrance exams started from middle school, and you had to enter a prestigious middle school to easily advance to a prestigious high school and prestigious university, so elementary schools with many students accepted to prestigious middle schools naturally became popular. Not satisfied with transferring him from Seoul's Woosin Elementary to Seoul's Gyodong Elementary, when his grades didn't come out satisfactorily, his mother began searching for a private tutor. This was because the majority of students in his class were receiving private tutoring. However, Director Choi's family was not well-off, and with his younger brother suffering from heart disease, the family finances were gradually declining. "At that time, paying for my brother's hospital bills with father's salary alone must have been difficult. In that situation, receiving private tutoring made me think a lot even at a young age about what it meant."

When in dire straits, one finds a way. Mother, who would not bend her will despite father's opposition, found a method. She obtained information that someone who had served in the military under father had become a famous private tutor. That very day, she took Director Choi's hand, went to find the private tutor, and earnestly requested. Rather than the private tutor, the other team members' mothers unanimously opposed it. "They had no choice because the children receiving tutoring together were only from the highest class - the hospital director's son, the Vice Minister of Communications' son, etc. The other mothers all said in unison, 'We can't include someone from Seoul's outskirts. What if our children's level drops too?'" However, his mother knelt down on the spot and pleaded, "Please just accept him, you can treat our child as if he doesn't exist." Seeing that scene, Director Choi felt something unknown stirring in his heart. It was a complex mix of emotions including anger and defiance. "My pride was hurt, and I also resolved to study hard. This expectation from mother served as a lighthouse for me throughout my school years. Even when I was wandering, it brought me back to my place. The fact that three of the four brothers became university professors is all thanks to mother's educational fervor."

"How dare a woman call first"

Because he grew up seeing his father's patriarchal and authoritarian appearance, he couldn't help but resemble him. When his girlfriend called first during university, he was so deeply entrenched in male chauvinism that he would say, "How dare a woman call a man first?"

-Looking at you now, it's hard to imagine.

"I really was like that back then. Even though I hated my father's appearance, I ended up growing up that way too. But when I left for study in America and studied the discipline of evolutionary biology, I changed 180 degrees. I came to see and learn about the world with an open perspective. Meeting my current wife also had a positive influence. My father-in-law was also a professor, and it was hard to believe they grew up in the same Korea - it was such a liberal family. Seeing that, I naturally changed."

-There must have been things you learned from your father too.

"Except for how harshly he treated mother, I deeply respect him in my heart. Father is someone who lives his life like the character for 'correct' (正). He is integrity itself. I have never seen him do anything that deviates from principles. Something that happened when I was in third grade left a deep impression. I opened the door without much thought after finishing school, and there was a box full of bundles of money in front of a gentleman in a suit. I had never seen that much money. I was surprised and closed the door and came out, but shortly after, I heard the sound of slapping along with the roar, 'How do you see me that you brought this?'"

-Was it a bribe?

"At that time, father was working as a discharge officer at Army Headquarters. It was a position where he could expedite discharges, so high-ranking officials made many requests. There was even a saying that 'if you work as discharge officer for six months, you can buy a house.' But father, I can say with certainty, never once did anything dishonest. This was in the 1960s when such things were commonplace. Thanks to that, mother still hates the word 'integrity' the most. If father had been just a little less upright, the family's livelihood could have been much more comfortable. He was truly a descendant of General Choi Yeong from the Goryeo period, who left the words 'regard gold like stone.' Thanks to that, I too have lived trying not to harm others and to walk the right path until now."

The secret to his son's SAT perfect score was reading

Unlike his own father, Director Choi raised his child freely. He would jokingly say to his wife, 'What fortune was our son born with to meet a father like me?' "When I was young, seeing my authoritarian and strict father, I made two decisions. It was when father was eating and bit into a stone, mother was trembling as she cleared the table, and we brothers sat holding our breath. One was 'later when I marry, even if a stone comes out of the rice my wife makes, I will chew and swallow it without my wife knowing,' and the other was 'I want to be a soft red-bean porridge father to my child.'"

The child born after nine years of marriage was like a treasure to the couple, but both were clumsy at child-rearing while studying in a distant foreign land. However, they had the chance to learn an excellent educational method through a coincidental opportunity. It was when an elderly couple, whom his wife who majored in music met while conducting a church choir, visited their home saying they wanted to see the child. "The elderly couple told the child, who was only 100 days old, all sorts of stories about how the world works. What happened in the neighborhood yesterday, what the president said on the news, how the world is turning. When we looked puzzled, the grandmother said, 'Do you think the child doesn't understand? Absolutely not. The child understands everything we say.' It was like being hit on the head with a hammer."

After that, they changed their child-rearing method. They, who had spent their days just feeding, sleeping, and playing peek-a-boo, tried to fill the child's mind with knowledge. The couple took turns telling about what happened during the day and read books to the child every single day without fail. They read aloud not only children's books but also specialized books and papers next to the child. Not only the couple but also the Harvard dormitory students, for whom they were serving as house masters at the time, would chat with the child about articles from The Economist and what happened in school classes whenever they had time.

When the child was three years old, something like this happened. Director Choi fell asleep while reading a book due to fatigue, and the child was reading the book by himself. "He wasn't reading the letters but remembering the book's content and saying it out loud. We had read that one book over 50 times, so it was natural he would memorize it. But his ability to acquire language and his memory were exceptional. I could see how important it is to read books to babies."

-Did the child consistently love reading?

"Before going to college, he must have read at least 1,000 books, possibly thousands. He liked all fields without discrimination. Even though his school grades were terrible when he attended international school, seeing him get accepted to prestigious American universities, you can't ignore the power of reading. Even taking the American college entrance exam SAT without any preparation, he always received scores close to perfect. When I asked the child 'what's the secret to getting good scores,' the answer was always the same: 'Dad, all the answers are in books.' Actually, he basically went to school to play. He wouldn't even do coloring homework, saying he didn't want to."

-Many students even receive hagwon education to get good SAT scores.

"We couple also sent our child to an SAT prep hagwon. But due to a small incident, he quit before even attending a week. When the SAT test format completely changed, the hagwon conducted a test, and our child got perfect scores in all subjects. It was amazing. Several parents started raising objections, saying 'Does it make sense to get 100 points on a test format that's being administered for the first time? Something's strange,' and the child said 'I want to stop going.' The child's logic was always 'SAT is similar to an IQ test, so there's no need to prepare in advance.'"

-At first glance, he seems like an 'exemplary friend's child.'

"Right. He grew up without any deficiencies. In short, he had no intensity at all. He's a son I love so much it wouldn't hurt to put him in my eye, but I often thought 'I raised him wrong.' In my view, the child was selfish, only doing what he wanted to do. I sometimes fell into self-loathing at the fact that I had sent such a child into the world. My wife had different thoughts from me. Her logic was that if love overflows, you naturally give that much love to others. Fortunately, I had two opportunities to confirm this."

-What kind of incidents?

"Before college graduation, the child made a bombshell announcement. He said he would go to Johannesburg, South Africa with friends to do volunteer work. The plan was to teach local children for a year, play basketball with them, and give them new life opportunities. Since it was a place famous for poor security, my wife tried to dissuade him. She told him to go to Taiwan or Malaysia instead. But the child wouldn't bend his will, saying 'I must go because it's a dangerous place.' At that time, I honestly almost shed tears of emotion. It was because of my conviction that we hadn't raised our son wrongly. The child stayed in South Africa for a year and even received an award from the South African government for his recognized contribution to the local community."

-What was the other incident?

"I had the opportunity to read my child's college application essay. It was an essay I couldn't see even once when he was applying to colleges. The child, whose school grades were rock bottom but whose SAT scores were excellent, gave amazingly philosophical excuses in his essay about why his school grades had to be bad. The content was that 'he already enjoys many things, and if someone who has more gets even more, the world wouldn't be beautiful.' Simply put, he said he didn't study hard to give opportunities to people who were less fortunate than himself. The writing was so persuasive that I nodded my head several times while reading. It was an incident where I discovered my child's true nature in my own way."

-Did your usual philosophy of 'if you know, you love' work?

"Yes. The same goes for father. It's not that there weren't times I hated him, but when I got to know him, I realized father also had great love. I first felt this when I went to study in America. When I first said 'I want to go study abroad,' father was firmly opposed. After failing to get into Seoul National University medical school twice that father wanted, and barely getting accepted to the zoology department, and then spending time on club activities and playing rather than studying, when his son said 'please help with the cost of studying abroad,' even I would have been flustered. But at that time, I was really desperate and earnestly requested. Father, who understood my intention, quit POSCO where he was working after being scouted from Army Headquarters to provide study abroad funds. Later I learned that rather than money, he retired to spend time with me. After setting out for study abroad, I believed that studying hard was the only way to repay father's love. It's the same with family relationships and other human relationships. When you get to know the other person, you can't help but love them more. Think about walking home with a child you used to bully and having a conversation after meeting by chance. After that, could you still ostracize that child after visiting their home and greeting their mother? I think most human relationship problems are misunderstandings that occur when people don't know each other well. Nature is the same. Insects or trees that look disgusting and useless on the surface all have elements worth loving and cherishing when you get to know them. This is my motto, the reason I pursue academics, and the life value I want to convey not only to my child but to people."

Choi Jae-cheon Profile
Born 1954 in Gangneung, Gangwon Province
1972: Graduated from Seoul Kyungbok High School
1977: Graduated from Seoul National University College of Natural Sciences, Zoology
1982: Earned Master's degree in Ecology from Pennsylvania State University Graduate School, USA
1989: Received Young Scientist Award from American Entomological Society
1990: Earned PhD in Biology from Harvard University Graduate School, USA
1990-92: Harvard University lecturer, USA
1992-94: University of Michigan professor, USA
1994-2006: Seoul National University College of Life Sciences professor
2000: Received 1st Korea Science Culture Award
2006-present: Ewha Womans University Division of EcoScience chair professor
2007-2009: President of Korean Society of Ecology
2013-present: Director of National Institute of Ecology
2014-present: Technical Support Unit head of Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES)
2013-present: Alternative chair of Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD)

●Life role model: American professional basketball legend Julius Erving. I think he's cool flying around the court like a bird. When I was at an American university, I thought I'd give extra points to students who called me Dr. J. Dr. J is Julius Erving's nickname and my English name is also Jae. Later when my son said "If dad had been Black, I could have become an NBA player," I briefly dreamed of being born as Julius Erving.
●Book that changed my life: Jacques Monod's 'Chance and Necessity.' This book, which I discovered during my desperate college life, gave me hope that a biologist could write philosophy books.
●Motto: If you know, you love. Although it's embarrassing to have a motto from words I created myself, you can only love if you know, and you can only cherish nature. This is why I pursue academics.

  "translated_title": "[Cover Story] In the Era of English Absolute Assessment, What Should We Evaluate?",
  "translated_text": "CSAT English in Light of TOEFL
The two eyes of Dike, the goddess of justice, are covered with cloth. In her hands, she holds scales and a sword. The cloth-covered eyes symbolize impartial judgment, the scales represent the strict standards of law, and the sword symbolizes the swift execution of justice. Among these, the most striking is the scales. Without strict and credible standards, judgments and executions based on them cannot earn trust.

Concerns and confusion are mounting over the CSAT English test that will switch to absolute assessment starting from the 2018 academic year. While the success of absolute assessment depends on establishing proper standards, criticism has been raised that the evaluation criteria are vague. If standards are not properly established, it will be difficult to have one's abilities recognized no matter how well one solves test problems. There are also concerns that 600,000 test-takers taking university entrance exams annually may fall into confusion, wandering with blindfolded eyes. To establish impartial and rigorous standards like Dike's scales, we have examined everything from the current state of English education in Korea to cases worth benchmarking.

Changing Landscape of English Education
Absolute Assessment: 1st Grade from 20,000 → 90,000 Students... "Don't Need to Study English Anymore?"

Absolute assessment perceived as easier test for 1st grade
Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] lines: "Reduce English classes and increase math"
Actual study time decreases, concerns about downward standardization

Students memorizing only EBS guidebook translations
Short passages, multiple choice... requiring only fragmentary thinking
Need for evaluation methods like TOEFL that build English proficiency

Starting from the 2018 academic year when current 11th graders take the CSAT, the CSAT English test will change to an absolute assessment method. This change follows the government's policy to eliminate unnecessary learning burden in English and reduce hagwon education [in Korean context, 사교육 refers specifically to the hagwon/tutoring industry]. With news that the test evaluation method will change, not only school English classes but also the atmosphere in hagwon districts has changed. This is due to the characteristic of Korean education where middle and high school education is geared toward university entrance preparation. The biggest change is that high school students' English study time is decreasing. This is due to expectations that the CSAT English test will become easier with the introduction of absolute assessment. As interest in English decreases both in schools and hagwons, experts are voicing concerns that "absolute assessment might create a downward standardization of English proficiency." The landscape of English education is changing with the introduction of English absolute assessment, implemented 22 years after the introduction of the CSAT.

Turmoil Ahead of 2018 Absolute Assessment Transition
The places that experienced the greatest turmoil with news of the CSAT English test transitioning to absolute assessment were high schools in Seoul's Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] area. This is because parents are raising voices demanding "reduce English class hours and increase math classes, or just have students do self-study instead."

Indeed, several schools plan to adjust English classes from six times a week to 4-5 times starting from the second semester. An English teacher at a Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] private high school said, "Students in this area have high average English proficiency through short-term study abroad from elementary school and continuous hagwon education," adding "After the absolute assessment introduction news was announced, as the thought of easily receiving 1st grade became widespread, enthusiasm for English cooled off the most."

Another English teacher in Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] reported that "students' concentration during class has noticeably dropped." "Previously, top students were in an atmosphere of concentrating on class with tension that they might not receive 1st grade if they got even one problem wrong, but now they're taking care of other subjects first, saying 'I already have the ability to score 90 points in English, so there's no need to do more.'"

The number of English hagwons is also decreasing. According to the Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education, English hagwons decreased from 1,213 in 2009 to 986 in 2013, with only 871 remaining last year. Lee Mi-ae, director of Sharon Coaching and Mentoring Research Institute, said, "Even Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] parents are not paying much attention to English hagwon education," explaining "The recent trend is for top students to study English for university entrance only until middle school, and in high school, focus on math or receive high-quality English education at TOEFL hagwons."

Kim, director of an English hagwon in Bundang, Gyeonggi Province, who is recruiting students for a 'CSAT preparation middle school class' for summer vacation, said, "The number of 10th-12th grade students has noticeably decreased since the announcement of absolute assessment introduction." He added, "Especially top students who are confident of receiving 1st grade tend to quit all English hagwon education except for school record hagwons," and "Other hagwons are also finding a way out by reorganizing CSAT English classes that targeted high school students to target middle school students." A middle school parent who visited this hagwon said, "I heard that since the CSAT has become easier, students should finish entrance exam English in middle school and focus on math when they go to high school to get into good universities," asking "Wouldn't there be no need to exert effort on CSAT English in high school?"

These changes occur because the introduction of English absolute assessment is interpreted as meaning "it has become easier to receive 1st grade in English subjects." With the current relative assessment grading method, one must be in the top 4% to receive 1st grade. If perfect scorers exceeded 4% of test-takers, getting even one problem wrong would slide one down to 2nd grade or lower. Intense competition for 'absolute perfect scores' was inevitable to receive 1st grade. However, with absolute assessment introduction, all students scoring 90 points or above will receive 1st grade. When the Ministry of Education announced its policy to maintain the current easy CSAT trend, stating "problems will be set at a level that any student who faithfully completes school education can solve," the perception of 'English absolute assessment = easy test' became official.

According to data analyzed by Jongro Academy Sky Education, when converting the current CSAT English test to absolute assessment method as is, the number of 1st grade recipients would dramatically increase from 26,070 to 90,664. The total number of new students selected annually by Seoul universities combined is only slightly over 70,000. Arithmetically speaking, among 90,000 students who received 1st grade in English, 20,000 would have difficulty getting accepted to Seoul universities. There is also analysis that students passing major universities' minimum CSAT English standards would surge from around 69,000 to around 144,000. It has become virtually impossible to differentiate students with the CSAT English test changed to absolute assessment. This is why universities are reducing the reflection ratio of CSAT English test scores.

Professor Lee Byung-min of Seoul National University's English Education Department pointed out, "If absolute assessment standards are not precisely calibrated and only increase the number of 1st grade recipients, it will ultimately only lower the importance of English subjects in university selection processes and deteriorate the quality of English learning during high school."

Concerns arise that if absolute assessment is introduced without improving current CSAT test problems, Korean high school students' English proficiency will overall take a step backward. The government has not yet presented specific measures on how English tests will change after introducing CSAT absolute assessment.

English education experts unanimously agreed that "problems currently possessed by the CSAT must be urgently improved ahead of absolute assessment introduction."

The first problem identified is 'English becoming a memorization subject due to high EBS linkage rates.' The current CSAT English test's linkage rate with EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] materials reaches 70-80%. Moreover, since even English passages are identically presented, test-takers prepare for English tests by memorizing Korean translations recorded in guidebooks instead of interpreting English texts and solving problems. 12th grade students say, "Since passages from EBS appear identically in the CSAT anyway, memorizing guidebook translations is much more efficient than spending time reading comprehension myself, as guidebook translations are accurate."

This is also why Professor Lee points out that "it's difficult to grasp what the CSAT English test actually measures," saying "It's impossible to know whether it measures ability to communicate in English, evaluates linguistic knowledge of English, assesses high school academic achievement, or determines intellectual qualities for continuing studies at university."

The fact that only short texts of 120 words are presented as problems is also pointed out as a problem with current CSAT English tests. This is because it only requires fragmentary and standardized thinking. Professor Lee Hyun-woo, department head of Inha University's English Education Department, criticized, "When CSAT tests only deal with fragmentary and marginal problems, students focus only on simple memorization during school years without developing creative and critical thinking skills." The point is that if one only trains to think within standardized frameworks until adolescence, it becomes difficult to demonstrate creative thinking ability after becoming an adult.

Kim Seung-kyu, TOEFL star instructor at EBS LANG (EBS online foreign language learning site), also said, "It's difficult to accurately judge students' abilities with only the current written examination format of simply choosing answers from given options." "While comprehensive evaluation that simultaneously tests reading, listening, speaking, and writing like TOEFL would be desirable, realistically, introducing something like 'English essay writing' should be considered."

▷Click here to see larger image

"CSAT Doesn't Improve English Proficiency"
Many cited TOEFL as an exemplary case worth referencing for the CSAT English test changing to absolute assessment. Unlike the CSAT English test being criticized for not accurately measuring students' English proficiency, research papers have proven that TOEFL scores accurately evaluate students' actual English abilities. Professor Lee, department head, who wrote papers such as 'Validity of Official English Standardized Tests as Communication Ability Measurement Tools' and 'Research on the Relationship between TOEFL, TOEIC, TEPS Test Scores and University Academic Ability,' said, "It's a proven fact that students with high TOEFL scores have high levels of understanding classes and performing assignments at university."

In a survey conducted by JoongAng Ilbo Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] Correspondence targeting EBS LANG members, contrasting evaluations of CSAT English tests and TOEFL could be confirmed. Over half of respondents (54%) answered that the most effective method for preparing for CSAT English tests was 'memorizing past problems.' 51% also answered that 'repeatedly reviewing only specific textbooks (EBS materials) is sufficient.' In contrast, only 17% felt that 'English proficiency itself improves through CSAT test preparation,' and only 12% said understanding was more important than memorization. Additionally, they answered that for CSAT English tests, 'memorization is more important than understanding' (61%), 'grasping grammar and sentence structure takes priority over ability to converse with foreigners' (45%), and 'memorizing prescribed vocabulary is more effective than English debates' (45%).

Perceptions of TOEFL were different. They thought that 'studying for improving common sense and thinking ability beyond English study is necessary' (62%), one should 'develop habits of expressing thoughts using English regularly' (64%), 'understanding is more important than memorization' (48%), and 'English proficiency itself improves through test preparation' (48%).

Professor Lee emphasized, "The CSAT English test must improve both format and content before just changing the grading calculation method to absolute assessment," stressing "The important task is to precisely design evaluation methods so that English proficiency can improve just by studying for tests, like TOEFL."

English Evaluation Standards Seen Through TOEFL
Reading long texts and grasping context instead of grammar, evaluating writing and speaking abilities too

TOEFL also had 'pinpoint lectures' [teachers known for accurately predicting exam questions] in early days
Changed to iBT requiring critical thinking abilities
Japanese and Chinese university entrance texts longer than Korea's

Changes in evaluation methods can change classroom appearance. TOEFL testing actually did this. Shin Eun-mi, TOEFL instructor at English specialty hagwon Yeongdangi, said, "Whenever TOEFL tests were upgraded, hagwon class appearance also changed."

The TOEFL test first implemented in 1964 wasn't much different from today's CSAT. For reading sections, short texts consisting of 250 words per passage were predominant. There were also many grammar problems. Professor Lee Byung-min of Seoul National University's English Education Department said, "When I took TOEFL tests, there were problems in listening evaluation asking to find answers after hearing just one sentence." With standardized questions asking fragmentary knowledge levels, 'pinpoint lectures' [teachers known for accurately predicting exam questions] flourished at every hagwon. It wasn't uncommon for instructors to point out expected problems before tests, with test-takers memorizing only these to receive high scores.

This atmosphere changed with the introduction of iBT TOEFL in 2006. Instructor Shin said, "When TOEFL tests changed to long text reading and speaking and writing were introduced, making it impossible to receive good scores through memorization alone, I began giving students advice like 'read texts while thinking' and 'engage in logical and critical thinking' during lectures," adding "When evaluation methods change desirably, classes preparing for them must also develop."

There were two changes to TOEFL testing before the current iBT TOEFL existed. The first was changing from paper-based PBT (Paper-Based-Test) to computer-based CBT (Computer-Based-Test) starting in 1998. In evaluation content, grammar was removed and writing tests began. The current internet-based TOEFL test iBT (Internet-Based-Test) started in 2005. It was introduced in Korea from September 2006. Speaking sections were added at this time. Jennifer Brown, TOEFL Program Executive Director at ETS, the TOEFL organizing company, said, "Starting with iBT, we began creating problems based on 'communication ability theory,' and comprehensive evaluation of four areas—reading, listening, speaking, and writing—is also based on this theory."

Kang Ki-nam, vice director of YBM Sisa Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] Academy, explained, "TOEFL has gradually excluded problems grasping grammar and short sentence structures, changing toward verifying whether students can actually attend classes and perform assignments when going to English-speaking universities."

Korean students who study by identifying test types and learning high-scoring strategies fell into confusion whenever TOEFL test content and format changed. Instructor Park Se-yeon of Yeongdangi said, "The period when students received the biggest shock was when speaking sections were added," adding "To avoid taking speaking tests somehow, an enormous number of test-takers flocked to the previous month's TOEFL test."

Vice Director Kang also recalled, "Whether public or hagwon education, Korea was about listening to lectures and memorizing without saying a word during English time, but speaking about one topic for 45 seconds in TOEFL was difficult to adapt to." Korean test-takers' TOEFL scores also dropped significantly at that time. Korea's TOEFL ranking, which was 77th among 134 countries in the June 2006 CBT test, dropped to 111th as soon as the iBT test with speaking sections first introduced began in September that year.

However, it rose again to 58th among 166 countries in 2013. The ranking is higher than China or Japan, similar to Hong Kong. Vice Director Kang said, "While Hong Kong has high speaking and writing section scores, Korea has the highest reading scores but relatively low speaking scores."

TOEFL tests measure English ability in four areas: reading, listening, speaking, and writing. Professor Lee said, "Reading sections present a total of three passages with about 650-750 words per passage, which is quite long compared to CSAT English test reading passages consisting of 120 words." Professor Lee explained, "Evaluating long text reading ability in university entrance exams is also a global trend," adding "Even Japan and China have English passage lengths 2-3 times longer than ours in domestic university selection tests."

Professor Lee Byung-min said that 'finding grammatical errors' and 'filling blanks' commonly appearing in CSAT English tests are not actually English abilities universities need. Professor Lee, who says "reading long texts and reading short texts evaluate completely different abilities," explained, "Reading short texts requires knowing the exact meaning of each word, but reading long texts requires ability to grasp overall context rather than word meanings. Universities need ability to read at least one chapter of long text and organize one's thoughts, not reading methods that examine each sentence with a microscope to find grammatical errors."
