  "translated_text": "Ongoing Controversy Over Comprehensive School Record Admissions
▷Click here to view larger
Preparing for comprehensive admissions while also studying for CSAT... burden too great
More than half of students and parents: "Should reduce proportion of comprehensive admissions"
"Disadvantageous for passive students who only like studying"
Problem is school and teacher gaps leading to hagwon education dependence
Tendency for only some top-tier students to receive 'management'
"Support to encourage teacher efforts through incentives urgently needed"

Controversy surrounding the Comprehensive School Record Admissions system (hereafter "comprehensive admissions") continues unabated. As millions of won worth of hagwon education for writing small research papers flourishes, comprehensive admissions has even been called the "golden spoon admissions system." Some argue for the uselessness of comprehensive admissions, claiming "CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] is more fair and objective" and "the proportion selected through CSAT should be drastically increased." Such arguments are gaining considerable sympathy among students and parents.

On the other hand, many teachers say "comprehensive admissions has contributed to normalizing public education through curriculum diversification" and "arguing for abolition while ignoring its positive functions amounts to nothing more than regressing to the early 2000s when we worried about classroom collapse."

JoongAng Ilbo's Open Study, together with Jongno Academy Sky Education [an entrance exam prep institution], surveyed 850 nationwide 2nd and 3rd year high school students (522 from general high schools, 328 from specialized/autonomous private schools) and 285 Seoul-area parents from the 20th-27th of last month about their opinions on comprehensive admissions. Results combined JoongAng Ilbo's survey of students at 5 Seoul-area high schools (2 general, 2 autonomous private, 1 specialized) with Sky Education Jongno Academy's online survey. For teacher opinions, we referenced results from a survey conducted by the National College Admissions Guidance Council (hereafter "NCAGC") targeting 385 middle and high school teachers nationwide from the 19th-22nd of last month.

Students and parents negative, teachers positive
▷Click here to view larger
The perspectives of students/parents versus teachers on comprehensive admissions are starkly divided. Only 21.5% of students answered that "comprehensive admissions contributes to normalizing public education." For the same question, only 18.9% of parents answered "yes." However, in the survey of 385 middle and high school teachers, 76.6% responded that "comprehensive admissions contributes to normalizing public education." Teachers hold positive views while students and parents hold predominantly negative views.

The burden felt by students and parents regarding comprehensive admissions was considerable. Among surveyed students, 39.8% chose comprehensive admissions as the most burdensome college entrance exam type to prepare for. 58.9% of parents answered that "comprehensive admissions is most burdensome."

Regarding fairness and objectivity, opinions between teachers and students/parents also differed greatly. While 56.1% of teachers answered that "comprehensive admissions is a fair and objective evaluation system," only 19.4% of students and 11.6% of parents thought so.

Accordingly, opinions on comprehensive admissions selection scale also differed greatly. While 39% of teachers answered that "comprehensive admissions selection scale should be increased more than now," only 24.1% of students and 12.6% of parents supported expanding comprehensive admissions. Students and parents were dominated by opinions favoring reduction. 50.5% of students and 68.5% of parents answered that "comprehensive admissions scale should be reduced from now."

The biggest reason students and parents feel burdened is that there are more than one or two elements to prepare for. They must manage school records [GPA] as well as extracurriculars like clubs, reading, and volunteer activities, while also preparing for CSAT. Kang, a 2nd-year student at a general high school in Seoul's Gangbuk-gu [a district in Seoul], said "You have no choice but to become Superman" and "Since you can't only look toward comprehensive admissions, you can't reduce CSAT study time while doing extracurricular activities."

The fact that it's qualitative rather than quantitative evaluation like CSAT also adds to confusion. Kang said "For CSAT and essay-writing exams, there are many past problems and you can analyze question trends, so you can make plans about how much you need to do, but for comprehensive admissions I don't know the specific evaluation criteria themselves, so I have no sense of how to prepare."

Lim Byeong-wook, vice principal at Seoul's Inchang High School, pointed out "It's time for universities to proactively consider more detailed disclosure of evaluation indicators." Vice Principal Lim said "Some worry that if universities disclose specific evaluation indicators, the hagwon education market will grow, but right now restoring student and parent trust in comprehensive admissions is more urgent" and "If it's truly fair and objective evaluation, there's no reason each university can't disclose it."

Lee Seong-kwon, teacher at Seoul's Daejin High School (representative of the Korean Education Policy Teachers' Solidarity), pointed out "Instead of expressing with ambiguous vocabulary like academic capability, major aptitude, self-direction, and character, they should explain with rich examples and concrete definitions what kind of student has major aptitude."

In this year's college admissions, total early admission recruitment is 248,669 students, reaching 69.9% of total recruitment. Of this, 72,101 students (20.3%) are recruited through comprehensive admissions. While it's just over 20% nationwide, when narrowed to top-tier Seoul universities, the selection scale is large at 30-40% of total recruitment. Seoul National University selects 76.7% (2,406 students) of this year's total recruitment through comprehensive admissions, and Korea University plans to abolish essay-writing admissions from the 2018 academic year and drastically increase comprehensive admissions. Kim (45, Seoul's Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry]), who has a 2nd-year high school child, said "Comprehensive admissions is now 'essential,' not 'optional'" and "With selection ratios this high, how can you not prepare?"

Criticisms arise that comprehensive admissions selection ratios are excessively high. Kim said "Comprehensive admissions is disadvantageous for students who are quiet and passive and prefer studying over activities" and "For such students, it seems right to select half through CSAT." Ahn Yeon-geun, teacher at Seoul's Jamsil Girls' High School (president of Seoul College Admissions Guidance Council), said "Since comprehensive admissions isn't suitable for all students, to give diverse students college admission opportunities, it's right for universities to maintain appropriate ratios of not just comprehensive admissions but also essays, special talents, and CSAT."

Worry of 'only I will lose out' without consulting
▷Click here to view larger
Since comprehensive admissions evaluates school activities, admission results are greatly influenced by career and aptitude development programs provided by schools and teacher passion. Among 385 teachers participating in the NCAGC survey, 85.5% answered that "comprehensive admissions can change students' admission results depending on the quality of individual schools' curricula and career/college prep programs," and 88.1% responded that "students' admission results can change depending on teacher passion."

Students' satisfaction with school comprehensive admissions programs differed by school type. 36.3% of specialized/autonomous private school students answered that they "receive help from school," but only 23.2% of general high school students said so. Conversely, "not receiving help" responses were higher for general high schools at 38.9% compared to specialized/autonomous private schools (25.6%). General high school students feel they receive less school help than specialized/autonomous private school students.

Students pointed to school program deficiencies in order of "schools only care about some top-tier students" (37.1%) and "college counseling is irregular and inaccurate" (15.9%). Kim, a 2nd-year student at a general high school in Seoul's Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul], said "With CSAT, at least there's hope that you can succeed through hard work, but with comprehensive admissions you often can't even get opportunities from the start" and "Schools only provide intensive management for top students within the top 10% in school records." Many schools operate various forms of comprehensive admissions-focused ability grouping under names like advanced classes, intensive study groups, and gifted classes. With limited school resources and funding but needing to produce comprehensive admissions guidance results, they focus only on a small number of top students.

Gaps between schools and teachers lead to hagwon education demand for consulting and personal statement editing. General high school students with lower satisfaction with school programs showed higher hagwon education dependence. 39.1% of general high school students answered that they "need much hagwon education help," while the response rate for specialized/autonomous private school students was lower at 25.3%. General high school students answering "receiving or planning to receive hagwon education" were 47.9%, higher than specialized/autonomous private schools (43.3%).

Parents unanimously say "if we don't receive consulting, only our child will lose out." Lee (51, Seoul's Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry]), who has a 2nd-year high school child, said "Teachers know even less than I do" and "The process of how they worked hard is important, but many teachers just record tons of results like 'did XX.'"

Students also most frequently cited "school records vary greatly depending on teachers" as the biggest factor harming comprehensive admissions' fairness and objectivity.

Arguments emerge for creating unified standards for school record writing methods to overcome teacher gaps. A research paper titled "Restructuring School Record Information" announced by Seoul National University last February proposed "It's necessary to institutionalize within schools a procedure where all teachers who handled students - homeroom teachers, subject teachers, career counselors, and club advisors - gather each semester and at year-end to share student evaluations and participate together in school record writing."

Changes in frontline school and teacher awareness are also needed. Ju Seok-hun, principal of Seoul's Mirim Girls' High School, said "Fundamentally, there are problems with teaching methods." Principal Ju said "Many schools still rely on one-way lecture-style classes" and "When student-centered activities like presentations, discussions, and project assignments increase in classes, teachers have content to observe and can record processes in school records." He said "Rather than focusing on creating unique extracurricular programs, it's important for schools to steadily carry out their fundamental work of developing and applying new teaching models."

General high schools improving teaching models see better college admission results
▷Click here to view larger
Despite various controversies, comprehensive admissions is clearly driving changes in frontline school settings. Teacher Ahn Yeon-geun said "Ten years ago when I was in charge of drama club guidance, parents strongly opposed it saying it interfered with CSAT studying, but now parents welcome diverse club activities." Teachers unanimously say "Since comprehensive admissions expanded, positive changes are occurring in many schools, including increased student-centered classes with presentations and discussions, and activated clubs."

In the NCAGC survey, 61.3% of 385 teachers answered that "curricula have diversified since implementing comprehensive admissions," and 75.3% said "students participate more actively in classes and school activities since implementing comprehensive admissions." Teacher Ahn evaluated "When there was only CSAT, the widespread perception was that you just needed to go to hagwons and study for CSAT, and classroom collapse occurred with some specialized school students' group withdrawals" and "Compared to then, changes led by comprehensive admissions are clearly positive."

Many also believe comprehensive admissions can provide opportunities for general high schools, not just specialized/autonomous private schools. Seongdeok High School in Seoul's Gangdong-gu is such an example. Seongdeok High converted from a commercial high school to a general high school in 2013. Kim Yu-dong, Seongdeok High's career guidance department head, recalled "In the early period of general high school conversion, prejudices that academic levels would be low because it was formerly a commercial school followed like a label."

This school found answers in comprehensive admissions. They secured many young teachers and developed new teaching models. They judged that innovating school classes for the comprehensive admissions era was the only way to survive. This school created 100-minute block time classes combining two periods. 1st and 2nd year students conduct 100-minute block time classes once weekly each in Korean, English, math, social studies, and science subjects. Four days a week they have 50-minute classes for basic subject progress, and one day they conduct 100-minute classes. Teachers observe presentations, discussions, and experiments during the 100 minutes and record each student's comments in school records.

As block time class effectiveness became known, Seongdeok High developed into a popular school with 4-to-1 application ratios and improved college admission results. Department head Kim said "About 90% of students who passed through comprehensive admissions among February graduates were students who would have had difficulty passing those schools with CSAT scores."

Inchang High School, a general high school in Seoul's Seodaemun-gu, also shows examples of school field changes in the comprehensive admissions era. This school of about 800 students has as many as 140 clubs. There are 60 R&E clubs conducting small research papers and discussions with teachers. Vice Principal Lim Byeong-wook said "Teachers handle an average of 3 or more clubs each for guidance" and "After daily classes end, club activities occur actively in each classroom."

Arts and physical education is also notable. All 1st year Inchang High students belong to 51 bands and learn vocals, guitar, drums, etc. They brought the one-person-one-instrument education popular in specialized/autonomous private schools into general high schools. This school also extended its annual October one-day festival to three days starting last year. Student-planned festivals are good material for showing planning ability, self-direction, and cooperation that comprehensive admissions evaluates importantly.

However, not all general high schools are quickly transforming to match comprehensive admissions. Teacher Ahn said "Perspectives on comprehensive admissions vary even within teacher groups" and "A considerable number of schools still haven't escaped from regular admission (CSAT)-centered college guidance." Vice Principal Lim said "Teacher dedication and effort must be prerequisites to change school systems for comprehensive admissions" and "Policy support to elicit teacher efforts is desperately needed."

Opinions also exist that the Ministry of Education should expand financial support for general high schools. Currently, the Ministry of Education supports about 45 billion won [approximately $34 million USD] to universities nationwide under the name "high school normalization project" to expand comprehensive admissions. However, there's no financial support for general high schools. Teacher Lee Seong-kwon argued "Government policy priorities are wrong" and "Financial support should be expanded so general high schools can innovate teaching models and operate diverse programs through excellent teacher incentive systems."

By reporters Jeong Hyeon-jin and Jeon Min-hee Jeon.hyeonjin@joongang.co.kr

2016 Academic Year Analysis of Comprehensive Admissions Successful Candidates at 5 Universities Including Seoul National and Yonsei
Comprehensive admissions successful candidates: 63.5% from general high schools, 25.7% from specialized/autonomous private schools

There's much criticism that the Comprehensive School Record Admissions system (hereafter "comprehensive admissions") is a golden spoon system advantageous to specialized/autonomous private school students. Some argue "comprehensive admissions should be drastically reduced and regular admission (hereafter "regular") centered on CSAT should be increased." Is this really true? If regular admissions increase, can university doors open wider for general high schools than now?

We analyzed 2016 academic year successful candidate data by high school type from 5 universities - Kyung Hee, Seoul National, Yonsei, Ewha Womans, and Chung-Ang - to examine the ratios of general high school versus specialized/autonomous private school successful candidates in each university's comprehensive admissions and regular admissions. Analysis results showed general high schools had higher successful candidate ratios in comprehensive admissions than regular admissions, while specialized/autonomous private schools had higher ratios in regular admissions than comprehensive admissions.

Among the 5 universities' comprehensive admissions successful candidates, 63.5% (4,316 out of 6,796) were from general high schools, while among regular admissions successful candidates, the ratio from general high schools was 58.1% (3,247 out of 5,587). Conversely, successful candidate ratios from specialized/autonomous private schools were 25.7% (1,748 out of 6,796) for comprehensive admissions and 35.2% (1,967 out of 5,587) for regular admissions, with regular admission success ratios being higher. Lim Jin-taek, chief admissions officer at Kyung Hee University, explained "Among college entrance exam types, the factor with the greatest hagwon education influence is CSAT" and "Disparities by high school type are more serious in CSAT-centered regular admissions than comprehensive admissions."

Regional distribution of successful candidates also shows comprehensive admissions being more balanced than regular admissions. Looking at regional distribution of 1,820 general high school students who passed Seoul National University in 2016, students from Seoul-Gyeonggi regions comprised 46.9% (628 out of 1,339) in comprehensive admissions, while 66.1% (318 out of 481) were from Seoul-Gyeonggi in regular admissions. Seoul-Gyeonggi regional concentration was more severe in regular admissions than comprehensive admissions.

Narrowing the analysis to within Seoul, examining distribution of general high school students from educational special districts like Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul], Seocho, Songpa, Yangcheon, and Nowon versus non-educational special districts, educational special district graduates reached a whopping 80.3% (143 out of 178) in regular admissions. In contrast, educational special district graduates were only 54.4% (215 out of 395) in comprehensive admissions. This means comprehensive admissions keeps doors more widely open for general high school students from non-educational special districts than regular admissions. Teacher Lee Seong-kwon from Seoul's Daejin High School analyzed "It's really difficult for general high school students from Gangbuk [northern Seoul districts, generally less affluent] regions to pass Seoul National University through regular admissions" and "Comprehensive admissions shows more balanced regional distribution compared to CSAT, which has significant hagwon education influence, by importantly evaluating school records."

By reporter Jeong Hyeon-jin

  "translated_text": "Summer vacation has begun. Study method experts unanimously agree that "vacation is both an opportunity and a turning point." Students need strategies to analyze their strengths and weaknesses and fill in gaps. We asked three people famous for study method coaching about summer vacation study strategies: Kang Seong-tae, CEO of Gongsin.com; Jo Nam-ho, CEO of StudyCode; and Song Jae-yeol, Leader of Study Revolution Corps. All three did not have outstanding grades when they first entered high school. However, they achieved dramatic grade improvements and were accepted to Seoul National University. We've compiled study strategies drawn from their experiences.

Kang Seong-tae, CEO of Gongsin.com
Don't look at multiple workbooks, solve one until it falls apart
There's hardly any difference in content between workbooks on the market
You must understand perfectly enough to teach it
Parents should praise 'you can do it' to help overcome limits

Being impatient is a sure way to ruin things. The same goes for studying. When vacation starts, many students get overly enthusiastic and buy loads of workbooks. But a month later, the results are often disappointing. Most cases involve scribbling here and there without properly finishing even one book. It's worth reflecting on the meaning of gwa-yu-bul-geup (過猶不及) - excess is as bad as deficiency. Kang Seong-tae, CEO of Gongsin.com, advises that "greed is forbidden" and "studying requires selection and focus." He says, "To make selections, you must first discard and empty out unnecessary things," and advises, "Start by throwing away the workbooks you display proudly on your desk but never actually look at." "This summer vacation, no more, no less - choose exactly one workbook per subject. Then repeatedly solve that workbook until it falls apart. When vacation ends and the semester begins, you'll gain confidence in studying."

-Students might feel anxious if told to solve only one workbook.
"Digesting large quantities gives you a momentary sense of satisfaction. If you stick with just one workbook, you'll have anxious thoughts like 'Is it okay to study so little?' But thinking long-term, this method allows you to digest much more. Even if it seems slow now, speed increases over time. Actually, workbooks on the market have hardly any differences from each other. With CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] having been around for over 20 years, there are established patterns for basic, example, and application problems. There are slight differences in editing and composition between workbooks, but no major differences in problem composition. If you repeatedly solve one book multiple times and perfectly understand one semester's worth of content, you'll gain speed when solving the next workbook. You can finish the next workbook even faster. Properly completing one book gives you the confidence of 'I did it' and creates momentum in studying."

-This seems like advice to focus on understanding.
"That's right. Study methods that mechanically increase quantity focus on memorization. It's the approach of 'just solve a lot.' But wrong problems remain wrong, and mistakes repeat. That's because you don't look for reasons why you got them wrong. The study method of properly finishing one book emphasizes understanding. You skim through once to find problems you get wrong, then repeatedly solve them while analyzing why you got them wrong, then solve again to reduce mistakes. Rather than solving new problems each time, it's more efficient to solve the same problems multiple times to make them truly yours. It's good to repeatedly solve one book until you can immediately think of the solution just by looking at the problem."

-Did you have such an experience yourself?
"My high school life was a series of feelings of inferiority. I listened to classes earnestly and really tried hard, but my grades always stayed in place. I worked hard but got poor grades, while a friend who always played during class would borrow my notes, study, and get 100 points. I became impatient. I bought more workbooks. In first year, I bought all the workbooks on the market and tried to memorize problems and solutions completely. Then around mid-second year, I seriously reflected on myself. Why weren't my grades improving? What was the problem? I changed my study method to earnestly solving one workbook. I solved one math workbook 10 times. Then I understood the problems. I could see why I was getting them wrong. I finally understood what it meant to understand concepts. From then on, I reduced the number of workbooks for all subjects. I had to write the character 正 (meaning 'correct') twice in front of workbooks to finish one."

-How do you confirm whether you've properly understood concepts?
"Try giving a lecture for exactly one hour in front of friends. I mean explain in your own way, using your own language. If you can't figure out how to explain it to others, you haven't properly understood the concept. If your conceptual understanding is too lacking, you don't even need workbooks. Repeat textbooks this vacation. Most students ignore textbooks as being easy, but if you ask them to give a one-hour lecture with a textbook, no student can do it. It means they've understood concepts roughly. After finishing daily study, filling out a blank sheet in your own way is also a good method. Recalling what you studied today and what concepts you learned while organizing once has a good review effect."

-You usually emphasize parents' roles a lot.
"Most students with low academic achievement have low self-esteem. Before even trying, they tend to prejudge their own limits, saying things like 'I'm weak in math' or 'I naturally lack linguistic sense.' Parents have a big influence. When I ask such students why they think that way, most answer 'That's what my mom says.' Many parents evaluate their children based on just a few low test scores. From childhood, children hear their mothers say 'You seem weak in math.' There are more negative words like 'No' and 'You can't' than positive words like 'Well done,' 'You can do it,' or 'It's okay.' Then children naturally set limits, thinking 'Oh, I can't do math.'"

-What was Representative Kang's mother like?
"I attended middle and high school in Ilsan [a suburban area of Seoul]. At that time, Ilsan had non-standardized high school admissions, so you entered based on joint exam scores. I entered the highest-performing high school in the region. I had been 2nd in my class in middle school, but in the class placement test after entering high school, I ranked around 300th out of 330 students. Since only high-performing students were gathered at that school, it was overwhelming to keep up at first. From when I was young, my mother always told me to the point where my ears could have calluses, 'You will become a great person.' Even when I brought home report cards with grades close to last in the school, she always said the same thing. Thanks to my mother's encouragement, I didn't give up."

-What advice would you give to parents?
"Finding good hagwons [private academies] and good private tutors, analyzing college admission information instead of the child, and devising strategies are useless if the child lacks motivation to study. Rather than scolding 'Why don't you study?', it's important to instill motivation in the child. Taking a break from studying this vacation is also a method. Send them to volunteer at really difficult and challenging places. Moving your body through hardship and thinking about and experiencing your neighbors' difficulties is also good studying. And I hope you always say positive things to your children like 'Well done' and 'You can do it.' Positivity and praise will become the driving force for children to overcome their own limits."

Kang Seong-tae was born in Seoul in 1983, graduated from Ilsan Baekseok High School in 2001, entered Seoul National University's Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering in 2001, started educational volunteer club 'Gongsin' activities in 2006, established learning consulting company 'Gongsin.com' in 2008, and graduated from Seoul National University in 2009. His books include 'God of Study: 1000 Secrets' (2013) and 'You Must Be Crazy to Study' (2015). ※ After entering high school, he scored around 300th out of 330 students in the class placement test. In first year, his school records were mid-level, and his CSAT mock test scores barely made 'in-Seoul [universities in Seoul]' possible. Around mid-second year, he changed his study methods and significantly improved his grades, gaining admission to Seoul National University.

Jo Nam-ho, CEO of StudyCode
Don't open books for a week, if grades don't rise, think about study methods first
Seoul National University students focus on understanding, not memorization
Make study plans based on quantity, not time
Study methods must vary according to individual characteristics and strengths/weaknesses

Education experts cite 'metacognitive knowledge' as the most important ability in studying. This refers to the ability to accurately identify what you know and don't know when learning something or doing new work, then act accordingly. For example, when grades in a particular subject are poor, it's the ability to find reasons yourself and make and implement plans for overcoming problems. Jo Nam-ho, CEO of StudyCode, advised developing metacognitive knowledge this summer vacation. "It's not important to solve many problems right away," he said. "As you start this summer vacation, examine your own study methods and find and solve problems."

-You often advise to 'study study methods.'
"There's something I really want to tell students as this vacation begins. This might sound absurd, but I want them to close their books for a week. Not studying for a week won't make your grades drop. And take time to carefully reflect on your study methods. Think about whether the studying you've done so far was right, what you lack, and how to fill those gaps. It's not about tackling workbooks, but studying 'study methods.' If you're working hard but your grades are stagnating, there's definitely a problem with yourself first."

-Are you saying that poor studying isn't just a matter of insufficient effort?
"Effort is of course the first prerequisite. But effort doesn't directly lead to results. Students now digest tremendous amounts of studying, including school and even hagwons. In terms of study quantity alone, it's the world's best. While taking hagwon classes, everyone thinks 'I'm studying hard.' But the 'quality' of effort differs by student. You need to seriously consider whether you're wearing clothes (study methods) that fit you. Seoul National University students focus on understanding. They make efforts to make it their own. In contrast, students who don't study well pile memorization upon memorization."

-How are Seoul National University students different?
"In preparing to start StudyCode, I conducted in-depth interviews with about 3,000 Seoul National University students. You might think Seoul National University students have tremendously high IQs, but the average IQ of those 3,000 Seoul National University students was only 110. They didn't study well because they were born with exceptional brains. The key is intellectual persistence. Specifically, they focus on understanding rather than memorization. Seoul National University students constantly asked 'why' when encountering new concepts and problems. They continuously ask themselves questions like 'Why is this problem solved this way?', 'What's the core of this concept?', and 'I keep getting the same problem wrong, how should I solve it?' If they can't convince themselves with these questions, they don't move to the next stage. They invest tremendous time in understanding one problem. They're almost like 'obsession patients' - when they encounter difficult problems, they persistently work until they solve them with their own strength."

-Are you saying quality is more important than quantity?
"That's right. The amount of studying digested per day varies individually. Some students solved only 5 math problems per day, while others solved 30 problems. The speed and method of solving and understanding problems differs by person. There's no clearly unified correct answer for specific study skills like preview and review methods. But whether solving 5 or 30 problems per day, the common factor is that they perfectly understand whatever they planned to study until they completely comprehend it. Seoul National University students showed the characteristic of making study plans based on quantity, not time, when planning. Rather than mechanically planning what to study from what time to what time, they specifically set target quantities like how many pages or problems per day."

-It's impressive that there's no correct answer in study methods.
"When people talk about study methods, they often ask questions related to study skills, like how to write error notebooks or what to focus on during review. But since students each have different styles - morning types, evening types, etc. - study methods that fit everyone are like a mirage. What's important is the process of finding study methods that suit you. You can find the best study methods through the process of asking yourself about and pondering study methods that fit you."

-What about yourself?
"I really worked hard until second year of high school. But my grades always stayed in place. My scores barely made 'in-Seoul [universities]' possible. Starting the winter break of second year, I seriously wondered why. I closed books for a week. Then I kept following around and asking a friend who did well on CSAT mock tests. 'Why don't you look at that chapter when studying Jeongseok [a math workbook]?' 'You fold your scratch paper in half to write? Should I try that too?' Later, that friend got angry that he couldn't study because of me - I bothered him that much. I kept asking 'why.' Following him around and observing for a week, I could see differences from me. For two years, I had tried to memorize everything unconditionally. I just memorized problems and answers. But that friend would struggle with one problem. From then on, I changed my study methods. I consciously decided 'let's not memorize.' When solving problems and studying concepts, I always asked 'why.'"

"The first three months were really anxious. But I was desperate. If I had worked so hard for two years but results weren't good, I thought there was definitely something wrong. When I changed from memorization to understanding-focused methods, the amount I studied drastically decreased. But after doing that for six months, around the summer break of third year, I got a sense of what CSAT was about. It was a new sensation I had never felt before. Understanding concepts gave me speed. I could digest much more at a much faster pace than when I only memorized. Just running forward looking ahead isn't always the answer. If you stop once and look around, you can see things that weren't visible before. If you seriously doubt yourself, you can see what you lack and what you need to fill going forward."

Song Jae-yeol, Leader of Study Revolution Corps
Don't make hagwon pilgrimages, without time for self-study it's a waste of time
Grades don't rise with just hagwons and private tutoring

During vacation, don't nag 'study'

Song Jae-yeol, who leads learning consulting company 'Study Revolution Corps,' entered Seoul National University's Archaeology and Art History Department and transferred to Cornell University's Architecture Department as a sophomore. Looking at his career alone, he seems like a model student. But he didn't walk a smooth path. Three turning points changed his life.

The first turning point was during the second semester of first year middle school. After six years of elementary school with no connection to studying, he became class president by chance. Thinking he should be a role model for friends, he began studying earnestly. His rank jumped from 30th-40th out of 60 students in the class to 2nd place. He consistently maintained ranks of 20th-30th school-wide while serving as vice president in second year and president in third year.

However, when he became head of the cheering squad in second year of high school, he began neglecting studies. His grades, which had been in the upper ranks until first semester of first year high school, fell to 22nd out of 50 students. "When grades fell, I disliked studying even more. Once I consistently marked '4' on a German test and got 20 points. Going from model student to problem child happened in an instant."

What made him want to study again was his homeroom teacher in second semester of second year high school. Though a first-year teacher, he showed special interest in Song, who was active and had good relationships with friends despite poor grades. He even bought dinner at family restaurants after school. The homeroom teacher told him, "It would be a waste to throw away what you studied before, so how about starting again?" It was sincere affection and interest, not nagging.

-Did you actually study hard again?
"Yes. The more the teacher was good to me, the more sorry I felt. I wanted to repay that feeling. It was a moment when I realized that the power to make students sit at desks isn't nagging to 'study' but heartfelt encouragement and love."

-Did your grades improve easily?
"During winter break of second year, thanks to efforts going around hagwons, my first mock test score in third year improved by 100 points. From 220 to 320 points out of 400. I received 15 types of hagwon education including hagwons and private tutoring throughout the break."

-Did your parents have high educational enthusiasm?
"My mother had a longing for Seoul National University. She said that seeing the son of a family she briefly stayed with get accepted to Seoul National University made her think, 'If I have a son later, I should send him to Seoul National University.' In fifth grade elementary school, I first received tutoring from a Seoul National University student."

-Did hagwon education help?
"Looking only at results, it failed. My first mock test score in third year remained my CSAT score. Since I had started preparing for CSAT in earnest from winter of second year, I had regrets. I knelt before my mother and asked for one more chance. When repeating, I attended hagwons even more diligently than in third year. But a year later, results weren't much different. I couldn't surpass the top 20% threshold."

-What did you think was the problem?
"The problem was attending hagwons and receiving private tutoring. I only attended hagwons and only received private tutoring. There was no process of self-directed learning to make that knowledge my own after taking classes. Now there's high interest in self-directed learning, but 15 years ago, that concept didn't exist. I desperately realized the importance of self-directed learning while repeating for the third time. This was my life's third turning point."

-Was this the motivation for starting the learning consulting business?
"That's right. When I studied alone while repeating for the third time, my CSAT scores were in the top 0.6% nationally. I was accepted to Seoul National University and fulfilled my mother's wish. After that, I wanted to help students who waste time like I did. Hagwon education can be effective when there are subjects or chapters you can't understand through school classes alone. But students attending hagwons without knowing what they lack is a waste of time. Also, mistaking attending hagwons as 'studying' is a problem. This is where the biggest difference between students who study well and those who don't emerges. Excellent students always have time to study alone even when receiving hagwon education, but students with poor grades only attend hagwons. According to one research result, brain waves when taking classes and when studying alone are different. Brain waves when taking classes at school or hagwons are similar to when watching movies. Students who only attend hagwons are just watching learning videos day and night."

-What effective subject-specific study methods would you recommend for mid-to-lower level students?
"For math, you should choose one textbook per subject and solve it at least three times. This means repeating until there's not a single problem you can't solve within one workbook. You can identify which chapters are weak and supplement lacking areas. I recommend trying it once during vacation, even if skeptically. By the time school starts, you'll discover yourself with confidence in math. For English, you should focus on memorizing sentences rather than studying grammar. Open past exam problems or mock tests and memorize just 20-30 passages per day. At first, it's fine to do it while looking at translations. What's important is consistently repeating daily. You can naturally learn sentence structures and vocabulary. In just one month, 600-900 sentences accumulate in your head. If you do this for a year, there won't be problems you can't answer on CSAT. For Korean, using past exam problems is also good. After reading passages, training to summarize content by paragraph can develop not only reading comprehension but also thinking and logical abilities to distinguish correct and incorrect answers on CSAT."

-What would you advise parents?
"I hope that during summer vacation only, you won't nag your children to 'study.' Don't bring up topics related to 'studying' at all. Taking good care of delicious food and asking if there are problems with friend relationships is sufficient. Nagging only provokes rebellious feelings in children. When mothers stop nagging, children realize they must take responsibility for their own lives. I've seen many students sit at desks out of anxiety."

Song Jae-yeol was born in Boseong, South Jeolla Province in 1980, graduated from Seoul Baemyeong High School in 1999, entered Seoul National University's Archaeology and Art History Department in 2001 (dropped out), started study method lectures at SkyEdu in 2003, transferred to Cornell University's Architecture Department in 2006 (currently on leave), established learning consulting company 'Test Master Study Method Research Institute' in 2009, and changed the company name to 'Study Revolution Corps' in 2014. His books include 'Test Master Song Jae-yeol's Right Place Right Time CSAT Secrets' (2004) and 'Rather Have Parents Teach' (2013). ※ In second year of high school, he was 22nd out of 50 students in his class. In third year and when repeating, his CSAT scores were around the top 20%. When repeating for the third time, his CSAT scores were in the top 0.6% nationally, and he was accepted to Seoul National University."

Energetic Mom: And my position was as an undergraduate student. It's not a normal situation at all. Based on the 2015 CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam], among regular high schools in Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] District, Sookmyung Girls' High School had the highest percentage of students scoring within the top 2 grades in CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] (33.2%), and in Seocho District, it was Seomun Girls' High School (15.1%). CEO Lim Seong-ho diagnosed, "Since there are few autonomous schools that girls can attend, the phenomenon of female students flocking to girls' high schools with high academic levels has intensified."

Some public coeducational schools are notorious among parents as schools to avoid. Among 13 regular high schools in Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] District, three public coeducational schools belong to the bottom 5 group with low percentages of students scoring within the top 2 grades in the 2015 CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam]. Lee (46, Nonhyeon-dong), who has a 9th-grade male student, confessed, "Especially C High School, which is a public coeducational school, has terrible student guidance and poor college admission results, so everyone hopes their child won't be assigned there."

What factors divided preferred and avoided schools? Experts point to 'principal leadership.' For regular high schools with fewer resources compared to specialized and autonomous schools to prepare for holistic admissions, they must draw out cooperation and dedication from all school teachers. This is because each teacher must take charge of 2-3 clubs while planning and operating project classes and various in-school competitions.

Min Byeong-gwan, principal of Yangjae High School, argued, "To lead changes in regular high schools, we shouldn't rely only on individual schools' will, but must establish foundations for principals to exercise leadership as managers. We need to guarantee personnel rights to principals and broadly guarantee autonomy to freely organize school budgets and curricula."

By Jeong Hyeon-jin, reporter Jeong.hyeonjin@joongang.co.kr
Photos by Shin In-seob, photographer shinis@joongang.co.kr"

  "translated_text": "_ 30 Minutes Before the Collapse

Sometimes there are days when you crave cup ramen. I wait for steam to come billowing out of the spout of a stainless steel kettle, not water hurriedly boiled in a plastic electric pot. I carefully sprinkle the soup powder into the cup ramen, pour in the water, and wait three minutes while reading the text printed on the lid. Then it's complete—hot and spicy cup ramen that's crude yet seems to contain all the flavors in the world. Ramen, tissue paper, sanitary pads, and cigarettes aren't items that sell particularly well on specific days. About half the customers who come and go from the 'Danggok 24-Hour Convenience Store' where I live with the TV on twenty-four hours buy these predictable items and pay for them. I wait for them while eating cup ramen or reading day-old newspapers. That's my job. Of course, it wasn't the job I dreamed of when I was young...

He too was one of those predictable people buying predictable things. With his sports haircut mixed with a bit of gray and neat, dark eyebrows that left an impression, he would occasionally stop by to buy ramen or cigarettes. Sometimes he would pay for canned coffee and gulp it down right there at the counter before trudging away. It was around the time when August's sweltering heat was beginning to yield to the sleet. He had placed a five-pack of ramen on the counter and was hanging his head. As I scanned the barcode and handed him his change, a lukewarm droplet fell with a 'plop' onto the back of my hand. Thinking it might be rainwater, I casually looked up to see his pupils—like black holes—steadily and vacantly shedding tears without a tremor. I could tell he was crying only because the tears had fallen; otherwise, he wore the same peaceful, bored expression as always. When the transaction was complete, he nodded slightly and left the store. Even after his presence disappeared, a cold aura he had left behind lingered in the cramped convenience store. I completely forgot that my cup ramen was getting soggy as I stared through the glass window plastered with beer advertisements in the direction he had vanished. Through the glass where thick raindrops rolled down like tears, I couldn't find any trace of him. Only the brilliantly lit GS25 convenience store sign across the street caught my eye.

As years pile up and you age, you inevitably get covered by the spider webs of indifference. Curiosity that once shone like jewels would disappear without a trace the moment it got caught in those spider web-like threads of indifference. Smacking my lips, I was picking up the soggy noodles with chopsticks when I saw the family photo on top of the beverage refrigerator and couldn't help but chuckle. The small photo album that could be folded and unfolded like a folding screen contained all the years that had passed. I was thirty-two when I gave up on the civil service exam I had been obsessed with since college. After confirming that my name wasn't on the second-round pass list, I drank all night and returned to my boarding house to throw all my law books in the trash. The end of blind pursuit was emptiness. Thinking of my parents' wrinkled faces—they had expected a judge, prosecutor, or at least a lawyer for a son—I squeezed my eyes shut and wailed, banging my head against the empty bookshelf. The first thing I saw when I woke up was Youngsim, the daughter of the boarding house owner. As she placed a wet towel on my forehead with worried eyes, I grabbed Youngsim's arm and cried bitterly for a long time, and she warmly embraced me as if she understood. That winter, we went ahead with our marriage despite opposition from both families. With both sets of disapproving parents on either side, Youngsim smiled brightly with a two-month-old baby in her belly. And I had to plunge into a war with a new life I had never known before. After working as an insurance salesman, water purifier salesman, and then teaching at various specialized hagwons, my parents, taking pity on me, offered me money as land purchase compensation when we had been married for six years and our son Hwi was five years old. What I established with the money my parents gave me was this Danggok24, a convenience store that wasn't really a convenience store. The business that had been doing reasonably well at first saw its sales cut in half due to real convenience stores that increased along with the growing number of office buildings. The photos that reminded me of such various memories from the past were eventually dominated by Hwi as he grew bigger. The child who always smiled brightly was staring at the camera with a gloomy, cold expression in the last two photos. After it was confirmed that he had contracted acute lymphocytic leukemia—a disease I had never heard of—around the time he was about to enter elementary school, the child always had to be in the hospital. Since no family member had compatible bone marrow, he received a hematopoietic stem cell transplant from a bone marrow bank in Japan. Watching Hwi suffer through the bone marrow transplant, I cried and cried. But all I could do was guard this old, narrow fake convenience store. Only then could I provide some comfort to my son battling for his life moment by moment in the hospital and my wife who was watching over him...

Sniffling, I wiped away the tears that had gathered in my eyes and stirred the chopsticks in the cup ramen broth. Somehow, I had to survive. I stuffed my mouth full of noodles that had gotten so soggy they broke apart. I desperately wanted some cola that would let me burp refreshingly, but I couldn't bring myself to touch it. Taking a sip of lukewarm barley tea I had brought from home, I naturally let out a sigh. When you're alone, all sorts of thoughts come to mind. Sometimes in the personnel announcements in newspapers I occasionally read, I would see the names of friends who had studied with me and passed the civil service exam.

'Those bastards, back then they were always whining to me that they couldn't do it...'

With a bitter smile, I brushed off the past and turned the channel on the television placed on top of the refrigerator. It was a secret from my wife, but I made sure to watch a daily drama featuring an actress who looked remarkably like my first love. The actress who had been struggling in a predictable story of birth secrets and stepmother abuse was in the middle of screaming after learning that the man she liked was actually her half-brother. I was sniffling along with the actress who was quite good at capturing emotions when I got annoyed at the bold letters 'Breaking News' that suddenly appeared at the bottom of the screen. As I was clicking my tongue, I was stunned by the words 'Sehwa Hospital Collapse' that appeared next. Sehwa Hospital was the hospital my child had been transferred to earlier this year. While I sat there unable to close my gaping mouth, the screen changed. The anchor, who had been frowning deeply as if the earphone in his ear was malfunctioning, looked at the screen in confusion as if he had received a cue signal belatedly.

Currently, over a hundred fire trucks and ambulances from nearby fire stations have been dispatched and are conducting rescue operations, but there are successive speculations that many casualties may have occurred due to the sudden nature of the collapse. Let's connect to the scene. Reporter Kim Boseong, please come in.'

The anchor's anxious and urgent voice, so different from his neat appearance, echoed through the convenience store. The screen changed again and was chaos itself. The reporter standing with the collapsed building debris behind him spouted rapid-fire words, but I couldn't hear anything.

'There, in there, my wife and child are in there.'

Thick streams of water sprayed from fire trucks poured down like tears over the collapsed hospital. The wildly shaking camera showed residents who had clearly poured out from nearby apartment complexes. After silently capturing the chaos, the camera returned to the reporter and also captured another person standing to one side.

'Currently, the exact cause of the accident and the scale of damage have not been revealed, but considering that the collapse occurred so instantaneously and there are testimonies that no one escaped immediately after the collapse, we cannot rule out the possibility of casualties exceeding those of the Sampoong Department Store collapse. Let's hear from an eyewitness for a moment. Where were you at the time of the incident?'

'Well, I was diligently shining shoes at the shop in front of that hospital when I suddenly heard something like thunder. Since it was a clear sky, I wondered what kind of lightning it could be and poked my head out, and that hospital just came crashing down. This is the first time in my life I've seen such a thing.'

The bald middle-aged man in his fifties was speaking enthusiastically, spitting as he talked. The reporter pulled the microphone back and asked again.

'Didn't you notice any strange signs just before the hospital collapsed? For example, strange sounds coming from the building?'

'What?'

At the reporter's surprised question, the bald man spoke again with a face full of conviction.

'It was a pretty little girl, about seven years old. She was flying around like a butterfly over that collapsed hospital.'

'No, not that kind of thing. I mean signs like cracks appearing in the building or the ground sinking. Other witnesses say there was a loud sound from the hospital direction about an hour ago.'

At the clearly flustered reporter's words, the bald man got angry.

'Those Samhwa apartment people are all liars whenever they open their mouths. This Bae Daesik has been polishing shoes right here for exactly thirty years. Thirty years...' The reporter, startled by the bald man's rambling, hurriedly said thank you and withdrew the microphone. An arm from outside the camera frame grabbed and pulled the bald man. Shaking off the arm trying to drag him away, the man shouted at the screen.

'Why are you doing this! I definitely saw it with my own eyes, a young girl flying around over the collapsed hospital. Grinning, she was. It was definitely a nine-tailed fox. When I was young, my grandmother used to say...'

The reporter, unable to stand it any longer, pushed the bald man out of the frame. The man disappeared outside with a death cry, his arm flailing once or twice at the edge of the screen before vanishing. I had been quietly watching this ridiculous scene unfold in the small rectangular space when I suddenly jumped up. The belated thought struck me that my beloved wife and son were trapped under the debris of that massive building. Without even turning off the television, I pulled down the shutter and rushed out of the store. I ran frantically toward the main road. The rainy streets were quiet, but no empty taxis were in sight. As I ran blindly toward Sehwa Hospital, looking back to see if any empty taxis were coming, I eventually got into a taxi stopped at a traffic light.

'Sehwa Hospital!'

Ignoring the taxi driver's grumbling about the seat getting wet, I clasped my hands tightly and prayed. Although I had only gone to church a few times since my son got sick, my head filled with desperate calls to God was full of nothing but regret. I remembered how I had casually agreed when my wife suddenly suggested moving our son to Sehwa Hospital early this year. My wife had rambled about various things, but I was having a headache because the building owner had suddenly demanded a rent increase, so I just nodded absently.

'Please, God.' Traffic control began from the intersection where Sehwa Hospital could be seen in the distance. Police in blue raincoats and vinyl-covered caps ran between cars waving red warning lights, and the long line of stopped cars expressed their frustration by honking their horns. Before the taxi driver could finish saying we couldn't go any further, I jumped out of the taxi and started running between the vehicles. Steam rising from the heated car hoods flowed backward toward the sky through the rain. After passing the major intersection, the congestion became even worse. The narrow uphill road leading to the hospital was packed so tightly with ambulances, fire trucks, and even broadcasting station vehicles that there wasn't room to stick a needle through, and reporters wearing construction site hard hats were running around with large cameras. Since everyone was busy with their own tasks, the uphill road wasn't too difficult to pass, but the large iron gate of the hospital was already being controlled by police. Riot police with new riot helmets and shields had almost occupied the wide-open iron gate, blocking people. In front of the riot police, people who appeared to be families of patients who had been in the hospital surged like waves. The people who had been quiet for a moment began crying out again, starting with someone's shout. I too joined those people, constantly looking for my son, my wife. The combination of emotions brought rapid amplification. The wave of people gradually pressed forward. The blue shields struggled to hold against the wave of people. Sensing that the opposition was gradually crumbling, people shouted 'heave-ho, heave-ho' as they pushed forward, and reporters around held up huge cameras and greedily pressed their shutters. I had no idea how to find my wife and child among all that debris, but I was thinking only of rescuing my family with my own hands, even if it meant scraping away the debris with my bare hands.

The rain-soaked alley had only one cat licking its front paw, seemingly completely uninterested in the commotion outside. On one side, people who hadn't yet received raincoats were receiving them from a man standing in front of the furniture store. The hope that I might be able to get inside by joining them led me forward. The vinyl raincoats made rustling sounds with the slightest movement. I cautiously approached those who were all turning their backs to me and asked hesitantly.

'Excuse me, if you have any spare raincoats, could I get one?' Instead of an answer, what came back were cold, suspicious stares. The intimidating gazes from people of various genders and ages made it hard to breathe, but thoughts of my family gave me courage I didn't have.

'My family is also in there. If you just let me in, I'll do whatever you tell me to do.'

'This isn't a place just anyone can join.'

A big man who suddenly emerged from among the hesitating people said this. He looked like a gangster at first glance, but the tension that had reached its peak swallowed even fear.

'Then just give me one of those raincoats. I have to get in there somehow.'

'You seem to have ear holes, so why can't you understand? I told you this isn't a place for you to join.'

The other party, pointing one finger straight up, poked my chest repeatedly while spitting out words mixed with profanity. Wiping away the rain that clung to my face like sweat, I too pushed back against the other party's chest without backing down.

'I told you my family is in there. Is this how people who gathered to rescue lives should talk?'

'Well, this is...'

A cracking sound came from the neck of the man who turned his neck once with an incredulous expression. What stopped this man was another man.

'Samsik. Stop it.'

'Ah, hyung-nim too...'

The man who had briefly swept his short hair hidden under the raincoat with his palm withdrew his dissatisfied expression. With the man's threat gone and the scattered people's entangled gazes received once more, the dry awkwardness ended when the man who had been distributing raincoats in front of the Hanssem furniture store approached. I was about to make another request when I was startled to see the other party's face.

'Wait, aren't you...?'

'If you have a cigarette, let's share a smoke.'

At the other party's unexpected words, I rummaged through my pockets. The cigarettes I had quit when my son was hospitalized had come back to life since this spring. A cigarette pack with just two cigarettes left came out of my pocket. When I held out the slightly rain-dampened pack, the man shook his head.

'Not now, after we go in and come back out.'

And then he handed me a sky-blue raincoat rolled up in one hand.

'Look here. If we let such riffraff join our team, it'll become a complete mess.'

Although I heard dissatisfied words from behind me, the man replied with a bright expression. 'Gilsu-ssi. Mr. Na Jeonghyeon isn't riffraff; he was originally supposed to join our rescue team. The man who checked the time by shaking his wrist shouted toward the sky-blue raincoats scattered here and there in the alley.

'Everyone, attention! It's now 4:40. We'll now infiltrate the hospital disguised as a civilian rescue organization as planned. I'll be at the front with the priest. If anyone asks, just say you're a member of the Korea Life Rescue Association. If there's a problem at the main gate and you can't get in, go to the office building I mentioned earlier and wait, and if you do get inside but get separated from others, just come alone to the lobby of the Clinical Research Center behind the main building. Any questions?'

The people in sky-blue raincoats who had gathered in front of the man glanced at each other with heavy, complex expressions. A young man with glasses in the back raised his hand high.

'How do we get from the lobby to that place?'

'The original passage must have collapsed, but there are several emergency passages prepared for that. We'll use one that's in good condition to enter.'

'What about after we go down there? Are we directly rescuing our families?' A slightly older man among the middle-aged couples who were holding hands and trembling in one corner asked.

'That's...'

The man with a troubled expression turned his eyes to another man standing right below him. The other man who received his gaze pulled back his hood and turned to the people. I saw the Roman collar around the neck of that gaunt man with venomous eyes. Adding the quiet words 'priest' from people nearby, he was probably a Catholic priest. The priest spoke in a voice that carried a different kind of uprightness from the previous man.

'You will have to meet the creatures that your greed and avarice created down there.'

'When you were sweet-talking us into signing, that was one thing, but what's the point of saying such things now.'

The owner of the voice full of discomfort, who stood right in front of the priest, was a young woman with her hair tied tightly back. As other people seemed to agree with the woman's words and nodded, the atmosphere became as cold as the rain.

'How many of you joined this affair with pure hearts? Didn't you gather here to prevent what will happen when they return?'

I couldn't understand what the priest was saying, but I decided to listen quietly for now. The priest's passionate speech grew hotter.

'We didn't gather here to achieve something noble. We gathered to hide ugly truths, and everyone knows this while pretending to worry about their families.'

'Is that bastard really a priest?'

The grumbling from the man who had poked my chest with his finger earlier was immediately buried by the sharp voice of another woman who popped out.

'No. This is all God's will. God, who bore all the sins of the world, has given us a signal toward a new world. We must all pray. We must abandon false and corrupt false religion to follow the true will. Let's all pray.'

The woman wearing round glasses without frames tightly grasped what appeared to be her husband's hand and offered a prayer.

'They're all doing various things.' Someone's grumbling couldn't overcome the words pouring out rapidly like a rapper from a young couple. The atmosphere was chaotic enough that they seemed ready to scatter at any moment, but no one left their spot.

'Stop it and let's get moving. If we stay gathered here like this and catch other people's attention, it could become troublesome.'

It was that voice that had mentioned making a mess earlier. Although the eyes hidden by the hood weren't visible, judging by the appropriately fleshed chin and slightly upturned lips, he felt like a man in his mid-thirties who hadn't yet had his vitality stolen by time.

'Understood. Please all put on the name tags I distributed earlier and follow me.' The man who had stepped down from in front of the Hanssem furniture store put on his name tag. The name tag, coated to the size of a palm, had 'Cha Jaekyung' written on it.

He has published history books including 'Lovers, the lovers', 'Goddesses of Revolution', 'Famous Detectives of Joseon', 'Joseon War Live Coverage', 'Goryeo War Live Coverage', 'Joseon Occupation Records', 'Joseon People Records'.   "translated_title": "[Life and Culture] A Movie Worth Savoring",
  "translated_text": "On the night when thirty-year-old hagwon instructor 'Kim Jung-eun' felt uncontrollable romantic feelings for her seventeen-year-old student who resembled her first love, she lay languidly 'floating' on her live-in boyfriend's bed and said this: "I want to sleep with that kid." Her boyfriend's reaction to this shocking confession was even more refreshing. With a smile playing on his lips, keeping his eyes on the monitor, he casually said, "In case you forgot, you're now at an age where you should be taking vitamins or health supplements."

From that exact moment, my heart began racing. This is an impossible relationship in this world. A gentle, peaceful romantic relationship that could accept even the passion burning for someone other than themselves—this is an absurd fantasy. But just as my heart beat uncontrollably when our Don Quixote, armed with worn armor and weapons, set out 'to dare to dream the impossible dream, to dare to love the impossible love, and to dare to go where even brave people haven't gone,' my heart pounded again before that impossible relationship.

For a long time after, I thought about the two people in 'Love Tooth.' The director doesn't explain what twists and turns led their cohabitation to reach that level (or state). They don't even tell us what kind of work the ideally portrayed live-in boyfriend does, or with what feelings he observes his girlfriend's new romance. We only learn that they were high school classmates and that the man has been divorced once.

Instead of this 'unkind' director, I often imagine the history of these two people that the movie doesn't show. For convenience, let's call the woman J and the man Y.

Since they're thirty years old, J and Y would have each experienced the romantic, passionate ecstasy of love where dopamine and adrenaline are secreted at will at least once or twice. But if there was a difference, it would be that riding the wave of their respectively most intense love emotions, Y got married and J moved in with someone. And like other people, they too witnessed how that emotion called love withers with time or intimacy. But what made them unable to live like other people was that they were the type who believed more in romance novels like Tolstoy's 'Anna Karenina' or Boris Pasternak's 'Doctor Zhivago' than Jung Yi-hyun's 'Romantic Love and Society.' Eventually Y gets divorced and J leaves her live-in boyfriend. And as a man and woman who don't believe in marriage or cohabitation premised on marriage, they live alone for a while. Then J and Y, who meet again through the gods' mischief, drink late into the night, saying that whether it's marriage or cohabitation premised on marriage, they're the same in that they monopolize love and constrain people.

That's as far as it goes. So please don't ask whether they came to cohabitate as simple roommates or whether they came to live as lovers who occasionally share a bed. I'd like to leave the rest to the two people's 'secret.' Life without 'secrets' is bound to become miserable.

◆Biography=Feature team director at licensed fashion magazine 'BAZAAR,' author of 'Beautiful Monster' and 'Kim Hoon is Kim Hoon and Psy is Psy'
Kim Kyung, Columnist"
