  "translated_title": "People the Editor Met (6) How Are Century-Old Companies Created? "Make Your Employees Ask Questions"",
  "translated_text": "Professor Paul Kim (46) is the Associate Dean of Stanford University's Graduate School of Education. Born in Incheon, he moved to the United States after finishing high school and received his education in educational psychology and technology education from the University of Southern California in 1999. From 1996 to 2000, he served as CTO of the University of Phoenix, America's largest online university, where he developed innovative educational environments and operating systems such as virtual classrooms and simulation systems. After joining Stanford University in 2001, he has developed and operated various courses related to educational technology.

Professor Paul Kim is particularly an outstanding talent who contributes to improving educational accessibility and equity by traveling between developed and developing countries. He practices 'education without borders' by personally traversing various parts of the globe and undertakes educational policy projects and consulting in various countries in the Middle East, South America, and Asia. His SMILE (Stanford Mobile Inquiry-based Learning Environment) project was selected as a UN Future Education Innovation Technology in 2016. Rich in ideas in both education and business management, he is an excellent CTO who promotes entrepreneurship and supports startups as a global figure. He can be called a rising management guru sufficient to inspire domestic entrepreneurs pursuing innovation. This is why Forbes interviewed him.

I understand you're an educational technologist and CTO. What kind of work do you mainly do?
I'm an educational technologist who develops experimental educational programs or systems, applies the developed programs and models to educational sites worldwide, analyzes their pros and cons, organizes them, and publishes them as papers. I'm also an entrepreneur working in the education industry myself. Currently, the educational technology industry is such a hot market that $3 billion [approximately $3 billion USD] has been invested in education technology-related industries in the United States. Major global publishing companies in America are rapidly transforming into digital companies by acquiring and merging educational technology-related companies through M&A. Coaching and consulting for them is also part of what I do. I also give advice to students preparing to start education technology-related businesses.

Professor Paul Kim is a pioneer in educational technology who developed an online education system that could accommodate 500,000 simultaneous users for study as early as the 1990s. He said he's currently creating programs for leadership training of knowledge education-related companies regarding lifelong education for corporations.

What kind of lectures do you give for companies?
Mostly online lectures. I lecture on leadership or lifelong education-related content by creating databases of interviews with many companies and CEOs. I'm also innovating lecture methods. Harvard Business School uses PDF files, Stanford Business School mainly uses multimedia for lectures, but I'm preparing to create lectures where you can directly simulate like playing games. If what Harvard Business created is version 1 and what Stanford created is version 2, what I'm doing is version 3.

What should be done for century-old, sustainable companies?
In this era of the Fourth Industrial Revolution, employees must continuously update and renew their abilities. Only then can companies survive. Now is not a world where you can succeed by being good at just one thing. Already, survey data from 2009-2012 showed that companies could survive only when each employee acquired five or more skills (abilities). Now that level is nowhere near enough. One person must have 15 or more skills to survive. When current elementary school students get jobs 10-15 years from now, 65% of currently existing jobs will be gone. The competencies companies will require then will be completely different from now.

Regarding corporate lifelong education systems these days, the educational business becoming an issue is the MOOC (Massive Open Online Course) system, an online open course platform. If you enter there, you can watch lectures from famous universities like Harvard, MIT, and Stanford for free. Companies like Coursera, edX, and Udacity are such companies. My two daughters also go online to Stanford to attend lectures. Starting in America, MOOC companies supporting each country's language have emerged in Germany, Japan, China, Spain, etc. I understand K-MOOC is also being attempted in Korea.

It sounds like you're saying companies must become learning centers for their employees in order to survive.
That's right. For companies to survive, lifelong education for employees is essential. Corporate-led lifelong education is possible through online education companies, not offline. As a CTO, I'm helping companies in that field. There's an online education company called UDEMY in America. Along with Linda.com, PluralSight, and Treehouse, it's a company representing the paid MOOC market. It's an online practical university for working people, where for just $40 [approximately $40 USD], working people can apply for and take any education they need. UDEMY's slogan is 'Anyone can learn anything.' In the future, companies will contract with such education companies and take responsibility for employee education. It's unlimited educational refills for employees. (Laughs) Of course, companies must bear the education costs. Only such companies will survive in the future and become century-old companies. If companies become permeated with the idea of just staying safe and going on as now, entrepreneurship disappears.

How can we revitalize the declining entrepreneurial spirit?
All change comes from cultural change. Companies must also lead by example starting with the CEO. To put it somewhat roughly, cultural differences create innovation differences. MOOC is the same. Rather than just telling people to do MOOC, you must create time and an atmosphere where employees can study online without worrying about others' reactions. For companies to grow quickly and always remain in innovation mode, there must be a culture where employees can engage in self-development. Facebook and Google encourage employees to use 10% of their daily time for self-development, hobbies, or volunteer activities. Stanford, where I work, is the same. Stanford's competitiveness is diversity. Whether Nepalese or Bangladeshi, capable professors become presidents and deans. It's purely merit-based regardless of race, gender, or nationality.

Korea isn't at that stage yet.
Of course I know. In Korea, you have to be a Seoul National University graduate to become a Seoul National University professor, become an associate dean, and rise to dean positions. But this kind of culture doesn't help the continuous development of ideas at all. New ideas from outside must come in to serve as catalysts that accelerate innovation. What kind of culture the field I live in has is very important. In America, whoever chairs that day's meeting sits in the center of the conference room. If you're not chairing, the team leader must sit at the very end. Companies and countries are the same. In other words, companies where you can't tell who's the team leader and who's the employee are innovation companies now. That's Silicon Valley's culture, Stanford's culture. Professors sit at the very end and coach. It's helping experts demonstrate more expertise. Innovation cannot succeed in a culture like ours where people open notebooks and say 'just tell us what to do' while being busy writing down what's said.

Professor Paul Kim recently published 'The Future of Education: Coaching, Not Teaching.' It's a book organizing conversations with literary critic Ham Don-gyun, HK Research Professor at Korea University's Institute for Korean Culture. The gist is that what teachers should do is not teaching knowledge but becoming coaches who point out important contexts and help and guide students by properly understanding their limitations and potential. His argument is that if teachers focus only on teaching without doing this, children lose opportunities to think and ask questions. According to him, Korean students and American students, especially Stanford students, have completely different learning attitudes. Most Korean students are passive and don't ask questions well. They mainly ask 'how to get a job well' or 'what to do to get a job at Samsung.' In contrast, Stanford students mainly ask 'I want to create a company bigger than Samsung, how should I do it?' His argument is that such cultural differences acquired from school lead to innovation differences when they get jobs and work at companies.

What is Stanford University's competitiveness?
A questioning culture. Companies that don't ask questions cannot grow. New services and new businesses are born in companies that ask questions. In Silicon Valley, the issue of sustainability is ultimately an issue of innovation. If you don't always ask questions, you're instantly eliminated. Look at Airbnb's case. They were told to come to Silicon Valley for a conference, but it was so difficult to book hotels. And expensive too. Ordinary people would have said 'that's how it is, I'll have to pay more.' But the person who created Airbnb asked whether hotels are really the main option. Are there no other accommodation options? What new options could emerge in this environment? After asking themselves this and pitching a tent in the backyard for $20 [approximately $20 USD] per night, someone appeared to contract. They said for $20 [approximately $20 USD], a tent is fine and sharing a bathroom is okay. By continuing to ask questions like this, Airbnb was born. Is this business legally possible? Is the business model truly appropriate? Is it an appropriate solution for trends? Because they continued asking questions, a company was born and currently has 150 million users. Again, innovative ideas absolutely never come out without asking questions.

Uber is also such a case.
That's right. There are various options like taxis or rental cars, but are these really the most appropriate options? They questioned it. They also caught the new sign that millennials don't buy cars. Because they asked appropriate questions at the appropriate time, appropriate solutions came out. Among companies that are now gone, there was a company called Blockbuster that rented videos. You'd go to the store, rent a video, watch it at home and return it, and if you didn't return it by the due date, you'd pay late fees. But when Netflix appeared, they promoted that they would eliminate late fees. Take one video, return it, and then you can watch a new video again. Wouldn't it be possible to watch as many videos as you want, with no late fees, return them when you want to return them, and take other videos too? Netflix was born by repeatedly asking such questions. So Blockbuster, the previous market-dominating company, was naturally bound to be eliminated. In short, Blockbuster was eliminated for not asking questions.

How should media industries or technology-related industries that are having difficulties these days innovate?
Media or technology-related industries have quite fast clock speeds. So they need to ask questions more frequently and often. It can be said that the society we currently live in has changed into one that requires asking many questions. But in such a changed society, the less questions there are or the slower the questioning without asking quickly, the lower the question frequency - that is, the slower the clock speed - the further you get from sustainability and the more you're bound to be eliminated. Whatever industry, you can survive only by knowing what the clock speed is in that industry and always checking the question frequency, quantity of questions, and quality of questions that match it.

'Clock speed' is one of the keywords Professor Paul Kim frequently uses. As he says, it's an era when companies with fast clock speeds succeed. Naver headquarters in Bundang, Gyeonggi Province [a city south of Seoul], reorganizes twice a month. This is because they proceed with work centered on projects. Even if projects fail, they don't hold members responsible and let them return to their original positions. They pursue such frequent changes to continuously create new services through collaboration between various departments due to the characteristics of information technology (IT) that is rapidly converging and combining. According to Professor Paul Kim's theory, Naver is a company with fast clock speed.

In an era where clock speed is emphasized, what kind of leadership should managers demonstrate?
The role of leadership is to create a culture where people can freely ask questions within the organization and confidently share them. Because the person in a position to accommodate such questions is actually the organization's leader. But if managers, leaders, and employees have never studied such culture even at school since childhood? They face a state of leadership absence.

It's the same for countries. Countries where individuals can confidently ask any question without personal loss or threats to survival become sustainable countries pursuing innovation. If countries discourage questions and a culture forms where people can't question national leaders and worry about others' reactions, they cannot develop into countries that can innovate and lead proactive development. Whether schools, companies, or countries, they're all ultimately the same. Living as passive students in passive, rote memorization, non-questioning cultures, then working as passive employees and becoming passive leaders and passive citizens. They become schools in closed wells, companies in wells, countries in wells. Then clock speed slows and they gradually go bankrupt. Therefore, it's important to sustain a culture of questioning at the national level and at the pan-social level. To make them question, parents and teachers must lead children to learn such culture from first grade of elementary school. Only then can that child create such culture when entering companies later.

I heard Korean companies visit you often. I heard there were many cases asking Professor Paul Kim about the next business opportunity...
They do visit me, but actually I don't know the right answers well either. (Laughs) But there's something I always say when such requests come. 'What questions are you asking within your organization?' 'Please gather what questions employees, managers, administrators, and executives are asking.' 'Don't let only top executives ask, but have everyone from the bottom ask all questions, rank those questions, and crowdsource what you think is most important.' These are the advice I give.

No matter how low-level an employee, they'll have plenty to question, and that question could become one that plays a big role in determining the company's survival.

What is the culture of global companies like?
In Google's case, all employees use a system called Dory where they can freely ask questions. Even low-level employees ask freely without worrying about reactions. All employees can evaluate questions. By evaluating each other, the top questions are filtered out - whose questions are more important questions. It's a system where CEOs and other top officials directly and publicly answer questions that rise to the top through employee votes. This way, problems and ideas are quickly shared, sufficiently discussed, and responsible answers can be given. It's a desirable system and corporate culture.

If there's something in Korean culture you think should fundamentally change?
The culture of fearing to try new things. In such organizations, rather than challenge or innovation, they watch other organizations innovate and then think 'let's copy that and try something.' Unfortunately, Korean society has been immersed in such culture since elementary school. The reality Korean companies are experiencing now stems from past wrong education. Again, cultural differences appear as innovation differences. If there's fear, innovation is difficult and change is difficult.

Second, the culture of fearing failure. Venture companies and startups also have different cultures between America and Korea. America values the experience of people who have various failures. They see success potential because there are lessons learned through failure. But in Korea, if you fail once, you become a dropout. You become a credit defaulter who can't get loans. That difference is big. The difference between starting a business anticipating 60 failures and thinking it's over if you fail even once is big. Entrepreneurs and founders cannot innovate if they have fear. Founders must escape fear of failure to think freely. Cognitively, brain activity significantly decreases when there's fear. But the moment they hear 'up to 60 times is okay,' students become free. This is the core of what I'm saying. When you become free, creative thoughts emerge and fear disappears. Because fear was eliminated, Stanford's clock speed is fast. They start businesses quickly, fail quickly, and quickly course-correct to try again. Then success probability becomes much higher. Actually, one female student I helped failed to receive investment for her startup item but received 14 billion won [approximately $10.5 million USD] investment on the 60th try. It's a success story I often tell students.

Professor Paul Kim's argument has basis. According to Lee Min-hwa, Chairman of the Creative Economy Research Institute, who recently wrote 'Korean Youth Entrepreneurship Will is World-Class' in JoongAng Ilbo [a major Korean newspaper], globally, new jobs have been created by ventures, with 4% of venture companies in America creating 60% of jobs. Large corporations contributed to growth but couldn't create jobs, and self-employment contributed to neither growth nor employment. Venture startups are the only alternative that both grows the economy and creates employment. Yet while 20% of American Ivy League university students have entrepreneurship will, only 3% of Korean university students do. This difference is the difference in national innovation capacity and quality jobs, according to Chairman Lee. But when Korean youth were asked differently about entrepreneurship will under the condition of 'not becoming credit defaulters,' the result surprisingly appeared as 20%, the same as America. Korean youth's hidden entrepreneurship will is world-class, but wrongly designed national policies are blocking startups, making youth choose the path of public service.

To cultivate creative employees, how should we change now, immediately?
We must change from passive education to active education. We must create a questioning culture starting from first grade of elementary school immediately. First, 'awakened' parents should practice. Actually, I myself am someone who cultivates questioning culture. For example, I ask students 'As we rapidly change to the IoT era, what competitiveness will Google have and how can it survive?' I also ask 'Talk about the 5 most important questions we should ask Stanford within the next 5 years.' Deans, associate deans, and presidents share and discuss those questions with each other. And they answer important questions. Companies are the same. You must let them present ideas without fear, without risk. And you must give incentives to employees who bring good ideas. You must give performance bonuses, not take from others to give.

What's the best method to increase the speed of innovation within companies?
To maximize corporate capabilities, all executives and employees must share the company's founding philosophy, product philosophy, service philosophy and vision, and direction together. The company's mission and vision must be aligned in a straight line. In terms I use, you must always check whether value perception is aligned. The higher each company's Cohesion Ratio, the higher that company's stability and innovation. Conversely, the lower it is, the less growth and cohesion. If all executives and employees don't have one voice and one vision, that company's growth is bound to be slow. These are things always emphasized in Silicon Valley, at Stanford.

Reporter Na Kwon-il na.kwonil@joongang.co.kr · Photo by photographer Woo Sang-jo"

  "translated_title": "[Lee Taek-hee's Flavor Trail] A chef who brews alcohol, bar snacks at fine dining level … 'Korean Tavern Eolssu' in Seogyo-dong",
  "translated_text": "When you get off work today, the longest ten-day holiday (September 30 - October 9) since the holiday system was introduced in this country will begin. Those who prepared diligently will enjoy a fulfilling vacation, but most ordinary people with empty pockets and no leisure time or mental space will be at a loss for what to do. When outing cars pour out, traffic conditions also become difficult, making it not easy to hit the road recklessly. There's a classy tavern worth entrusting an evening to on a leisurely day, so I'm introducing it for the holiday season. They say the moon that rises two days after Chuseok is the real full moon, so that day might be worth targeting.

October Menu: Neungi [pine mushroom] galbi jjim, Korean beef suyuk, jumbo shrimp jang

'Korean Tavern Eolssu (2nd floor, 136-3 Eoulmadag-ro, Mapo-gu, Seoul / Tel. 02-333-8897)' is located midway on the path from Exit 8 of Hongik University Station to Seogyo Elementary School. It's a premium tavern equipped with generous and luxurious bar snacks that can substitute for meals and 50 types of traditional Korean liquor. There are about 20 bar snacks, with the main items changing slightly each month. The 'October menu' consists of three items: ▷Korean beef shank suyuk [boiled beef] (35,000 won [approximately $27 USD]) served with mature young cabbage spread on the plate bottom and just enough broth ▷Neungi Korean beef galbi jjim [braised short ribs] (40,000 won [approximately $31 USD]) with plenty of pine mushrooms ▷Jumbo shrimp jang + soy sauce egg rice (25,000 won [approximately $19 USD]) with 10 large shrimp soaked in seasoned soy sauce. The steady-seller bar snacks on the regular menu include ▷Bossam (35,000 won [approximately $27 USD]) with 500g of domestic female pork belly boiled and served with anchovy jeotgal [fermented fish sauce] (or cutlassfish intestine jeotgal) ssamjang [dipping sauce], pickled wild garlic, cucumber kimchi, and scallion kimchi ▷30cm (diameter) seasonal seafood vegetable pancake (25,000 won [approximately $19 USD]) ▷Korean beef naengchae [cold beef salad] (30,000 won [approximately $23 USD]) with 150g of grade 1 female beef chuck eye roll cooked and served with chives and chili soy sauce ▷Seasonal grilled fish (30,000 won [approximately $23 USD]) ▷Kimchi jjigae [kimchi stew] (25,000 won [approximately $19 USD]) with 200g of domestic female pork ▷Golbaengi muchim [seasoned sea snails] (25,000 won [approximately $19 USD]) ▷Dried bar snacks (25,000 won [approximately $19 USD]) consisting of beef jerky, dried pollack, and mixed nuts. For alcohol, there are 14 types of distilled liquor, 14 types of cheongju [clear rice wine], and 22 types of takju [cloudy rice wine] supplied from breweries nationwide. They also sell regular soju and beer.

Business hours are 6 PM to 1 AM the next day (2 AM on Fridays and Saturdays), closed on Sundays. During this holiday period, they plan to close on the two Sundays and October 4-5, operating normally for the remaining six days.

I'm a drinker, but when I go to 'Eolssu,' I'm more interested in the bar snacks than the alcohol. Every time I go, I'm curious about what ingredients they used this month and how they created the flavors. This is because the bar snacks are quite different from ordinary taverns. They're not the same old tavern snacks you can see anywhere. 'Cooking' comes out that's made with proper study, good ingredients, and formal preparation, comparable to food from authentic Korean restaurants. That's why I became a regular.

A premium tavern where bar snacks are more anticipated than alcohol

The friendliness of young owner-chef Jo Seong-ju (33) and his generous food hospitality also attract people. When he's not cooking, he brings ordered drinks or bar snacks to the table while explaining various things. Content like the characteristics of the alcohol, how to enjoy the bar snacks deliciously, and choosing alcohol that matches the snacks. The bar snacks are good quality for the price and generous in portion like the chef's build. The '30cm seafood vegetable pancake' clearly shows this. It's not just wide in area. The thickness and the seafood and vegetables inside are generous. The batter is added just enough to keep the ingredients from scattering. It's reminiscent of the thick and large Chicago-style deep dish pizza famous for its thickness and size. But the texture isn't heavy. The outside is crispy and the inside is soft while the taste is light. Tables with several people don't miss this bar snack.

On evenings when it rains or snows, I reflexively think of this place. If I don't have special appointments, I set my way home in that direction. The front building is one story, and Eolssu is located on the second floor. When you open the wide windows like folding doors, the street scenery unfolds refreshingly. Imagine sitting by the window on rainy evenings listening to the sound of rain, or on snowy days following the traces of flying snowflakes, drinking good alcohol with delicious bar snacks. Even when it's not raining or snowing, the night view unfolding outside the window serves as a bar snack.

Korean food and traditional liquor related events and happenings are also frequently held here. First, the 'Delicious Korean Food Imagination (Representative Kwon Yong-guk, CEO of Seoga-ne Sundae-guk, hereinafter Han-mat-sang)' meeting is held monthly. It's a gathering where active Korean cuisine chefs get together to study, build friendships, and share food and drinks. This month, the 23rd meeting was held for over three hours starting at 9:30 PM on the 17th with the theme 'Beopgo-changsin [learning from the old to create the new] Second Story - Rediscovering the Beauty and Value of Korean Cuisine.'

Young Korean chefs' study groups and events too

On the 11th, an event called the 'Bermuda Triangle Cooperative Project,' a collaborative planning by three famous Korean taverns in Seoul, was held. It's an event where three young chefs operating 'Eolssu,' 'Dameun (B1, Building 4, Banpo Shopping Town, 189 Sinbanpo-ro, Seocho-gu, Seoul / Tel. 02-536-7500),' and 'Dudu (3-4 Dongsung 2-gil, Jongno-gu, Seoul / Tel. 010-9119-1884)' gather to serve each other's signature dishes - gochujang jumbo shrimp, mukdeok fermented soybean paste, and grilled pollack roe with seasonal wraps and rice bowls - arranged on one table. The price is surprisingly cheap at 29,900 won [approximately $23 USD]. The triangle refers to connecting Hongdae area-Banpo-Daehangno [university district near Seoul National University]. The event continues on October 5th at 'Dameun' and November 12th at 'Dudu.' When I asked why they hold events when profits must be thin, they said promotion is a bonus, and the purpose is exchange, mutual verification, and idea sharing. They said it's an event to charge momentum for change when they feel their food has stagnated.

On August 30th, there was a pairing tasting of 'Baehyejeong Doga' [a traditional liquor brand] alcohol and 'Eolssu' food. Besides this, events like Christmas Eve Korean dinner courses with Korean traditional liquor, 'Spring Day Cherry Blossom Season Day Drinking' (Sundays) centered on spring vegetable bar snacks, cocktail and bar snack pairings, and tasting new traditional liquors are constantly held on weekends.

I attended both the 'Cooperative Project' and 'Han-mat-sang' events and received drinking tables. The monthly 'Han-mat-sang' proceeds with a 60-90 minute lecture on a set theme followed by sharing traditional liquor and course meals. It's a paid event with membership fees (about 40,000 won [approximately $31 USD]). The meeting starts on Sunday evenings from 9-10 PM. It's a time when active chefs can gather after finishing business. They don't skip studying to break away from the reality of having no time to study due to being overwhelmed by work. The food is prepared by dividing the six-member management team into two groups, alternating every other month. They spend two months pondering like homework to prepare. This month, Group B, led by chef Jo from 'Eolssu,' was in charge.

Discussing Korean cuisine's beopgo-changsin and tasting new foods too

This month's study topic with about 20 people gathered was 'Korean Cuisine's Beopgo-changsin.' Food space director and film food director Kim Min-ji (39) gave the lecture. Representative Kim opened by asking, 'What do you think are the good points of Korean cuisine?' Various answers came out. Spreading out a world map, she said that the things cited as Korean cuisine's advantages exist everywhere on Earth, stating 'There is no originality in food culture by region or ethnicity.' Tension flowed across the faces of those who answered. She summarized the discussion by saying, 'I think the characteristics and value of Korean cuisine are yaksik-dongwon [food as medicine] and yin-yang and five elements.'

Beopgo-changsin (learning from the old to create the new) is a new literary theory advocated by Yeonam Park Ji-won (1737-1805). Professor emeritus Jeong Ok-ja of Seoul National University (late Joseon intellectual history) annotated: 'If you become too obsessed with beopgo [learning from the old], there's a risk of becoming stale, and if you're only inclined toward changsin [creating the new], it becomes dangerous as you lose your foundation. This can be said to be a principle applicable not only to writing but to all worldly affairs.' (『What We Really Need to Know About Our Scholars』 2002. Hyeonam Publishing)

When the lecture ended, course food prepared mainly by Chef Jo came out. Sweet pumpkin porridge topped with dried cranberries and dried fruits, spicy seasonal mixed vegetables with burdock root, young cabbage, spinach, cucumber, carrot, and onion mixed with chili oil, and fried back ribs followed. The fried back ribs was a menu considering the day's study theme of beopgo-changsin. Pork ribs were marinated in seasoning, coated in batter with rice grains stuck to one side and fried, then served on a plate mixed with cooked chestnuts and ginkgo nuts. They said it was a Korean interpretation of back ribs cooking. The sauce was a dip sauce made with sour cream enhanced with crab and shrimp flavors and mixed with cheese and tomato.

Next came North Korean-style hangover soup. It was a soup dish boiled with white-leg shrimp, shiitake (very little), shiitake mushrooms, two types of oyster mushrooms, and bottle gourd in seafood broth. They replaced the originally used beef with shrimp. The seasoning sauce was made by mixing and marinating salted shrimp, red pepper powder, and cheongyang peppers. The soup initially had a refreshing taste, but became very sharp after adding the seasoning sauce. For the croaker gulbi jjim [steamed croaker], they poured matcha broth sparingly to remove the fishy smell and steamed it topped with roughly chopped wild sesame leaves from the ends of autumn perilla stems.

Finally, radish rice and dandelion jang came out. It's rice cooked by mixing soaked rice with cooked shredded radish. Radish rice is difficult to get the water ratio right, and the rice was mushy that day. The bibim soy sauce was fragrant with chopped dandelion leaves and chives mixed in. For dessert, there was omija [five-flavor berry] syrup applied from sujeonggwa [traditional cinnamon punch] and assorted seasonal fruits. It was a cool taste with sweet, sour, and cinnamon flavors harmoniously blended by soaking seasonal fruits - Korean melon, melon, grapes, and figs - in a cup containing juice made by mixing water boiled with cinnamon, omija syrup, and lime (or lemon) juice.

Solidly built industry foundation in 3 years and 3 months

'Eolssu,' which opened in 2014, has just passed 3 years and 3 months in business. I've been frequenting it for a little over 2 years. I'm close enough with Chef Jo's mother to be considered quite a regular. But I've never seriously listened to his story. Using the article as an excuse, I met him for lunch on the 23rd. He came out carrying a bag of scallion kimchi as a greeting. That thoughtfulness was lovely. When I left the location choice to him, he picked 'Eulji Myeonok' [a famous naengmyeon restaurant]. It was the second time we had a meal together, and we ate naengmyeon [cold noodles] both times. We ordered bibim naengmyeon [spicy mixed cold noodles] and jeyuk [spiced pork] and mixed them with extra seasoning. While eating, the meat was left over and the noodles weren't enough, so we added extra bibim noodles. We used that as a side dish and drank one bottle each of red-capped soju. For palate cleansing, we also had a bowl each of mul naengmyeon [cold noodle soup]. After finishing the meal, we moved to my office and continued the conversation. We went back to 'Eolssu' to take pictures and drink. After 12 hours and 30 minutes of accompanying and listening to his story, I grasped the storyline.

Although born in Daejeon where his maternal relatives lived, he grew up traveling around the country following his father, who was a soldier. Just the places he remembers include Jindo, Gangwon Province's east coast, Yongin, Suwon, Anyang - about 8-9 regions. For food, Jindo and the east coast come to mind. His mother's family was a wealthy family in Daejeon. His father's hometown is Imcheon-myeon, Buyeo, Chungnam Province. Imcheon, which was the outskirts of Buyeo's Sabiseong [ancient Baekje capital], is a fertile plain area developed along the Geum River about ten li (4-5km) ahead. It was a countryside rich in natural resources, facing Ganggyeong Port where fishing boats from the seas off Gunsan used to come up and unload cargo.

After graduating high school in 2002, he took the CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] three more times but had no connection with university. He told another reporter, 'I found what I wanted to do. I thought there was no need to go. If necessary, I can go later' (Hankyoreh Seoul& 'Places Park Mi-hyang Goes' May 19, 2016). After helping with work at the hagwon he attended, he completed military service as an active reserve from the end of 2004 to December 2006. He was among the first to benefit when service was shortened from 28 months to 24 months. After discharge, he taught students at a hagwon from 2007 to 2009. Around that time, the social issue of celebrities' false academic credentials was ongoing. Issues also arose at the hagwon regarding 'Teacher Jo Seong-ju.' His dream was to become a star instructor, but he concluded it was realistically impossible. It was also a time when his concerns about the mismatch between what he wanted to do and what he was doing deepened. He sought a new path.

Not entirely smooth conclusion of his twenties and starting a business

In 2010, he went to Japan to find his cousin who was a branch manager of a Korean company. He did work helping Korea-Japan connections for about 4 months. He was dissatisfied with working in too rigid a framework. He wanted to do work where rewards came back proportional to effort. When working at the hagwon, compensation came back that way. After returning to Korea, he considered trying business. His maternal uncles were in the restaurant business. Making and supplying convenience store products for 'Jangchung-dong Wangjokbal' [a famous pig's feet restaurant] was one of his uncle's businesses. He thought it would be fine to do such business.

While considering what the right item would be, the makgeolli [traditional rice wine] boom hit. He liked alcohol and was very interested. He looked into whether there were traditional Korean soju and cheongju. Books were rare, but even when available, the contents were varied. Knowing that materials were scarce, he visited breweries. He wandered around for about a year to master craftsmen's workshops and yakju [medicinal liquor]/soju production facilities. He went to almost all of Chungcheong and Jeolla provinces. When he went with difficulty and listened to stories, they hid too much about alcohol, and regarding food, they only emphasized following tradition. In the case of Songhwa Baekil-ju [a traditional liquor], since it's monks' alcohol, they spoke of bland side dishes excluding meat as if it were an iron rule. It was noticeable that they didn't consider the harmony between alcohol and side dishes. He thought that high-proof distilled liquor would go well with meat or rich side dishes. He decided to make side dishes that match alcohol himself. This was the starting point of stepping into the culinary world.

His maternal cousin who ran a tavern in Daejeon moved the business to Seoul in 2012. He came to work there. Initially, he didn't intend to take charge of the kitchen but aimed to learn for his own business. He was told that to know everything, he had to know the kitchen, so he took on kitchen work. Curiosity about alcohol led him to dig deeper, and the center shifted to curiosity about the harmony between alcohol and side dishes. He entered the field directly and picked up a knife without prior education. He literally started headbutting the ground. With only ingredients for making set side dishes, he couldn't try the foods he wanted to make. It was frustrating.

He wanted to handle sashimi. He went to find an academy and attended an intensive 3-day course. While considering attending more lectures, he decided to buy fish with that money and practice instead. That's how he learned. Next, he went to learn Chinese cuisine. He liked Chinese food. He quit work and only attended the academy. It was a 6-month course, but he skipped theory and begged to take only 2 months of practical classes. He liked using the wok and still frequently uses it for Korean cooking. He didn't look for Korean cuisine because most were certification classes. He studied focusing on practical food making. At the end of 2013, he moved to 'Wine Tavern Chacha.' It was a bistro chain advocating wine and Korean food. While helping with food work, he attended wine classes to study.

Food and alcohol study process: zigzagging and crisscrossing

After bouncing around between alcohol and food like a rugby ball for just 2 years, learning through physical confrontation, he opened 'Korean Tavern Eolssu' at the current location on June 26, 2014. His mother Kwon Yeong-sim (60), who dearly loves her only son, found the location and took care of food and operations from the beginning. Following the principle of handling Korean traditional liquor, he selected alcohol that suited his taste. Initially, he set alcohol prices from a consumer's rather than business owner's perspective, selling at ridiculously cheap prices. Nearby businesses greatly disliked it, saying he was dumping.

With so many types of alcohol handled, he had to provide explanations about the liquor. He talked about which region's alcohol it was, how it was brewed, what it tasted like, and what characteristics it had. But customers would often say the taste wasn't like that after trying it. When tasted, it was different from what he knew. The explanation was wrong. Tracing the cause, breweries were often at fault. Quality didn't come out consistently each time alcohol was brewed. It's relatively stable now, but just 3 years ago, there were quite a few breweries that had recently started learning and producing.

He thought he needed to know the alcohol-making process. He went to learn from Park Rok-dam, director of the Korea Traditional Liquor Research Institute. He studied for one month. He quit because his thoughts about alcohol didn't match. He went to find Ryu In-su, director of the Korea Home Brewing Research Institute, to learn again. Later, he also took various classes at the Korea Brewing Research Institute run by Dr. Lee Yun-hee, considered a disciple of the late Chairman Bae Sang-myeon (1924-2013), founder of Kooksundang, and National Tax Service liquor education. Unable to grasp which was real, he tried listening to various classes to make judgments. In the final stage of Director Ryu In-su's home brewing research institute classes, he came to study ancient documents. While taking classes like Joseon Dynasty humanities, he learned that fermented foods like alcohol, vinegar, jang [fermented sauces], and kimchi are all neighbors within one fence. It became an opportunity to enter deeper study.

Brewing 100L monthly for alcohol study... distilled liquor practice too

Then he went to find Han Yeong-seok, director of Suwon's vinegar specialist fermentation research institute. Having cured spinal cord inflammation with fermented vinegar, he researched alcohol that becomes the raw material for vinegar, and while directly treading nuruk [fermentation starter] to brew good alcohol, he's systematizing fermentation. Director Han's teaching was the transmission of living knowledge gained through experience. He came to understand why traditional liquor should go this way. He continues learning while using nuruk from there when brewing alcohol once a month.

From when he first learned alcohol from Teacher Park Rok-dam in 2014, he studied through physical confrontation, saying 'You only know by trying.' He learned while brewing directly, making failure his teacher. For about 2 and a half years, he brewed two types of alcohol monthly using eight 30L jars. From this year, he brews once monthly in a 100L stainless steel container. The alcohol quality clearly improved after taking classes at Han Yeong-seok's fermentation research institute. His thoughts about alcohol seem to have been organized.

During this time, he's tried brewing Seoktan-ju, Baekhwa-ju, Yeonyeop-ju, and Oyang-ju, and also experimented with yellow plum wine, bokbunja wine, aronia wine, yagwan-mun wine, galhwa wine, and herb wines fermented with nuruk. Since brewing alcohol in 100L containers requires 6 months of aging for strained alcohol but there's no suitable place, he's also doing distillation practice these days. He tried making Igang-ju [a traditional distilled liquor]. It's not the traditional method of using soju-gori [traditional distillation equipment] but using a purchased home-use simple distiller. On the day 'Han-mat-sang' was held, he poured about 10mL of Igang-ju into a glass for tasting, and when held in the mouth, it properly produced the feeling of distilled liquor spreading warmly. Previously, he often offered brewed alcohol to customers for tasting, but it's decreased recently. He said since offering brewed alcohol to customers for tasting made alcohol sales poor, he now only shows tastes in small amounts.

When opening 'Eolssu,' he leisurely thought he could just make set items for food. Actually doing it, the more he did, the more there was to touch, and when he thought he knew something, he immediately saw what wasn't right, and walls were everywhere. He went through countless trial and error from cutting frozen meat to properly cutting refrigerated meat. He likes beef jerky and makes it directly to serve as a side dish, but the amount of meat wasted before making it properly was indescribable. 'If I had to start over, I don't think I could do it. Now I know that experience is the best teacher,' he said.

'What are Korean cuisine's characteristics?' - Question receives new eyes opened

Starting with the intention to do what he likes and enduring for 4 years with his body while running down one path, one day in 2015, a bamboo stick flew at his back. Food space director Kim Min-ji asked, 'What are Korean cuisine's characteristics?' He had never thought about it. He couldn't answer. It was shocking. He came to face fundamental questions about what he knew about Korean cuisine. He realized he was very lacking. He eagerly looked for books and whenever he had time, he visited senior chefs to ask. He especially relied heavily on Chef Park Seong-bae, chief researcher at 'Onjium' [a Korean cuisine research institute]. He visited many times. Even now, when something interesting comes up, he takes it there. He seems to go about once every two months.

Shocked then, he accelerated his Korean cuisine studies. He started joining his mother when making jang or kimjang [kimchi-making season] at home. While learning, ultimately most of it would be used at 'Eolssu.' His mother has good cooking skills. She makes jang and kimchi well, and especially has good skills at seasoning food. Her method of explaining soybean paste making is unique: 'When separating jang to mix soybean paste, grind and add barley rice and chili seeds, boil white beans until very soft, mix everything including the water without discarding it, knead and put in a jar for aging, and the soybean paste will ripen to a golden color.' The son is inheriting such details.

In 2015, he also took classes at Uri Jang Academy run by culinary researcher Go Eun-jeong in Jirisan's Gyeonbul-dong and Sempio's jang fermentation class held at year-end. From April to August this year, he studied Korean cuisine at Han Bok-ryeo's Royal Cuisine Research Institute. There are levels from beginner, but with Chef Park Seong-bae's recommendation, he entered the advanced class directly. From July, he's studying traditional aristocratic cuisine weekly with Lee Mal-sun, a disciple of the late Professor Kang In-hee (1919-2001), who was an authority on aristocratic family cuisine, at 'Korean Flavor Research Society.' She teaches only a small number of people at her home, and with many people wanting to learn, he waited as a standby and entered.

Business performance is barely making personal wages

Due to the atmosphere and food influence, customers are mostly office workers in their 40s and above. Young people in their 20s-30s are about 30%. Since Korean cuisine is the keynote, the food is distant from the new generation's taste starting from ingredients. The cuisine Chef Jo pursues is modern Korean cuisine. 'I try to base it on Korean cuisine but not be old-fashioned. Fish jjim doesn't necessarily have to use fish broth. I want to use meat broth or chicken broth to approach from different perspectives and create new flavors. I want to do Korean cuisine where I directly prepare everything from jang to kimchi and all seasonings. I want to become a chef who can control the entire process of Korean cuisine.'

He doesn't operate during the day because he goes out to study alcohol and food. Thanks to studying and working hard, the industry recognizes him quickly compared to his years of operation. He was appointed as a judge for the 2015 Korean Wine Evaluation and won a silver prize in the Munbae-ju [a traditional liquor] category of the Korean Liquor Competition. Last year, he received a gold prize in the individual exhibition category at the Asia Master Chef Competition.

When I asked if he makes some money, he passed the break-even point after one year of opening but barely makes wages. This doesn't count the wages of his parents who help almost daily until late."

  "translated_title": "[Monthly JoongAng] 5 Reasons Why the Government Cannot Control 'Gangnam Housing Prices'",
  "translated_text": "With high demand for residential and educational environments plus real estate investment opportunities, but reduced supply, prices are soaring… Should be resolved through quality housing supply such as creating alternative residential areas to Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] rather than regulations

Although the government has introduced various regulatory measures to stabilize Gangnam apartment prices, locally the scarcity value is only increasing while apartment prices surge. Real estate experts say government policy alone can never control Gangnam housing prices. Why is this the case?

Scene One. On February 2nd last year, at realtor A's office in a shopping complex in Banpo-dong, Seocho-gu, Seoul. When I pulled the door handle, it was locked. As I was about to turn away, an employee peeked out, looked me up and down, and guided me into the office. They apparently mistook me for a Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transport enforcement officer. Banpo-dong was one of the areas with very large apartment price increases over the past year-end period. I asked if there were any apartments around 84.94㎡ (25 pyeong [Korean unit of measurement]) that middle-class families of 3-4 people prefer.

"There are no properties at all. Right now people are anxious, so (homeowners) all say they won't sell." They said homeowners are anxious because they don't know what government policy will be. Among homeowners who put properties on the market and then withdrew them, some say things like "We held out during the Roh Moo-hyun era too, so what... Let's see how long we can hold out." With that kind of confidence, they could be wealthy 'big players' in the industry with financial power rather than homeowners with just one house. According to experts, the floating real estate funds currently in the market exceed 1,000 trillion won [approximately $750 billion USD]. As long as reconstruction apartment investment returns exceed financial sector and stock market investment returns, a considerable portion of these funds will inevitably flow into real estate.

"Even homeowners who put houses up for sale withdraw them when it comes to actually signing contracts (due to greed for money). Asking prices have risen a lot more due to fewer people putting properties on the market than due to traded prices rising." What are the market prices? They said a 26-pyeong apartment built 5 years ago costs 1.75 billion won [approximately $1.3 million USD]. Even then, you have to wait since there are no properties available. Similar-sized older apartments cost 1.7 billion won [approximately $1.27 million USD], while new apartments cost 1.9-2 billion won [approximately $1.42-1.5 million USD]. Ten years ago, an old Korea National Housing Corporation apartment in Banpo-dong cost 700 million won [approximately $525,000 USD]. Even then it was big money. Since then, prices have jumped 2.5 times.

"Aren't there any cheaper lower-floor units?" "Lower floors, upper floors, they're all the same price. If you don't have money, you can't buy a house in Gangnam." This sounded like saying that now not only ordinary citizens but even decent middle-class people can no longer dream of entering Gangnam.

Scene Two. Through an acquaintance who knows the real estate industry well, I found Mr. B who works in real estate brokerage one block away. He's a practical person who shrewdly purchased multiple reconstruction-target apartments over ten years ago. He borrowed names from university seniors, juniors, and acquaintances based on personal relationships, paying hundreds of thousands of won [approximately $750-3,750 USD] per person. The reconstruction apartments he purchased this way now cost 1.8-1.9 billion won [approximately $1.35-1.42 million USD] each. While Mr. B outwardly runs a shabby brokerage office, he's essentially as wealthy as any small-to-medium enterprise president. In fact, it's industry practice for real estate capitalists with financial power like Mr. B to make money.

According to Mr. B, Banpo Korea National Housing Corporation apartments have been and remain attractive investment targets. They're blue chips in the real estate market, so supply is always tight. At Banpo Raemian Prestige, an 84.94㎡ exclusive area unit was recently contracted for 2.3 billion won [approximately $1.72 million USD]. That's over 80 million won [approximately $60,000 USD] per 3.3㎡ (1 pyeong). A year ago, the same size apartment traded for 1.6 billion won [approximately $1.2 million USD]. It rose by a whopping 700 million won [approximately $525,000 USD]. That's more than the price of a decent apartment in Gangbuk [northern Seoul]. Acro River Park, also a reconstructed apartment, traded at 2.29 billion won [approximately $1.72 million USD] for 84㎡ in November last year. This was a 600 million won [approximately $450,000 USD] increase from the previous year. Banpo-dong brokers show these examples in graphs to 'customers' and 'madams' who come from all over the country.

According to Mr. B, even within the same Banpo-dong area, asking prices vary greatly. Banpo Complex 3, a reconstruction-scheduled complex that hasn't selected a construction company yet, is subject to excess profit recovery after reconstruction. Trading prices for 72㎡ exclusive area units only reach 1.8-1.9 billion won [approximately $1.35-1.42 million USD]. In contrast, Banpo Complexes 1, 2, and 4, which finished selecting reconstruction contractors at the end of last year, are apartments not subject to the excess profit recovery system implemented from January this year. An 84㎡ exclusive area unit asks for 3.4-3.5 billion won [approximately $2.55-2.63 million USD]. That's over 100 million won [approximately $75,000 USD] per 3.3㎡. Even so, there are no properties available. It truly makes you gasp at the 'hundreds of millions.'

Why are asking prices so high? Isn't speculative false demand driving housing prices up too much? Mr. B explained it this way:

"Reconstructed new apartments are what people call 'new products' these days. They're smart apartments equipped with cutting-edge features like artificial intelligence. Since they're new products, being expensive is natural. When homeowners set high asking prices, you have to consider that they've calculated additional contributions that association members must pay, 600-800 million won [approximately $450,000-600,000 USD] in burden according to the reconstruction excess profit recovery system, scheduled comprehensive real estate taxes, loan principal and interest burdens, and estimated amounts for future value. When the government pours burden payments onto housing prices, those burden payments ultimately get reflected in market prices. They can't help but be expensive."

When I said "Still, they're too expensive," Mr. B drove the point home as if I didn't know what I was talking about. "These days, Banpo students don't go to Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] (hagwon district). They've created Daechi-dong hagwons within Banpo. The area around S Apartment has now become a hagwon district. They've scouted all the high-paid instructors from Daechi-dong to Banpo-dong. You have to consider the current value of premium residential environment plus educational premium, and future value that enables real estate investment with returns higher than bank interest rates. Gangnam reconstruction apartments are profitable business even when bought expensively." Although the government announced a strong excess profit recovery system, Banpo-dong, where prices had already risen to the limit, seemed unaffected. Rather, it was building higher fortress walls.

The next day, this time I visited Jamsil apartment complexes. Jamsil, which became a forest of buildings through reconstruction projects like Jamsil Park Rio and Jamsil L'S, has literally undergone a complete transformation. Especially after Lotte World Tower was built, it became one of the residential areas most preferred by the middle class. Throughout Jamsil area, many real estate brokerage offices had their doors closed. Even those with doors open uniformly waved their hands saying they had no properties. I found one brokerage office among them. Units with 84.94㎡ exclusive area were trading in the 1.25-1.3 billion won [approximately $937,500-975,000 USD] range. Market prices were lower than Banpo-dong.

While inquiring about market prices and consulting, the brokerage office owner's mobile phone rang. Suddenly lowering his voice, the conversation lengthened. From the mobile phone, sounds of "It can't be less than XX hundred million won..." flowed out. The brokerage office owner said "I understand, madam! I'll confirm when we go to see the house" and hung up the phone.

'Housing price collusion' was suspected. In Gangnam, homeowners sometimes engage in housing price collusion as they worry that rapidly risen housing prices might fall. At the end of last year, an elevator in a reconstruction-planned apartment complex in Songpa-gu had a notice posted by the 'XX Housing Price Protection Campaign Headquarters' saying 'Gangnam is raising housing prices by 100 million won [approximately $75,000 USD] every week through collusion, and our complex has also resolved not to sell houses for less than XX hundred million won.' After resolving housing price collusion at residents' meetings, management office presidents and women's associations sometimes closely cooperate to 'manage' the range of trading prices. When homeowners urgently need to sell and put out bargain properties by lowering selling prices, absurd situations occur where they're urged to withdraw properties citing apartment complex market price declines. There are cases where people receive reprimands from women's association executives for calling out low asking prices. The myth of 'Gangnam invincibility' is not achieved for free.

As a result of on-site reporting, although the government has introduced all sorts of policies to control Gangnam housing prices, Gangnam locally remained unmoved. Armed with abundant liquid funds released into the market, it was building Gangnam's unique solid fortress. To buy Gangnam blue-chip apartments as investments, 1.7-2.2 billion won [approximately $1.27-1.65 million USD] is needed for 84.94㎡ exclusive area. Raising funds through mortgage loans has become unrealistic. To withstand cases where housing prices temporarily fall due to rapid changes in the global economy requires considerable capital, making it difficult to own Gangnam apartments without substantial financial power. Now Gangnam apartments are both housing for the wealthy and real estate investment targets. Entry barriers have become higher, and risk burdens have grown too large for middle-class people to jump in.

Executive K from an economic newspaper who has studied real estate for 20 years said this: "Gangnam housing prices can never be controlled by government policy. This is because Gangnam housing prices aren't determined by Gangnam's demand and supply alone." Let's listen more deeply to his words.

"People who want to buy houses in Gangnam now aren't just Seoul residents. Anyone with some money throughout the country wants to establish roots in Gangnam. Or they want their children to live in Gangnam. That's not all. These days, global companies entering Korea also want Gangnam. Even if they get offices in Gwanghwamun, they want to get houses in Gangnam. With good school districts, convenient transportation, and comfortable living, who wouldn't want Gangnam?"

K's words reflected reality. Gangnam's transportation, education, economic, and cultural infrastructure overwhelms other regions. Combining on-site reporting with several experts' views, five factors were at work in the government's inability to control Gangnam housing prices.

First, market principles. Basically, Gangnam apartments have high demand but insufficient supply. All housing in the Gangnam area totals only about 300,000 units. Demand for these 300,000 units is increasing continuously nationwide. According to real estate experts, Gangnam lacks land to build apartments, so supply must come through reconstruction. But the government regulates reconstruction, actually causing housing prices to soar. That policy is also causing confusion between government departments. When Minister of Land, Infrastructure and Transport Kim Hyun-mi hinted at regulations saying "We'll extend the possible reconstruction period from 30 to 40 years," Deputy Prime Minister Kim Dong-yeon expressed opposition saying "If that happens, it could block even Gangbuk reconstruction." While government policy failed to give market confidence, speculative liquid capital flowed massively into the reconstruction market, only driving up housing prices. Homeowners withdrew properties they had put on the market, naturally raising asking prices. This has been happening since the end of last year.

Some illegal elements also play a role here. It's the intervention of speculative capital. Real estate capital with abundant financial power competes to raise prices. There are also circular transactions. This is when large brokers artificially raise trading prices by buying and selling apartments they own to each other at high prices. This is also why the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transport investigation team has begun strong crackdowns. In the real estate industry, it's common knowledge that if you have financial power, the more you buy and hold, the more money you make. During housing price upswings, how much money you make differs based on how many houses you own. It's a structure where money makes money. However, such speculative capital and circular transactions are partial factors in housing price increases. The government also acknowledges that supply is insufficient compared to demand.

Second, the psychology of owning 'one solid house' for real estate investment purposes has spread nationwide beyond Seoul and the metropolitan area. When the government warned multiple homeowners saying 'Sell by April if it's not a house you live in,' multiple homeowners sold apartments in the metropolitan area and provinces while keeping only Gangnam apartments, further fueling Gangnam demand. The case of Cho Kuk, then Blue House senior secretary for civil affairs, shows this. Secretary Cho owned two properties - S Apartment in Bangbae-dong, Seocho-gu and K Apartment in Jwa-dong, Haeundae-gu, Busan (under his spouse's name) - and sold the Busan K Apartment at the end of last year. The recent market price of the Bangbae-dong 151㎡ exclusive area that Secretary Cho owns is about 1.3 billion won [approximately $975,000 USD]. He kept only 'one solid house.'

The psychology of owning one solid house stimulated the desires of provincial wealthy people, businesspeople, and local influential figures who own or want to own apartments in Gangnam and the Gangnam area. The case of Mr. S met at a real estate brokerage office illustrates this. He retired as a principal in Jeonju, North Jeolla Province, and has two children. His eldest son and daughter-in-law are both doctors. The apartment where the son currently lives is in Seocho-dong, which Mr. S arranged by selling a house in Jeonju he had prepared to give to his son when the son opened practice in Jeonju, adding cash to this. The son and daughter-in-law recently moved to a commercial district in Wirye New Town built in Songpa-gu when the rent for their rented Gangnam hospital clinic rose. Mr. S said "I told my son not to sell the Seocho-dong apartment" and "These days, wealthy people around me often say they need to arrange at least one house in Gangnam for their children."

A recent petition posted on the Blue House public petition board titled 'Minister Kim Hyun-mi, please resign' includes content pointing out "The government seems not to have predicted the phenomenon of ultra-polarization toward 'one solid house' when only multiple homeowners are treated as corruption and whipped." The argument is that the stronger government regulations become, the more severe Gangnam concentration and housing price polarization between Seoul and provinces become.

Third, Gangnam housing prices are linked to hagwons, the greenhouse of hagwon education, and school districts. According to real estate experts, in Korea, college entrance exams and educational issues have an inseparable relationship with Gangnam housing prices, and recently, preference for Gangnam school districts has strengthened further due to changes in government education policy such as abolishing autonomous private schools. Seoul's top-tier universities have been selecting students from autonomous private schools, foreign language schools, and science schools through early admission programs. After early admission programs are completed, mainly CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) high scorers have been accepted. But the situation changed when the Moon Jae-in administration announced plans to abolish autonomous private schools. Daechi-dong, which has prestigious private schools like H High nearby, began drawing attention from parents again.

Originally living in a new town apartment, he moved to Gangnam when his son entered H High. He sold his new town apartment and rented in Daechi-dong. Mr. Y's wife quit her side job to support their son commuting between school and hagwons. The son was accepted to prestigious K University's business administration department after retaking CSAT. Afterwards, Mr. Y and his wife withdrew their Gangnam rental deposit and found an apartment near Hapjeong-dong, Mapo-gu. This is a familiar case of Seoul middle-class parents becoming 'educational nomads.' It's common to send children to hagwon education in Daechi-dong and Mok-dong hagwon districts for middle school even if they attend elementary school near their residential apartments. This is why housing prices around Daechi-dong won't fall unless Seoul creates another Gangnam School District 8.

Fourth, existing residents also don't want to leave Gangnam. Mr. K (61), who lives in Jamwon-dong, is an adjunct professor at a metropolitan area university. The apartment he lives in is about to undergo reconstruction. The trading price exceeds 2 billion won [approximately $1.5 million USD]. From the apartment, Seocho IC and Express Bus Terminal are very close. Gangnam St. Mary's Hospital is nearby, and living convenience facilities like Shinsegae Department Store and JW Marriott Hotel are well established. Having only daughters, he plans to continue living in Gangnam even after his children marry. He has enough spare money to bear additional contributions as an association member. Among his acquaintances, some moved to areas like Yongin Dongbaek District for retirement life but then returned to Gangnam. The reason is that with hospitals and schools concentrated in Seoul, Seoul is more convenient for meeting children. Real estate expert Mr. G said "Moving Gangnam residents to metropolitan areas like Hwaseong and Dongtan by reducing acquisition and transfer taxes could be one way to lower Gangnam housing prices." However, considering residents' Gangnam preference psychology, this method's effectiveness would inevitably be limited.

Gangnam is no longer Seoul's Gangnam. It has already become a global brand beyond the domestic level. The 'one solid house' psychology is accelerating Gangnam concentration, with Seoul's middle class, provincial wealthy people, and even existing Gangnam residents all uniting to make Gangnam an iron fortress. Of course, distrust of government officials plays a part here.

Fifth, critics point out that Seoul City's housing policy has further strengthened Gangnam preference psychology. Democratic Party lawmaker Woo Sang-ho recently mentioned Seoul Mayor Park Won-soon's responsibility regarding causes of Gangnam housing price increases. He pointed out "Last year, reconstruction permits for apartments in Gangnam's 4 districts were issued intensively. Even when approving reconstruction, the Seoul mayor should have issued permits sequentially, divided slowly with intervals." This is the so-called 'Park Won-soon responsibility theory for Gangnam housing prices.'

According to real estate experts, Seoul City's 'Yeongdong-daero Underground Space Complex Development Project' announced last year also influenced Gangnam preference psychology and housing prices. According to the basic plan Seoul City announced in June last year, Seoul City announced it would create a complex transfer center and large-scale underground facilities under Yeongdong-daero between Samseong Station on Line 2 and Bongeunsa Station on Line 9 by 2023. Using the Greater Seoul Area Express Railway (GTX) entering Samseong Station as an opportunity, they will create a 6-basement-level multipurpose space. Above ground, a 105-story massive Hyundai Motor Global Business Center (GBC) and a large plaza from the old Korea Electric Power Corporation site to COEX will be built. This is a large-scale project costing over 1 trillion won [approximately $750 billion USD] with a groundbreaking ceremony scheduled for around May 2019. Gangnam residents mostly welcome the Yeongdong-daero underground development. Banners hang on Gangnam-gu main roads reading "<Congratulations> Yeongdong-daero 'Heaven and Earth Transformation' Level Development Plan Confirmed. Underground: 30 times Jamsil Baseball Stadium size 'Underground City.' Above ground: Large plaza 2.5 times Seoul Plaza size."

Ms. P, a housewife in her 50s living in Yeoksam-dong, said "Many people say Gangnam will become more prosperous when the underground city is developed. They say housing prices will rise further." In fact, a domestic agency for a foreign law firm moved its office to a nearby officetel that will face the Hyundai Motor Global Business Center. They quickly secured a position anticipating Gangnam's expansion potential. In Seoul, which has grown into an international business city, Gangnam is both an office building and high-end residential area preferred by global businesspeople.

So is there no way to control 'Gangnam housing prices'? Experts believe Gangnam housing prices cannot be controlled with temporary policies. They argue that the more the government intervenes, the more the market becomes distorted, only resulting in market price explosions. In fact, housing price polarization between Seoul's expensive and cheap apartments has deepened further as prices centered on Gangnam reconstruction apartments surged over the past year-end period. For this reason, they say the government should not regulate Gangnam reconstruction but leave it to market principles for the time being. Leading Gangnam housing price explosions are new apartments with good residential environments or reconstruction-target apartments scheduled for new construction in a few years. Golden apartments in areas like Dogok-dong that were noisy in the past maintain relatively stable prices after going through several years of adjustment periods.

The logic of increasing supply remains. Instead of suppressing Gangnam housing prices, the argument is to create a 'second Gangnam' or Gangnam alternative areas by supplying farmland around Gangnam, areas not fully utilizing farmland efficiency, or Seoul's Gangbuk regions. Arguments for first presenting measures for Gangnam-Gangbuk balanced development before talking about national balanced development are in the same context. However, supply alone is not a panacea given that Gangnam housing prices continued rising despite the government diligently supplying Gangnam alternatives like Bundang, Pangyo, and Wirye. Political circles believe the government will ultimately have no choice but to use comprehensive real estate tax cards if it becomes obsessed with controlling housing prices. The Democratic Party has decided on imposing 1% comprehensive real estate tax when it exceeds 1.2 billion won [approximately $900,000 USD] for single-house households and 900 million won [approximately $675,000 USD] for multiple homeowners. However, it's unknown whether the ruling government party will implement comprehensive real estate taxes that could worsen public sentiment ahead of elections. Related to this, some urge changes in the binary thinking of some government officials who view multiple homeowners as corruption or social evil. A figure in his 50s with deep experience in Yeouido political circles said "Power has already moved to the market. Unless the Moon Jae-in government is a revolutionary government, it won't be able to beat the (real estate) market."

To achieve the government's desired policy objectives, it must ultimately take the direct approach. The point is to work with experts to create real estate policies that fit actual reality and sophisticated policies targeting actual users, solving supply shortage problems and devising various demand dispersion measures. The forecast is that Gangnam housing prices will be difficult to rise significantly for the time being.

Real estate expert Mr. P from KB Kookmin Bank said "From now on, it will be a money fight, a defense fight. The psychology is similar to not wanting to lose in auctions." The psychological battle has begun between forces trying to maintain Gangnam invincibility and the government trying to control Gangnam housing prices. Can the Moon Jae-in government indeed break the myth of Gangnam invincibility?

Reporter Na Kwon-il, Monthly JoongAng"

  "translated_title": "[Jungang Student Central] Protecting our rights, changing the world... There's so much we can do as children",
  "translated_text": "Dear Jungang Student Central friends, how did you spend yesterday? Did you eat delicious and nutritious food? Did you have fun playing with friends and read books you wanted to read? Did you spend the day without hearing or saying discriminatory or comparative words about other friends? You might wonder why these random questions. Well, they're all related to the rights you have as children. You might ask what rights little kids could possibly have, but around you are peers working to protect children's rights. Let's meet these friends and hear their detailed stories now. Article by Kim Hyeon-jeong, reporter hyeon7@joongang.co.kr, Photos by Lim Ik-soon (Open Studio)・Kim Hyeon-jeong reporter・Children's Rights Self-Guardians・Youth Feminism Group, Illustrations・Materials by Children's Rights Self-Guardians・Children's Report Writing Team, Joint reporting by student reporters Ji Na-hyeon (Yonggang Middle School 1st year, Seoul)・Choi Chi-won (Geulbeot Middle School 1st year, Sejong)

Whether male or female, poor or rich, regardless of country and ethnicity, everyone has the right to live as a human being. This is called human rights. However, the recognition of children and adolescents' human rights hasn't been around for very long. The first attempt to view children and adolescents not as subjects of relief or protection but as subjects with human rights was the UN Declaration of the Rights of the Child announced in 1959. Later, in 1989, the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child was created, which legally recognized children as subjects of rights and guaranteed legally binding children's rights.

South Korea ratified (agreed to) it in 1991, becoming a party to the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. This convention is international law that binds the member countries, and these countries have an obligation to implement it and must report to the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child on how they are protecting children's rights. At this time, not only countries but also NGOs and children submit reports. It's an opportunity to let the world know how well or poorly the government is protecting my rights.

There are many issues related to children's rights that children in South Korea face. UNICEF Korea compared the results of a children's rights survey conducted in 2017 among 17,446 children in 14 UNICEF Child Friendly Cities with results from a survey conducted by UNICEF France. They divided children's rights into six areas: play and leisure, health and hygiene, safety and protection, living environment, education, and participation and citizenship, with the biggest difference in 'participation and citizenship.' While only 18% of Korean children answered that they had 'heard about children's rights,' 60% of French children responded positively. To the question 'I can participate in activities to make my community better,' 6% of Korean children said yes compared to 60% of French children, and to 'Local councilors or mayors in my area ask for my opinions about my life or our community,' 4% of Korean children said yes compared to 46% of French children.

Regarding the survey results, UNICEF Korea's Children's Rights Department stated, "Korean children appear to lack opportunities to develop their opinions through participation according to their developmental stages, and there seems to be insufficient social atmosphere for children to experience having their thoughts reflected in actual decision-making processes." Nevertheless, there are children who stand up to protect their rights. They pointed out problems currently faced by South Korean children through the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child, informing the world whether the country is protecting children's rights well and urging improvement. The report with children's participation will undergo preliminary review in February and be used as main reference material during the South Korean government's main review in September. UNICEF Korea's Children's Rights Department explained, "After the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child meets with the government, recommendations called 'Concluding Observations' are published. While there's no mandatory enforcement, if more people know what the government should do for children, it can add more strength to help the government act on the recommendations."

On November 21, 2018, children held a press conference at the National Assembly Press Center in Yeouido, Yeongdeungpo-gu, Seoul. The protagonists were the child writing team who created the '5th and 6th National Report on the Implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child in South Korea' (hereinafter 'Children's Report'). The writing team consisted of 23 people who wished to participate from the 'Children's Rights Self-Guardians' (hereinafter 'Guardians'), established to enable children to actively express opinions on issues affecting their lives and protect their own rights. A total of 394 children aged 10-18 nationwide participated as Guardians from 2015 to 2017 with help from the International Child Rights Center, UNICEF Korea, and Green Umbrella Children's Foundation.

The writing team compared the three-year Guardian activity report with the 5th and 6th National Reports on the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child submitted to the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child, organizing various cases of children's rights violations.
