Men's cuts for 5,000 won [approximately $4 USD], perms for 30,000 won [approximately $23 USD]... Even working all day, nothing was left over. They moved the shop from in front of Soongsil University to Sangdo-dong, but the situation didn't improve. When paying employee wages became burdensome, the couple decided to emigrate to Australia.

Last year, sitting before a simple ancestral table, the couple choked up. However, their emigration plan never materialized. "We even went to Australia for a preliminary visit, but at the last minute our eldest son, who was in high school, refused to go. That's when the thought suddenly struck me: 'Well, we don't have anything left to lose here...'" First, they reopened the shop after reducing it to half its size (10 pyeong [approximately 360 sq ft]). It was the smallest shop they had ever worked in. They didn't hire any employees either. Their strategy also went in the opposite direction from before. Though the shop was small, they avoided price wars. Instead, they displayed premium perm solutions and hair protection products next to mirrors, explaining to customers what made expensive products good and why they cost more. For differentiation, they also began offering computer-assisted hair loss management services. Mrs. Choi, who had experience working at a skincare clinic, learned hair loss management techniques. Regular customers increased thanks to services rarely seen in neighborhood hair salons. Choi said, "It's still difficult, but we've reached the point where we don't worry about our two sons' hagwon tuition."

Studious People Succeed
# 2 Lee Jun-ho (46), who runs a pufferfish restaurant in Gojan-dong, Ansan, Gyeonggi Province, is a 'studious self-employed person.' Having worked as a researcher at a large corporation for 12 years, he always approaches business with research. When Lee lost his job during the foreign exchange crisis, he used all his savings of 40 million won [approximately $30,000 USD] to open a small sashimi restaurant in Ansan. From that time, he began studying self-employment. Though he learned how to slice fish from a relative in the food business, he keenly felt that his clumsy 'knife skills' had limitations. While running the sashimi restaurant in the evenings, he worked as a kitchen assistant at a famous Japanese restaurant in Seoul during the day to learn cooking.

When he opened a Japanese restaurant in front of the Sihwa Industrial Complex in Siheung, Gyeonggi Province in 2001, he could confidently serve as head chef as well. The initially smooth-running Japanese restaurant fell into difficulty when companies in the industrial complex closed one after another due to the economic downturn. As quiet days without customers continued, he again studied pufferfish cooking on his own. The pufferfish cooking license he had obtained thinking 'it might be useful someday' became a valuable weapon.

Last summer, he gave up the shop in front of the industrial complex and moved downtown to open a pufferfish restaurant. The result was a great success. Lowering the price of pufferfish dishes, which are expensive and not easily accessible, was particularly effective. Like the restaurant's name 'Eight Thousand Pufferfish Restaurant,' he attracted family customers by lowering the price to 8,000 won [approximately $6 USD] per serving. Since pufferfish is a menu item that can't easily be eaten at home, it's an item with steady dining-out demand. His research led to menu diversification. He added high-end menu items using premium ingredients like fresh wild pufferfish, and developed pufferfish and pork belly bulgogi by stir-frying pufferfish with pork belly.

He said, "Whether the restaurant does well or poorly, you can only survive by studying and making changes."

Trial and Error as Precious Experience
# 3 When Kang Myeong-gu (45) started his own business 10 years ago after the small company he worked for collapsed, his dreams were big. He wanted to develop popular dining items and run a franchise business.

However, attempts and failures repeated in succession. He opened a pasta specialty restaurant, Thai restaurant, chicken galbi restaurant, and fried chicken restaurant in turn, but each met with failure after just over a year. Due to lack of experience (poor location selection) and bad luck including the avian flu outbreak, things went wrong. Kang meticulously recorded the causes of his failures. After 10 years of nothing but trial and error, his wife went out to work as a learning materials instructor to support the family's livelihood. The whole family even pleaded with him, "Please stop the restaurant business and look for a job."

In May last year, Kang spent all his remaining startup capital of 30 million won [approximately $23,000 USD] and after two months of preparation opened a beer hall ('BBQ Pork Ribs and Cold Beer') selling Western-style grilled pork ribs in Bundang, Gyeonggi Province. It was his fifth restaurant. He opened it with the feeling that 'this is really the last time.' Perhaps his previous failure experiences gave him strength. Through connections built during his business ventures, he was able to secure pork rib ingredients under favorable conditions. Developing sauces by visiting popular family restaurants was also something that wouldn't have been possible without experience.

Now he's sailing smoothly with daily sales of about 700,000 won [approximately $530 USD]. "It's still insufficient, but I'm just grateful to have succeeded this much," says Kang. However, Kang says his success wasn't like 'a cow walking backward and catching a mouse.' He believes it was possible because of the know-how and connections he built by focusing on the restaurant business. He smiled and said, "If you make good use of trial and error experiences, they ultimately become the foundation for success."

▶ Part 1 Don't just look at people, observe objects and surroundings too! In Part 1, difficult problems in photos with people as subjects often have answers in descriptions of surroundings rather than people. For example, a photo showing people walking with a woodpile visible behind them would have 'There is a pile of wood' as the answer. Even in photos of people observing something through microscopes in laboratories, rather than the prominently visible faces and microscopes, 'She is wearing gloves' might be the answer.

▶ Part 2 Must learn standardized answer expressions Part 2 has expressions that consistently appear as answers. 'I'm not sure' appears as answers more often than 'I don't know.' Other expressions appearing as answers include 'Not that I know of,' 'Not that I'm aware of,' 'I'm not sure,' 'That hasn't been decided yet,' 'Let me check it for you,' 'It's up to you,' 'Either will be fine,' 'Whichever is faster,' 'Neither,' etc.

▶ Part 3 Carefully catch answer clues In Part 3, read questions first, and for 'What are they discussing?' type questions, answers usually appear in the first exchange, while answers to future tense questions like 'What will the man do?' mostly appear at the end of conversations. Also in Parts 3 and 4, when words like but, however, actually, now, plus, except, please, well appear in conversations, answer clues often follow.

▶ Reading Comprehension Must consistently ask 'why' Reading comprehension requires solving plenty of good problems and consistently asking 'why.' Using English-English dictionaries is essential, and reading lots of easy texts to optimize English sense is important. Also, reading comprehension is a time battle. You must practice sufficiently with good problems to read sentences quickly and accurately and solve without burden. Fortunately, Parts 5, 6, and 7 have more connectivity than old TOEIC, making comprehensive learning easier. Reading comprehension's importance will grow further.

▶ Part 5 Part 5 has about 35-40% word form problems finding parts of speech for blanks. Word form problems should be solved quickly by understanding sentence structure without relying on interpretation. Time must be saved here to properly tackle Part 7. About 25% are grammar problems where identifying what grammatical element the problem asks about is key. This requires solving many problems. About 35-40% are vocabulary problems where high scores are impossible by memorizing only dictionary meanings of individual vocabulary when memorizing words. Often, words with identical Korean meanings have only one word suitable for given sentences. English has verbs and objects, adjectives and nouns, verbs and adverbs, verbs and prepositions that always pair together. Vocabulary must be studied as paired chunks.

▶ Part 6 In New TOEIC, Part 6 is an intermediate stage between Parts 5 and 7, with greatly strengthened reading elements. About 5 out of 12 total problems are 'Context Questions' unsolvable by interpreting only sentences with blanks. First try finding answers from sentences with blanks, and when 2 or more answer choices are possible, go back up to read passages and understand context.

▶ Part 7 Part 7's biggest problem is time shortage. Therefore, how quickly you solve Parts 5 and 6 to secure time for Part 7 is crucial. In Part 7, you must abandon the habit of reading questions first then reading passages while solving problems. Those with habits of reading questions first then finding related parts in passages later suffer embarrassing defeats on relatively low-difficulty General Questions and inference problems requiring understanding overall context. When reading comprehension skills are somewhat developed, reading passages first helps save more time.

▶ Part 1 Selective dictation Investing much time and energy studying Part 1, which has 10 questions in New TOEIC, is practically time-wasting. After memorizing previously tested vocabulary and expressions, you need to select and organize only parts you don't hear. The method developed for this is selective dictation. After solving one complete set (10 questions), listen again, skip sentences you hear clearly, and listen once more only to sentences you don't hear well. Then do dictation in notebooks and check corrections against correct answers. Since Part 1 requires momentary concentration, practice listening only once without repeated listening. After practicing one complete set this way, your notebook contains selective dictation materials with only parts inaudible to you. This saves time and catches inaudible parts, killing two birds with one stone.

▶ Part 2 Memorize past problem question-answer patterns entirely What must precede getting over half the points in Part 2 is memorizing patterns of frequently tested problems. Since consistently appearing question types often appear again with slight modifications, you must practice with materials organizing questions and correct answer parts separately, continuing to read aloud until questions flow from your mouth even without looking at materials. Summarizing question cores When memorizing basic problem and answer type patterns, you must simultaneously train to summarize question cores. Since this is a format requiring choosing correct answers from three options, consistent practice converting question cores into brief Korean summaries can be effective. This not only increases accuracy but also allows hearing three options without forgetting what was asked.

▶ Part 3 First dialogue dictation Part 3 combines several Part 2 question-answers with dialogue in between. What test-takers find most difficult in Part 3 is having to solve three problems while listening to one conversation. To solve this efficiently, accurate listening to the first dialogue is very important. Usually, the first dialogue contains clues to the first problem's answer. Also, listening well to the first dialogue increases understanding of subsequent content. Therefore, developing the habit of dictating only first dialogues after solving all problems creates the effect of unconsciously focusing on first dialogues even in test venues. PPS (Paraphrasing Pattern Summary) To quickly select correct answers in Part 3, it's good to train in identifying how answer clues are expressed differently in options. For example, 'reduced price' in passages appearing as 'discount price' in options. After finishing first dialogue dictation, practice reading aloud, then finally find only parts where answer clues are presented differently from passages and organize separately in small notebooks. Organizing these differently expressed parts helps understand paraphrasing mechanisms and leads to quickly selecting correct answers. It also speeds up finding answers in Part 7 (reading comprehension).

▶ Part 4 First four sentences dictation Unlike Parts 2 and 3, Part 4 passages have one person continuing to speak. Such passages mostly mention core content like topics or purposes at the beginning, add detailed content or evidence in the middle, then conclude with finishing content. Therefore, if you can't understand content until the first four sentences, you must guess three problems using only audible words. To prepare for this, after solving problems, first do dictation of the front four sentences in dictation notebooks. Since Part 4 content and flow are considerably standardized, such training develops ability to infer overall content by listening to front parts. It also has the advantage of reducing burden for understanding content while focusing on clue listening.

▶ Tips Test day strategies Most students often intently study reading vocabulary or past expressions until just before tests, hoping to get one more problem right, but on test day mornings, it's better to head to test venues while listening to Part 3 and 4 content you already know well. This provides the advantage of entering test venues while maintaining listening rhythm plus building confidence. Also, just before tests, there's a brief Direction period when many people solve reading problems worrying about time shortage. However, if you're in a situation where you can't solve several problems during Direction, spending that time reviewing Parts 3 or 4 to find sections with long problems and options clustered together and interpreting them once in advance can provide much more help later.

Why does this happen? When I became a cabinet member in 1993, on the first day at a cabinet meeting, I counted how many were from my alma mater and roughly over 50% were. Looking at statistics of minister and vice-minister backgrounds since liberation, during President Rhee Syng-man's time there were many who studied abroad, but from the military regime until today, graduates from one university are overwhelmingly numerous. Korea has nearly 200 universities, but from the public's perspective, there are a small number of universities recognized as 'symbols of success and advancement.' The proportion of so-called SKY universities (Seoul National University, Korea University, Yonsei University) is tremendously high. This reality forces parents to spend much on hagwon education to get their children into these prestigious universities. Currently, the proportion of SKY university graduates is two-thirds. This reality increases hagwon education costs along with educational suffering, ultimately shaking public education. This problem must be resolved.

Ultimately, everything is connected in one line. Which universities oppose the three prohibitions? Mainly a small number of prestigious universities. Universities representing less than 10% of all universities oppose it.

But as I mentioned earlier, a president of Korea's top university once said this: you need good raw materials to make good products. However, there's doubt about how seriously that university considers making the best products.

In short, university education is too lax, inefficient, and uncreative compared to advanced countries. Opposition to the three prohibitions policy stems from prestigious university selfishness. Therefore, rather than criticizing the three prohibitions policy, universities should focus on exit policies to thoroughly educate graduates to become individuals superior to Harvard, Oxford, or Tokyo University graduates.

School records weighting is the same. Good students will naturally go to Seoul National University even without mentioning school records. It's regrettable that Seoul National University, which operates with significantly more national financial support than other universities, presents policies to more efficiently monopolize better students - this appears to be competing for rice bowls with other first-class universities.

- How do you view specialized high schools?

"Specialized high schools were created to nurture excellent talent at the general education level. They should nurture excellent talent at the general education level according to their purpose. They don't exist for prestigious university admissions."

- The expansion of specialized high schools is a contentious issue.

"I think specialized high schools should be expanded. Even in general education, students who excel in specific areas and have aptitude should be nurtured. Students excellent in physics, chemistry, etc., should have broader paths to reach the highest level universities in those fields. That's necessary. But they must remain faithful to the specialized high school spirit. It's problematic when science high school students enter prestigious university law schools or business schools.

However, we must think about cases unrelated to specialized high schools. The issue of whether to give perfect scores to grade 1 and 2 school records - if this stems from prestigious university selfishness, then we should now pay attention to the pain of many students from grade 5 to 9 school records. Shouldn't we think about the wounds they receive in their hearts when hearing such talk?

If there are over 100 non-prestigious universities, wouldn't their alienation also be a problem? That's why it's time for universities, whether prestigious or not, to focus on selecting average or decent students and nurturing them into excellent talent over four university years.

When evaluating universities in the US, they don't look at just college entrance exam scores. The US has thousands of universities. US News & World Report conducts comprehensive evaluations of 220 universities annually. Looking at their evaluation, there are 18 variables. College entrance exam scores are just one of them. University evaluation variables include many things like faculty-student ratios. Prestigious universities have one professor for every 5-6 students. What about us? And how many classes have 20 or fewer students is also a variable. How friends evaluate students, how much alumni donate - these are also important variables. SAT scores aren't like ours where Seoul National University gets 395 out of 400 points, but they present ranges. Out of 1,600 points, Princeton's 75th to 25th percentile is 1,380-1,560 points, Harvard's is 1,400-1,580 points. The distribution of students entering these two universities almost overlaps. Even universities ranking about 10th overall have tremendous overlap (with the top). This means high school seniors don't line up in one line in front of a specific university but form multiple lines from the start.

The authorities' response was this: Harvard is not a school that selects study bugs. Harvard is a university that educates leaders of society and the nation. Our prestigious university presidents should remember this truth. They should nurture leaders who will lead the nation, people, market, and society - what good is it to select study bugs? High college entrance exam scores don't necessarily mean quality raw materials."

The Minister of Education, who will take practical responsibility for implementation, must pursue it while serving the same term as the president. As you know, the Minister of Education changes most frequently among all ministers. Always swayed by political problems, they couldn't focus on educational issues - this was the problem of all past presidents without exception. They probably realized 'oops, too late' only when stepping down. In the past, whenever education became politicized, they tried to resolve issues by immediately replacing ministers.

I served as the first Deputy Prime Minister of Education for exactly one year and one day. During that one year, I wrestled with general education problems and couldn't implement any of the university education reforms I originally planned. When I became the first deputy prime minister in 2001, the media focused criticism on the collapse of Korean public education. They mainly discussed the crisis in general education. Wrestling with those problems... I was regretful that I had to leave just when I was about to seriously address university education problems.

To reform universities, first, we must boldly consolidate the approximately 50 national universities. We should create about 10 regional hub national universities. The government should take complete financial responsibility for hub national universities. The state should take full responsibility for professors' research, salaries, and all facilities.

By concentrating the resources supporting 50 national universities into 10 universities, it can be accomplished. About 10 national universities should become hub universities, but all must be specialized. For example, Seoul National University for natural sciences, humanities, and social sciences that form the foundation of all learning, and other hub universities specialized by field - medicine, agriculture, engineering, marine science, advanced science, etc. Then what phenomenon occurs? From elementary school, if you want to raise your child as a great scientist, you'll try to send them to a specialized university that majors in that field. For instance, if medical school biotechnology is in Gangwon Province [a mountainous province in northeast South Korea], then you send them to Gangwon Province. This way, regarding national universities, students will line up in 10 lines from the start. As long as 600,000 high school graduates line up in one line in front of one university and are selected in hierarchical order, educational suffering cannot be reduced.

What about private universities? Complete autonomy. Whether they conduct independent exams or how they handle school record grades - it's not the government's business to intervene. Then several effects will emerge. Universities that truly lack competitiveness will close their doors themselves. And for specialized national universities, if students whose parents earn below a certain level of 15 million won [approximately $11,500 USD] and have grade 1 school records receive full 4-year scholarships, excellent students will naturally go to national universities even if poor. Then private universities will benchmark national universities. Private universities will benchmark specialized leading universities on their own without government interference.

To implement university education this way, we must establish a university policy administrative committee directly under the president. The Ministry of Education must change to a better form than now. Since the president must directly oversee it, specialized and regionalized national universities must be successfully fostered. Private universities should have complete autonomy, but supervisory functions to prevent private university corruption must exist.

General education should originally be coordinated with local government systems. We must strengthen the power of education superintendents, who are local governments' education officials. Education superintendents should take responsibility and lead. The state just needs to provide necessary financial support. If education superintendents in different regions are exceptional, they could achieve distinctive education. Excellence must be contained within the vessel of equity. Even in that case, specialized university education and specialized high schools should be connected.

Now education is economy, and economy is education. Education is most important

- Has education been a lower priority for past presidents or presidential candidates?

In the analog era, education and economy seemed separate, but in the digital era, education is economy and economy is education. Because it's a knowledge economy era, education directly connects to economy. In a knowledge-based society, how to systematize and politicize exploding information for national development and high-quality life for the people and society... this is tremendously important. Current presidential candidates are working hard, but they still seem to view education as just one sector's problem. Education is everything."

Educational beat reporters always view education as incidents. They view everything from the perspective of incidents... But education is a process. A growth process. Trees grow slowly - trees don't suddenly emerge from grass. The media doesn't seem to seriously recognize education's importance.

Earlier when discussing why educational reform hasn't gone well, I mentioned presidents, but there's also the problem of teachers as educational subjects in educational reform. If we divide educational reform into three types, hardware reform is the expansion of educational facilities. Software reform is innovation in curricula and educational content. Third is humanware - the problem of improving teacher quality. In our country, facility problems are directly connected to finances. It's not a complex problem. It's important, but not unclear or ambiguous. Reform at the humanware level is the problem of improving teacher quality, which is very important. Here, many teachers nowadays refuse evaluation. That's wrong. If they truly value true education, they should be evaluated on whether they're truly teachers providing true education. But teachers refuse evaluation? This could be perceived as meaning that even teachers who cannot provide quality education should be protected and remain in educational settings for a long time. The result of such people being protected differs from the spirit of true education. We must institutionally provide incentives to teachers who sacrifice their time to teach students to enhance creativity and improve cooperative ability and innovative leadership. Only then can creative education and character education be possible at the general education level. This is the teachers' reform responsibility.

Even if the average is 75 points, if they have exceptional qualities in a specific field, applaud and encourage them to become world number one in that field - many such parents should emerge. Don't think about sending them to prestigious universities for success. As I mentioned, if universities become specialized, even without sending children to a small number of prestigious universities, there will be valuable paths to success for children excellent in one or two fields. Now parents must move beyond the level of being proud of doing well on average with average standards. Only then will we get Picasso, Beethoven, and Edison. If Edison were alive now, if Madam Curie existed, what could they do within Korea's educational system?"

"It's all contained in what I said earlier. The current Ministry of Education must be developmentally readjusted. Now educational functions should be strengthened and their structure should be innovated."

With one (YS), I exchanged opinions on various policy issues when he was opposition party leader, and with the other (DJ), we went to prison together and suffered hardships. Candidate unification - when that didn't happen, military authoritarianism was extended as I feared. Later, after YS became president, he didn't ask me to take the Deputy Prime Minister for Unification post from the beginning. (Before YS's inauguration) somehow I came to handle unification issues, and I emphasized sunshine policy then. YS still doesn't like sunshine policy, but at the time he seemed swayed by various staff influences.

President Kim Dae-jung recognized that there should be a department for human resource development. So while expanding the Ministry of Education to the Ministry of Education and Human Resources Development, he asked me to serve as the first Deputy Prime Minister of Education. Actually, the core of human resource development is strengthening university education. But as soon as I took office, all media concentrated attacks on general education under the banner of public education collapse, so responding to that meant I couldn't touch university education at all. There's that regret.

- If you have more to say about educational policy, please share.

"In the 21st century, education is never just one sector's problem. Education isn't one among various sectors. Education is human beings, education is economy, education is peace, education is prosperity. It directly connects to all important socio-structural problems and historical problems. Educational capability is precisely the capability and competitiveness of the nation, people, and market. It's also peace-promoting power. Now we must change our perception of education. Korean educational reform's focus should be on university education. Universities must appropriately and sufficiently nurture creative talent that the market, world, people, and nation truly demand. We should teach relatively freely up to high school and let students do what they want, then in university, educate them so they cannot survive without truly studying. But the media is also a problem in education. I don't understand why there's no interest in exit but only interest in entrance. The future of society and the nation depends on the quality of produced talent.""

Most importantly, peanut allergies among children under five doubled between 1997-2002, among the scary allergies.

"The number has definitely increased in children," said Dr. Hugh Sampson, who conducts pioneering food allergy research at Mount Sinai School of Medicine (New York). "I think it will increase overall in the future."

Allergy specialists say there has been an unprecedented increase in children with complex allergies who show adverse reactions not only to staples from the 1950s like milk and flour, but also to global foods like sesame and kiwi that have since established themselves on American tables. Even egg allergies, which most children naturally recover from as they grow up, seem to last longer than in the past.

Parents with very young children become nervous every time new foods are introduced. They must watch for the first signs of symptoms such as rashes, diarrhea, or vomiting. While deaths from allergies are rare, very sensitive children can have their throats swell and become completely blocked when wrongly exposed to food.

Even if your child doesn't have allergies, you must be careful not to inadvertently cause allergic reactions in your child's friends or classmates. Nowadays, dairy-free birthday cakes are essential, and peanut-free Halloween parties are the same.

What causes the increase in allergy patients? The most interesting theory, nicknamed the "hygiene hypothesis," explains that we have become too clean. The immune system is designed to fight dangerous external invaders like parasites, viruses, and infections. However, clean water, antibiotics, and vaccines have eliminated several harmful challengers.

There's even interesting research suggesting that children born through cesarean sections, which have increased 40% over the past 10 years, have a higher risk of developing allergies. This may be because they were never exposed to healthy bacteria while passing through the mother's birth canal. The theory is that because there are no serious enemies, the immune system instead begins battling harmless things like eggs or wheat.

Almost everyone has had to adapt to the increase in food allergies. Children with allergies carry portable EpiPens containing epinephrine injections to administer in case of severe symptoms. Many schools like Mercer Elementary have designated "peanut-free zones" where allergic students can eat with peace of mind.

The number of states establishing allergy guidelines is also increasing. Thanks to federal law implemented last year, food manufacturers now clearly label the eight most common allergens (milk, fish, etc.) on their food labels. Many airlines serve pretzels instead of peanuts to passengers.

While scientists basically understand the process of allergy outbreak, they can only surrender when faced with the wall of the immune system. It's too complex for scientists to control. There is no cure for food allergies. There are only treatments for some symptoms. The best measure parents and children can take is to avoid the culprit.

However, interesting progress has recently begun to be made in research. Researchers are thinking of radical methods. The idea is to expose people to harmful components in advance to see if it's possible to treat or even prevent food allergy symptoms. In one study, children with peanut allergies were given small amounts of peanut powder to see if immunity developed.

The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases launched a five-year 'Food Allergy Research Consortium' (CoFAR) in 2005 with $17 million [approximately $13 million USD].

In another study supported by this consortium, researchers plan to give adults with peanut allergies small amounts of processed peanut protein to prevent allergic reactions and, if successful, eliminate the problem. In short, developing a peanut allergy vaccine is the ultimate goal. For Sampson, who is researching this, the search for a solution is more urgent than ever. "The situation is urgent," he said.

It's not easy to figure out how childhood pleasures like peanut butter sandwiches, warm chocolate chip cookies, and a cold glass of milk put small bodies into battle mode.

How can just one bite make your throat itchy, lips swell, and stomach suffer painful cramps? How does an immune system elaborately designed to protect us from bacteria and viruses regard healthy nutrients as enemies?

Brothers Brian Berning (13) and Daniel (11), who live in Lake Forest, Illinois, know well how it feels to be attacked like that. When Brian was about 6 months old, his body resisted after taking a sip of milk-based formula. "His lips swelled and his eyes rolled back," said mother Denise.

The list of foods the two boys can't eat includes eggs, tree nuts (including cashews, walnuts, almonds, and hazelnuts), milk, and shellfish or crustaceans. Daniel was diagnosed with allergy-related esophageal disease last March. So he can only eat apples and bacon. Now he absorbs most nutrients through tubes.

"It's really painful when I go to parties. I have to watch my friends eat ice cream cake while saying it's delicious," Daniel said. "When they say 'Daniel, this is really delicious,' I answer 'I can't eat it because of food allergies.'"

Exactly what causes food allergies is unknown. It's clear that genetic combinations (allergies are hereditary) and environment play a role. When a person prone to allergies encounters objects like pollen or peanuts, a series of events begins.

The body recognizes it as a problem and begins a first-stage attack: the production of antibodies called IgE (immunoglobulin E). These molecules attach to mast cells around the lungs, intestines, skin, mouth, nose, and cavities (empty spaces in the body).

When that person next encounters pollen or peanuts, the mast cells prepare for war and release powerful chemicals like histamine. This causes nasty allergic symptoms like sneezing, stomach cramps, itching, nasal congestion, swelling, and hives.

In rare cases, if the reaction against antigens is sudden and violent, the airways can close completely, blood pressure drops, and anaphylaxis (hypersensitivity) symptoms occur. If not immediately treated with hormones (epinephrine) that open airways and enhance heart function, shock death can occur.

As interesting research to discover the causes of allergies progresses, the hygiene hypothesis gains credibility. Research results show that children raised on farms are less likely to develop allergies because they constantly contact soil and animals. Canadian research published in early October also showed that rural children have a lower risk of developing asthma.

Scientists at Duke University studied this phenomenon at the molecular level. They compared the immune systems of wild rodents infected with parasites and diseases with their clean cousins raised in laboratories. Researchers put animal immune cells in petri dishes in an environment that simulates allergic reactions, then administered plant proteins known as immune system stimulants and observed cellular responses.

The results were published last year. The immune response of laboratory rodents was much higher than their wild relatives. The laboratory animals' immune systems worked too hard. The wild animals' blood, which showed little response to stimulation, had high antibody levels. This was evidence that they had already fought much scarier enemies and wouldn't bother with trivial opponents.

"Wild animals are thought not to get allergies," said William Parker, who led the investigation. "They're too busy fighting scary liver parasites to worry about things like pollen." Parker said parasites might eventually help scientists discover treatments.

Research results showed that patients with irritable bowel syndrome sometimes improved their symptoms when exposed to a parasite called pig whipworm. Parker wants to find out if similar controlled exposure might work to "stimulate the immune system in a good direction" for children with allergies. No one has conducted such research yet. However, theoretically it's "very promising," he said.

Every immunologist's dream is to fix the immune system so it can always identify allies and enemies with perfect accuracy. Unfortunately, researchers still lack sufficient knowledge to make that dream a reality. What if we made the immune system less sensitive so children could better accept allergy-triggering foods?

That medical technique, called immunotherapy, has established itself as the standard treatment for seasonal allergies like hay fever. Patients receive allergy shots containing small amounts of the problematic substance (weed or tree pollen) while gradually increasing the amount. This way, the immune system gradually becomes familiar with the antigen.

Researchers experimented with injection immunotherapy for food allergies, but it wasn't safe. Patients could develop hives or other adverse reactions. Scientists led by Duke University doctor Wesley Burks began carefully experimenting with oral immunotherapy rather than needles and started getting good results.

In a small study published in the January issue of the 'Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology,' Burks and Arkansas Children's Hospital doctor Stacy Jones reported that immunotherapy helped calm allergic reactions in children sensitive to eggs.

After taking small amounts of egg powder in increasing quantities for two years, most children were able to eat the equivalent of two eggs without any side effects. A similar study published in the October journal 'Allergy' also showed children developed egg tolerance. However, when powder consumption stopped, the effect also disappeared.

Burks uses the same method with peanuts. He gradually gave children with peanut allergies special powder containing small amounts of peanut protein in increasing amounts. The initial dose was 1/1000th of one peanut. The children slowly adapted to one peanut per day.

Early in the experiment, subject Noah Sheffer (7) immediately vomited after eating just 25mg of peanut protein, equivalent to about 1/12th of one peanut. However, in a food challenge test last May, the boy ate the equivalent of 13 peanuts without any problems.

Burks said these results don't mean Noah can now eat Snickers bars to his heart's content. Absolutely not. However, the newly developed tolerance might protect him if he accidentally takes a bite. Noah's mother Robin Smith said she no longer worries about terrible things happening. "I've completely lost that fear."

Burks' peanut powder is like a predecessor to the peanut vaccine that researchers hope to develop in the future. Burks and Sampson joined forces to develop a substance containing proteins that look like peanuts but are actually made to be less powerful than peanuts, and therefore less likely to trigger allergic reactions in patients. So far, they've successfully tested that preparation on mice. "If it works on humans too, there's hope for blocking allergic reactions," Sampson said.

There are still many mysteries about how allergies start and sometimes why they just disappear. Researchers know that babies with egg or milk allergies and dermatitis are more likely to develop other allergic diseases later as they grow up.

Look at Emily Godwin. Both parents have no food allergies, but Emily developed dermatitis at 3 months old. Five months later, doctors diagnosed food allergies. Now six years old, Emily can't eat eggs, wheat, tree nuts, or grapes.

However, she recently overcame her milk allergy. In fact, many children naturally overcome milk and egg allergies. This is also a mystery that doctors don't understand. Mount Sinai and four other research teams supported by CoFAR are currently recruiting 400 infants with milk or egg allergies.

These infants will be investigated over the next five years to see how many develop peanut allergies and how many naturally cure their milk or egg allergies. The goal of this research is to better understand at the molecular level what causes allergies and what makes them disappear. Eventually, that knowledge could lead to treatments.

The ultimate goal is still to prevent allergies from occurring in the first place. Professor Gideon Lack of King's College London discovered an interesting paradox after studying allergy cases worldwide. Countries like the United States that teach children to avoid peanuts from an early age have seen the greatest increase in peanut allergies. Meanwhile, some Asian and African countries where children eat various peanut products from a very young age had much fewer peanut allergies.

Now Professor Lack is conducting a groundbreaking experiment by gathering more than 200 babies known to have dermatitis or egg allergies but no peanut allergies. One group is given peanut-containing snacks, while the other group is not given peanuts.

Then he plans to observe them until they turn five to see if peanut allergies were prevented before taking root. "I'm thinking of trying to intervene in the first year of life," Lack said. If successful with peanuts, there's room to expand to other foods.

Lack was careful not to make hasty predictions and warned that no one knows whether avoidance or exposure will prove to be the best method. "I don't want to give the impression that feeding peanuts is a safe way to prevent peanut allergies. Because we actually don't know."

If parents try to feed peanuts early at home, there are "risk factors," he said. If this research succeeds, a major shift in medical advice is expected.

For now, parents have no choice but to be extremely careful. "They always feel like they're walking on eggshells," said Representative Nita Lowey, who proposed the federal labeling law. Labels that require clear ingredient disclosure ("milk" instead of the technical term "casein") so general consumers, not scientists, can easily understand are helpful.

Organizations like the Food Allergy & Anaphylaxis Network (FAAN) applauded the measure. The nonprofit citizen group FAAN still worries about hidden threats. Schools sometimes store crayons in empty peanut butter containers. Certain paints contain egg components.

Even if microwave popcorn labels say they contain milk, eggs, and fish, children with allergic symptoms who don't read them carefully are put at risk.

At home, parents manage their children's food. The problem is food safety outside the home. Ann Bullard, who runs Gwynn Valley Camp in Brevard, North Carolina, recalled worry-free days of the past. "Twenty years ago, we put peanut butter out in the dining hall for anyone to eat. Now we can't do that."

Nowadays, even if only 1% of the 1,050 children coming to camp have food allergies, the dining hall uses nut-free products. On evenings when they eat macaroni and cheese, they provide dairy-free alternatives for those who can't eat dairy products.

Allergy response methods vary by school. Julie Forest, who lives in Wyckoff, New Jersey, transferred her seven-year-old son who has peanut and tree nut allergies. This was because she heard from the principal of his previous school that they couldn't guarantee the child's safety.

According to a report published in October, two-thirds of surveyed schools have established allergy emergency plans. However, most measures are "missing basic essential elements" such as emergency contact information or student medical history files. Schools aren't the only ones being lax.

Some restaurant chains try not to use nut products (Burger King occasionally sells nut-containing pies that arrive in sealed containers), but other chains don't pay such attention. Another study published last July showed that even parents with allergic children increasingly ignore labels saying "may contain."

75% of parents say they read labels at supermarkets, compared to 85% in 2003. Now warnings are so common that another problem may have arisen. There are too many labeled foods, making it difficult to know which ones are dangerous.

"Suddenly these words come out: 'Made on equipment used to make peanuts.' Does anyone know what that means?" said Mike Reid, who lives in Houston. His son Andrew (7) can't eat peanuts. "We need uniform standards instead of forty unclear expressions of 'maybe yes, maybe no.'"

Still, there are people who greatly contribute to the fight against allergic reactions. Schools that completely prohibit peanut importation increased from 13% in 2005 to 18%.

At Mercer Elementary School, where Kalei Raiken and eleven other students suffer from severe food allergies, teachers and bus drivers have been trained to use EpiPens, and teachers explain allergies not only to students with allergies but to all students in the school.

In Connecticut, this is law. According to hagwon guidelines [Note: This appears to be an error in the original Korean text - it should be "school guidelines" based on context] established by this state, teachers must teach students about allergies. This prevents them from, for example, bullying classmates who can't eat grilled cheese sandwiches. Massachusetts, Vermont, and Tennessee also have allergy-related school guidelines.

This year, New York and New Jersey began creating their own guidelines. A federal bill in preparation would expand this further by providing up to $50,000 [approximately $38,000 USD] to each school and encouraging voluntary implementation of uniform guidelines so parents don't have to start the education process over from the beginning when students graduate or move to other states.

As awareness increases, some people wonder if food allergies might be exaggerated. While there are quite many children with allergies, less than 1% of children under five have peanut allergies, and 100-200 people annually die from severe side effects.

Parents who have become accustomed to receiving sensitive warnings from pediatricians to prevent their children from eating nuts and eggs may be unnecessarily frightened. Developing hives or stomach aches after lunch doesn't necessarily mean allergies.

For example, people who are lactose intolerant can't digest lactose, the main sugar in milk, and experience cramps or gas in their stomachs. Meanwhile, people with milk allergies have immune systems that identify milk protein as a risk factor and fight against it.

Allergy specialists say quite many children are told to avoid even foods that don't cause allergies. "Research shows that up to 25% of parents think their children might have food allergies," said Dr. David Fleischer of the National Jewish Medical and Research Center (Denver). "But only about 8% are confirmed as fact."

Accurate diagnosis requires time, skill, and patience. Allergy skin tests are extremely sensitive. About 60% overestimate the number of people who will react. Blood tests combined with carefully recorded symptom logs are even better.

When doctors see how many antibodies against specific food antigens have developed in the blood, it helps predict the risk of children developing allergies. The only way to definitively diagnose allergies is through food challenge tests. Doctors give patients small amounts of suspected eggs, wheat, or seafood and monitor them closely while checking for reactions.

Knowing in advance whether allergies exist relieves the burden on both parents and children. "If there's no need to avoid certain foods, the fact that family life has returned to normal is a great comfort," Fleischer said.

If science succeeds, that normal reality might someday come to child allergy patients. Last year, researchers at the National Jewish Medical and Research Center announced they had identified genes that protect mice from serious skin allergic reactions.

Researchers at Mount Sinai blocked allergic reactions in mice for 6 months, equivalent to a quarter of a mouse's lifespan, using herbal preparations. Now they're thinking of testing on humans. Sampson predicted that someday it might be possible to screen children's genes and intervene before itching or sneezing begins if risk is determined.

However, for now, this remains a pipe dream. Brian Berning's wish isn't so grand. He wants to grow up quickly and when his egg allergy disappears, eat "anything sweet" to his heart's content. Among the things he most wants to eat is birthday cake. After all that suffering, he deserves to be allowed to eat cake to his heart's content.

He's currently selling high-speed internet products. He shrugged his shoulders saying "I'm not confident I can receive my salary this month."

Just from his small voice and cautious manner of speaking, one could immediately tell Jang's timid personality. When told "Sales work probably doesn't suit you well," he nodded. "If I can't raise performance, I feel unwelcome at work and can't receive money. So I move to other workplaces, but they're all sales positions anyway."

Whenever he has time, Jang goes to entrepreneurship education institutions created by the government or local governments for training. Though he's genuinely interested in starting a business, he has neither capital nor the guts for it. The training fees he receives each time he attends educational institutions are more desperately needed. His bag was bulging with flyers and materials from various educational programs.

**High school graduate job seekers pushed out by overflowing college graduates**

"I'm getting older now and want to date and marry," he said, with profound loneliness appearing on his face. However, for Jang, who moves from company to company, there were no channels to meet and date romantic partners. From high school graduates to people with overseas MBA degrees, the stories behind individual job seekers vary, but anxiety sits in all their hearts.

Particularly unemployed people in their 30s who are older and have been job searching for a long time endure miserable situations living on minimum living costs. The enthusiasm they had when first challenging job searches has long been lost. Watching these young people who have lost all their youthful spirit and passion and sit in blank dismay, job seekers in their 20s also feel a sense of crisis.

One job seeker in his 30s met during reporting complained, "There are job fairs for the elderly, but there's no employment venue for unemployed people in their 30s or those seeking reemployment." To secure the limited—no, increasingly shrinking—vacant positions at companies, one must break through fierce unlimited competition. A recent Bank of Korea report announced that "the rate of taking jobs below one's qualifications decreased by about 3 percentage points compared to 2000."

This analysis suggests that instead of job seekers applying for lower positions, high-educated prospective workers joined the ranks of unemployment or economically inactive population. How can we resolve this phenomenon where high-educated unemployed increase while high school graduates are pushed out by college graduates? Korean society, with 2.57 million unemployed people with college degrees or higher, has no answer.

Reporter Park Mi-so smile83@joongang.co.kr

  "translated_title": "Have You Seen the Tears of Humanities Instructors Who Face Course Cancellations at Every Turn Due to 'Low Enrollment'?",
  "translated_text": "The reality of universities that shoulder our nation's future is utterly deplorable. Humanities courses symbolized by 'literature, history, and philosophy' are frequently plagued not by students but by course cancellation notices... Here is a French literature graduate's incisive critique of universities, told from a first-person perspective.

"When you look at evening, look as if the day were dying there. And when you look at morning, look as if all things were being born there. May what appears to your eyes be new at every moment. A wise person is one who marvels at everything."

André Gide's <Fruits of the Earth> was his spiritual autobiography and my spiritual pillar. More precisely, it was the finest book that made me, in my late teens, dream of university. Captivated by Gide, I resolved to pursue French literature.

That wasn't all. Among the writers I loved, many were from the French-speaking world. Starting with Alexandre Dumas, who wrote <The Three Musketeers> and <The Count of Monte Cristo> that everyone read in childhood, to Saint-Exupéry, forever in my heart with <The Little Prince>, Maupassant who wrote <A Woman's Life>, and the genius poet Rimbaud who died young...

I was often told I was more mature than my peers, but I didn't think that was necessarily bad. However, I wasn't exactly an outstanding student with excellent grades. Mathematics was particularly my weakness. Nevertheless, throughout three years of high school, I never once considered choosing a different major.

But my homeroom teachers urged me to reconsider and choose practical departments like business administration or law. The reason was clear. "The world isn't as easy as you think." They said I would greatly regret choosing French literature, which was difficult to make a living from—meaning it didn't lead to employment.

But I didn't care. I wanted to study, and if I could study properly, I wanted to see, hear, and learn what I wanted to do. Of course, my parents weren't pleased with my decision either. But I stubbornly persisted. I would become a great scholar, just wait and see. I even promised to work part-time jobs to cover tuition.

**University Culture Full of Propaganda**

After this persuasion, I was able to submit my application safely. In winter 2001, I finally got accepted to the French Literature Department at A University in Seoul. I was overjoyed. Now I could study to my heart's content, I thought. Little did I dream that moment would be the 'gates of hell.' From that moment on, I had to spend all eight semesters learning to wake up from the illusions I had about university.

The first gateway was freshman orientation (OT). On the first day of OT, I rushed to the outdoor theater on campus as instructed by the school. But a strange scene was unfolding there. In the outdoor theater were seniors holding flags for each department. To my eyes, they looked like people who had come to pick up kindergarteners, or rather, tour guides.

When I approached and carefully examined the phrases written on the flags, there were only words like 'steel,' 'vanguard,' and 'advance' in front of the department names. It was easy to see what this symbolized. The propaganda was so thick that I felt somewhat uncomfortable, but I decided to observe a bit more. Once students had gathered to some extent, several people came forward, introducing themselves as seniors.

They boldly announced their student ID numbers and names in loud voices. Behind them, several seniors stood with their hands behind their backs. They seemed to be upperclassmen, judging by their apparent age. It was what they called the 'FM' method of self-introduction. It was a kind of demonstration. As if to say, you freshmen should do the same from now on.

It reminded me of scenes I'd seen on TV. The sight of privates in the military energetically shouting their rank and name. Meanwhile, people from neighboring departments began to appear, dancing. They said it was doing movements to folk songs, but it was so embarrassing I could hardly bear to watch. Where else would you easily see people old enough to be called adults performing synchronized group dances with perfectly matched movements?

On my first day entering university, I established one principle. Starting tomorrow, I wouldn't attend OT. University is literally a place for 'great learning,' not a place for propaganda and agitation or experiencing military culture before enlistment, is it?

Of course, if I thought it was a gathering to build culture or form healthy relationships between seniors and juniors, I intended to participate. But this too was nothing but a futile hope. The atmosphere on the first day of my first MT [membership training retreat] and the first day of departmental academic society meetings wasn't much different either.

MT was almost exactly like OT. Just with some added entertainment. Now I want to talk about academic societies. I naturally joined the French literature society within my department.

I thought at least that place would be a gathering of university students who loved literature—novels, poetry, plays—and a space where intellectual conversations could take place. But that too was a misconception. Among the seniors, true book lovers were extremely few.

There were more ignorant(?) seniors who just pretended to know things superficially, making me wonder if they had properly read even one book. They were just department seniors rather than academic society seniors.

Naturally, I was puzzled. "Why did those seniors join the society, especially a literature society that should be somewhat serious?" The answer was surprisingly simple. It was exactly what my classmates did. The mechanism starts with OT. I didn't know well since I didn't attend from the second day, but close friendships had formed between seniors and freshmen.

Seniors seemed to compete to draw juniors into their respective societies. Though I don't know if it's true, there were rumors that societies with more members received more operational funding from the department.

**Academic Society Activities That Build Friendships, Not Scholarship**

Freshmen who were promised unlimited provision of alcohol and meals after joining societies seemed to focus on which senior to follow rather than their own interests. Was this only our class year's phenomenon? With this repeating every year, many societies had degenerated into ordinary social clubs contrary to their original purpose. Of course, not all seniors were like that.

Among the upperclassmen, there were a few who, befitting their major, were immersed in French literature. I think I only associated with such seniors. But even those seniors became very difficult to see after one semester. This phenomenon became more pronounced as the second-semester job-hunting season approached. Unlike the first semester, the campus atmosphere in the second semester was more cutthroat.

Around that time, I also quit the society. After finishing freshman year, most of my male classmates applied for leave of absence for military service. The few remaining classmates and female peers who stayed to advance to sophomore year had heated daily discussions about how to apply for double majors. One English literature friend who wanted to work in trade after graduation said she would apply for business administration as a minor, while another friend from the same department said she wanted to study syntax further.

At the time, I wanted to support the friend who had chosen deeper study. However, it didn't take long to realize my judgment was completely wrong. While others often couldn't take classes due to lack of seats during course registration, my case was different. I had plenty of room. The number of applicants for a liberal arts course, Modern Philosophy Lecture, didn't exceed 10 until the end of the registration period.

Having 11 people including the professor in that large lecture hall seemed like it would be as serious as a discussion forum. I also had expectations that I could gain deeper knowledge than in major courses. But that dream was shattered within a week. On the day of the first class, I left home with an excited heart, double-checking the classroom location.

"What kind of people will they be?" Already in my head, I was picturing discussing philosophy with them—Lacan, Derrida, Deleuze, and others. One person would speak, then the person next to them would share what they knew. While having such thoughts, the moment I entered the classroom, I couldn't help but be dumbfounded. "Course canceled due to insufficient enrollment."

**Humanities in an 'Age of Loss'**

The classroom was desolate, and on the blackboard was only a sheet of A4 paper with a few extremely bureaucratic words printed on it. Since this was my first time experiencing such a situation, I didn't know what to do. First, I sat down and thought carefully. I paid tuition and applied for a course I wanted, but they canceled the entire lecture due to insufficient enrollment? It was strange. There must have been a professor secured and conditions for classes established, which is why they posted it on the online course registration system, wasn't it?

While I was lost in thought, I heard footsteps. Looking toward the door, there was someone standing with two books in one hand and a bag in the other. They looked like a professor.

"Are you perhaps the professor?" "Yes. I hurried here, but you're the only student?" "It seems the class has been canceled."

The surprised professor looked toward the blackboard. After making a stiff face for a moment, he soon gave a bitter smile with a dejected voice, saying, "I didn't receive any notice... This happened last semester too, and now it's happened again." Not wanting to part ways immediately, I had a brief conversation with him. We found seats on a bench in front of the college building. He wasn't a full professor but a part-time instructor.

He said he traveled around universities nationwide like a Joseon-era peddler to give lectures. But even that was difficult due to lack of positions, and he confided this burden to a stranger he was meeting for the first time. I could guess how difficult it was. He said he had experienced course cancellations several times before, like this time. "This is the third time. Do students these days take such classes? It's not even shocking anymore."

He spoke as if it wasn't a big deal, but there was moisture around his eyes. When I said it was disappointing that I really wanted to take the lecture but couldn't, he continued, "When I was in university, there were still quite a few students like that." "In the past, there was something like an exploratory spirit for literature, history, and philosophy (文·史·哲). In a way, it was romantic, and that itself was something to be proud of. But it's not like that these days. People like you who are interested have decreased so much that they almost seem strange."

I had to agree with his point that there was inevitably little interest in non-practical studies unrelated to making money. He, who had pursued a philosophy doctorate in Germany, told me many stories about living in the world rather than philosophy, to someone like me who was still untainted by society. He said that although he had never properly taught philosophy lectures at universities, there was unexpectedly good response outside campus walls.

The point was that people thirsty for humanities were ordinary citizens, not university students. But he said that side didn't pay well either. This was due to the reality of humanities, where even if there were earnest auditors, the capacity was inevitably limited. Still, as his initial intention was, he was walking the scholar's path, so he was happy to be with people who had the passion to learn seriously.

The problem was still on the university side. Since there were no students seeking these courses, schools also reduced support, and the more this happened, the fewer people seemed to register for courses. Having seen this throughout my university life, it felt mundane now, but it was quite shocking at the time. I was surprised that the scholar's path I dreamed of was like that, and shocked again at the fact that the level of universities and university students was only that much.

The situation was completely different for business administration, which my high school teachers had recommended. As my English literature friend had done, non-business students were flocking to business courses for employment, so even when multiple courses were opened, students crowded in to bursting point. The vicious cycle of the rich getting richer and the poor getting poorer was ongoing even within the sacred ivory tower.

The crisis of my university life came from then on. I too began to wander. Even when taking major courses, I started with doubt. The behavior of professors and seniors and juniors became very irritating to me. To put it harshly, there were many 'fraudsters' among professors. Here, fraud means 'knowledge fraud.' How do professors who use 20-30-year-old textbooks and teach the same content every year manage to last until retirement?

They say nicely that humanities don't change, but my thinking was different from theirs. Humanities are bound to change with the times. That's why new interpretations emerge and new scholars are born, isn't it? Nevertheless, these people held on like iron fortresses, unwilling to give up their positions to juniors. In the case of French literature, with departments nationwide facing closure crisis and professor position announcements impossible to find even with thorough searching.

Actually, the quality of lectures was often much better from part-time instructors. For instance, one instructor who had recently returned from studying in France gave assignments in comparative literature courses to find commonalities between minority literature within French literature and minority literature in East Asian literature from Korea, Japan, and China, which included quite fresh content.

But these people seemed neither to receive attention nor grow within the university. Watching such scenes, anxiety about my dream that I had held since high school also crept in.

**Sick of Outdated Lectures...**

Students focusing on employment might be natural in a way. Especially during difficult job-hunting periods. However, I had the somewhat presumptuous thought that they should at least show some interest in the major they chose. There were many students in my department who only did cramming to get grades but attended literature classes without properly reading a single book.

The books they usually opened while sitting in the library were mostly English test materials or civil service exam-related books. Why were they attending university? Faced with such questions, I couldn't shake the impression that universities in our society were nothing more than college graduate factories. To them, diplomas were nothing more than employment certificates proving they had attended university.

One day, sitting in the library, I thought carefully about the value of my tuition. Considering courses with poor content that I had to take because they were major requirements, and the opportunity costs of that time, it was hard to calculate arithmetically, but I reached the conclusion that university might be an 'expensive library.' As I entered my 8th semester, I had many conflicts. Should I continue studying by entering graduate school, or should I start preparing for employment like other friends, albeit late?

The answer didn't come easily. In the current university reality, studying in a domestic graduate school would be burying myself in the ground, and it was obvious that even after obtaining a degree, I wouldn't be able to secure a part-time instructor position and would become a campus orphan. But jumping into the employment front also had problems. I knew all too well that there were no companies in Korea that would accept someone like me who had never taken a single practical studies course.

Moreover, I didn't have high TOEIC scores or other certifications that most students possessed. My GPA wasn't very good either. This was because I wasn't the type to seek out professors known for generous grading like other students.

**Universities Trying to Make Money with Fake Employment Rates**

Without being able to organize these thoughts, I graduated this past February. Though I had left university, I learned that I still wasn't free from the university. This was because of a phone call I received a few days ago. The content of the call from the school was "Are you employed?" No matter how important employment is, how could a university called the 'cradle of intellect' only ask recent graduate alumni about their employment status? The hidden meaning became apparent immediately in the conversation with the caller.

"Are you employed?" "Not yet." "Are you perhaps attending graduate school or even doing part-time work?" "I am briefly working as an instructor at a tutoring hagwon." "Then you are employed, alumni."

Could there be such an absurd thing? I couldn't help but be dumbfounded by this nonsensical employment rate survey. How could I be considered employed? This was a deception created by each university to encourage 'employment rate inflation.' I heard that universities use this data for promotion when attracting new students. It was to entice unsuspecting high school students.

This is the current reality of universities that should teach truth. If graduate employment rates are so important, I wish they would at least provide support enthusiastically. That way, many graduates who feel their tuition was wasted could receive help, wouldn't they? The reality is that while making constant efforts for new accounts—future freshmen—they ignore old accounts—graduates.

If university had been such a heartless place, I would never have entered in the first place. Of course, it's true that money is needed to maintain schools. Universities spare no major investment to secure money, an absolute necessity for survival. Splendid campuses, lecture halls equipped with cutting-edge facilities, and massive regular festivals to please students. Rather, securing faculty to improve lecture quality is a secondary concern.

Isn't this why people say universities have no future? Another thought also occurred to me. Given the weight universities occupy in our society, what role were universities actually playing? Standing before this somewhat lofty question, I naturally had to recall the past six years. There was a student who knocked on the door of higher education with dreams. He lost his dreams at university.

At the center was the logic that it doesn't make money. And now his alma mater tries to use him to make money. Even now, that university is full of job-seekers who must swallow the sweet and spit out the bitter. Didn't true universities and university culture never exist from the beginning? Living in this continuous series of doubts, I am now preparing to leave this country.

So-called studying abroad. But it's not to obtain a degree. It's to study properly once again. If I can study in an environment better than today's Korean universities, my dreams might rekindle. And in my current state of mind, I don't think I'll ever step on this land again. Rather than returning to endure a 'arduous march,' it would be much better to live as a scholar in the country where I study abroad or in another country. I take out André Gide's <Fruits of the Earth> again.

"After reading my story, throw this book away. And go outside."

Article by Kim Sang-jin, Monthly JoongAng reporter [kine3@joongang.co.kr], Lee Kyung-soo, Monthly JoongAng intern reporter [timehasgone@naver.com]
