She also repeatedly practiced solving only problems she had gotten wrong from CSAT past exam questions and Korea Institute for Curriculum and Evaluation mock exam math section problems while writing out solution processes. Ms. Kim said, "After solving problems, I always compared with solution processes in answer keys, and to prepare for high-difficulty problems, I solved practice problems from 'Silryeok Jeongseok' and EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] 'High-difficulty N Series' problem books to develop practical sense."

Preparing for English passages through reading comprehension training to find key points
Hankuk University of Foreign Studies

Hankuk University of Foreign Studies conducts essay exams only for humanities and social science tracks. In the 2012 mock essay exam, students were required to solve three questions in 120 minutes using two English passages and four Korean materials. The fact that two English passages were included is notable. However, Lee Seok-rok, Director of the Office of Admissions at Hankuk University of Foreign Studies, explained, "English passages will not exceed high school English textbook levels in vocabulary or sentence structure," adding, "The number of words used in passages will also be around 200, so students should not have major difficulties understanding the meaning of passages."

Strengthening interdisciplinary integration=Various materials related to English passages, literary works, and social phenomena are presented. In last year's early admission Round 2 essay exam, questions integrated content from various subjects including economics, Korean history, literature, and earth science. 'Atmospheric circulation' from earth science and 'explanations of economic circulation' from economics were composed as English passages. A paper on 'staphylococci' related to chemistry was included, and Kim So-wol's poem 'Chohon (Summoning Spirits)' and Kim Bu-sik's 'Samguk Sagi' were used as passages to strengthen integration between subjects. This year is expected to increase utilization of texts encountered in daily life such as textbook passages, newspaper articles, and literary works. In the 2012 mock essay exam, content from Jeon Gwang-yong's 'Kkeopitan Lee,' 'civic ethics' from high school ethics textbooks, and newspaper articles related to local talent recruitment quota systems were used as materials. Choi Kyeong-bok, director of the early admission general planning team at Vita Edu, advised, "While texts from both literary and non-literary categories are used evenly, most passages contain content from which concepts or issues can be derived," adding, "Training is needed to develop the sense for grasping core purposes, major topics, and controversial issues while encountering texts or materials from various genres."

Increased perceived difficulty of English passages=Even if English passages are not highly difficult, students cannot solve problems without properly grasping core content. This year's mock essay question 1 asked 'find the common topic addressed by English passages A and B, and describe the main point of each passage,' and question 2 asked 'compare and analyze two materials using English passages.' In last year's early admission Round 2 Essay A, all three questions required using content from English passages. Particularly, while questions asking for 'key words' from English passages were given as question 1 until last year, this year changed requirements to finding 'key topics,' so the perceived difficulty felt by test-takers is expected to rise. Director Lee emphasized, "Although passage length is not long, score differences can clearly widen depending on whether you can grasp the core and flow of the text," adding, "Students must develop the ability to grasp what the core content of texts is through textbook passages and describe main points in 100-150 character lengths."

Pay attention to changes in question 3 type=Question 3, which until last year required 'compare and analyze content of passages and materials,' changed to a 'problem-solving' type in this year's mock essay exam. A question was given asking 'defend content of other materials from the perspective of specific materials, and present expected counterarguments.' This reflects the university's intention to "evaluate students' creativity." To receive good evaluation, students must be able to write a complete essay using content they interpreted as 'evidence,' beyond simply grasping passage content. Training is needed in defending one's position based on specific perspectives or logically criticizing other positions from specific perspectives, and essay writing practice presenting expected counterarguments to one's position while providing counter-rebuttals.

Successful Applicant Interview Department of English Interpretation and Translation / Ms. Han Min-hye

"Hankuk University of Foreign Studies' humanities essay has more passages and materials compared to other universities. To organize matters that should be emphasized in each passage, it's advantageous to read questions first. Finding key words in English passages is important."

Ms. Han Min-hye (19, graduated from Ilsan Daejin High School, GPA 2.7 grade), who was admitted to Hankuk University of Foreign Studies' Department of English Interpretation and Translation last year through early admission Round 2 General Selection II (100% essay), advised, "Since questions finding and comparing/analyzing core points of passages carry significant weight, training to accurately extract passage themes is necessary." For this purpose, she developed the habit of dividing passages by paragraph, then finding key words and core points while organizing text structure. Ms. Han said, "Practicing diagramming text structure and content 20 times allows natural grasp of text flow," adding, "Afterward, I trained to organize passage main points into one sentence of about 100 characters."

Starting one week before the exam, she developed the habit of identifying which passages and materials should be connected in answer writing processes for each question, then noting matters to pay attention to during passage and material reading processes.

"Generally, the difficulty of vocabulary used in English passages is not high. However, it feels difficult because texts on topics not frequently encountered in daily life are presented." She analyzed passages on abstract themes like human consciousness, global environment, and welfare while solving CSAT foreign language section problems. She mainly practiced selecting key words and writing main points in Korean. When reading comprehension was blocked due to unknown specific words, she trained to infer themes by synthesizing text flow and content of other passages.

She also built background knowledge about social issues by clipping politics and economics-related newspaper articles. Ms. Han emphasized, "If topics you've encountered appear in passages on exam day, it helps not only in extracting text themes but also in providing evidence for your arguments when analyzing passages and raising counterarguments." She continued, "Since Hankuk University of Foreign Studies essays don't require long answers, it's important to grasp text cores and express them concisely," requesting, "Invest more time in accurately analyzing passages rather than developing writing ability.""
